Papua New Guinea's only cancer treatment centre at Angau Hospital in Lae has been caught in the middle of a media storm, with many taking to Facebook to complain that there is not enough funding for equipment and drugs to treat the patients there.

The CEO of Angau, Dr Christopher Kenyhercz told Pacific Beat this week that the media's coverage of the situation at the centre was mostly negative and unhelpful, and time would be better spent spreading awareness on how to recognise cancer symptoms early.

EMTV Journalist Scott Waide, who is based in Lae, says he agrees with Dr Kenyhercz that there are not enough messages on cancer prevention in PNG.

But he says the stories of the people suffering from cancer still need to be heard.

Listen here: http://ausp.lu/2lG5IaF
link_name: Public debate over Lae Cancer Centre continuing to divide opinion in PNG

status_message:
It's a problem that people worldwide are scrambling to address - how to stop the widespread death of coral reefs due to climate change and pollution.

With research from the World Resources Institute showing that all coral reefs could be under threat by 2050, one proposal is suggesting conservationists focus their efforts on the reefs least likely to die.

The 50 Reefs project aims to bring scientists together to identify the 50 reefs around the world that are the least vulnerable to climate change.

It's hoped that by doing this, those areas can then be properly protected and will one day replenish the reefs that have died off.

It's an initiative by The Ocean Agency, a not-for-profit organisation focused on communicating the need for ocean conservation.

Listen to Professor Ove Hoegh-Guldberg , The Ocean Agency's chief scientist and the director of the Global Change Institute at the University of Queensland, talk about the project:  http://ausp.lu/2l6kipW

Australia's former trade minister, Andrew Robb, says Australia should not be distracted by the Trump presidency as it prepares the first Foreign Policy White Paper in 14 years.

Mr Robb now works for the Chinese company that controls Darwin Port and is also chairman of Asialink, at Melbourne University.

He says Australia should take a long-term view and focus on the changes taking place across Asia.

The White Paper is intended to provide a roadmap for advancing and protecting Australia's international interests and to define how the nation engages with the world. Public submissions are invited and close next week.

What do you think Australia's foreign policy priorities should be in coming years?
link_name: Andrew Robb on Australia's Foreign Policy White Paper

Iranian refugee Loghman Sawari has been granted bail in Port Moresby. 

Mr Sawari was deported from Fiji earlier this month after flying from Papua New Guinea, where he was living as a refugee. 

His lawyer had said he intended to seek asylum in Fiji, but Sawari was arrested while on his way to a meeting with immigration officials, taken to the airport and sent back to PNG.

Police then charged him with giving false information in his application for a PNG passport.

PNG reporter Joy Kisselpar was at the court.
link_name: Iranian refugee Loghman Sawari granted bail

Hundreds of people attended a vigil last night in Port Moresby to pay their respects to Ruby Laufa. 

The law student died on Saturday, and police are currently investigating the circumstances surrounding her death.

Friends and family released purple lanterns into the sky, and remembered Ms Laufa as an extremely accomplished woman who had had a bright future ahead of her. 

"She was a force and she would have changed PNG. She would have been one of those women who would have been so successful in PNG and it's not just a lost for her friends and family, it's a loss for Papua New Guinea," Avis Babalu, who befriended Ms Laufa at university, told ABC's Pacific Beat program.

The vigil also marked what would have been the former miss PNG's 25th birthday. 

The memorial was initially just for family and those close to Ms Laufa.

But when they shared the details of the vigil with the wider public, her friend Avis Babalu says they were amazed at the number of people that arrived to pay their respects. 

"We were just overwhelmed with the turnout, like it was hundreds and hundreds of people," said Ms Babalu.

"It was mind blowing." 

Childhood friend Hanley Logoso said Ms Laufa had touched people from all different walks of life and that her ambitions had included to one day become Papua New Guinea's Prime Minister.

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-02-14/papua-new-guineans-mourning-death-ruby-anne-laufa/8269290
link_name: Papua New Guineans in mourning after death of former beauty queen

status_message:
The Royal New Zealand Air Force has flown more than a tonne of books to Papua New Guinea for disadvantaged children.

A C-130 Hercules aircraft on a scheduled flight to the Pacific took the books to Port Moresby.

They were collected from New Zealand libraries by Lorraine Goldsmith, the wife of PNG's Honorary Consul-General in Auckland, Dr Peter Goldsmith.

She says since the libraries in PNG have received the books, there has been an 80 per cent increase in children wishing to read them.

Ms Goldsmith tells Bruce Hill she was inspired to start the project when she saw the work done by the Buk bilong Pikinini program 

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-02-14/nz-air-force-flies-a-tonne-of-books-to-png-for/8270096

The Kingdom of Tonga is getting a formal postal system - but it's not your usual street names and numbers. 

Tonga has teamed up with a British company, called "What3Words" which uses GPS technology to assign three random words to every nine square metres across the planet.

For example, the address of Tonga Post's office in Nuku'alofa is: international.bashfully.placidity

It will be the fourth nation to adopt the system, and the first in the Pacific.

Listen to Tonga Post CEO Siosifa Pomana explain how it works: http://ab.co/2l5SWEA
link_name: Tonga's new postal system uses words, not numbers

Why are rugby's governing bodies in the Pacific so reluctant to change? They have complained constantly over the years that they don't get a fair deal from World Rugby, but when opportunities present themselves, local administrators refuse to embrace them. 

Former Fiji sevens coach Ben Ryan is a national hero after leading the team to Olympic glory, but he believes if the team is to achieve even more, then it needs to be set up as stand alone franchise, separate from the FRU. However the word is the FRU is not about to relinquish control. 

Now Cook Islands have terminated the contract of Stan Wright, their former captain who took the reins as national coach less than a year ago. 

Already he had established a fixture list for the national team unlike anything they've had before, with a tour to the Americas coming up in June, and he was building a list of new players who're keen to play for the islands, but he also wanted to see changes in the way the CIRU runs the game, and that's where he hit a wall.

http://ab.co/2kjZXy6

status_message: It's probably fair to say most boys growing up in Fiji want to be rugby players, and very few want to be referees. But Kaveni Talemaivavalagi and Tevita Rokovereni decided to go down that path, and now find themselves rubbing shoulders with Fiji's star players at the World Sevens Series. The two officiated for the first time in Wellington, and have just completed their second assignment in Sydney. Kaveni says he was told at school that Fiji has produced of hundreds of top class players, but not one referee who has reached the top level. Now after ten years hard slog, he has put matters right!

If these walls could talk … but all is now quiet at the Rocky Point hall, Moyston, western Victoria.

Photo taken by ABC Open contributor cinarto.

An amazing achievement by Papua New Guinea's Joanne Lagona to be chosen in the Women's Dream Team at the Sydney leg of the World Rugby Sevens series. PNG have never played at this level before, so no surprise that they didn't win a game. But of the 54 points they scored, Joanne scored 49 of them, and brought gasps from the crowd and pundits alike with her power and speed. Now she sits alongside World Player of the Year, Australia's Charlotte Caslick, on the Dream Team list!

A magnitude-6.9 earthquake has struck 284 kilometres south-west of Fiji's capital Suva just before 11am local time. 

The Pacific Tsunami Warning Center says the tsunami threat has now passed but people must remain vigilant and exercise caution near the sea.

An aftershock of 5.7 at a depth of 10km has also been reported. 

There have been no reports of damage or injury from Fiji. 

A magnitude-6.3 quake hit 582 kilometres south of Suva on Monday at a depth of 555 kilometres.

The former president of Nauru, Sprent Dabwido, is accusing the current government of playing games with his health.

Mr Dabwido has been told he needs specialist medical treatment in Australia for a heart condition, but he has yet to make the trip.

He was delayed for three months when the government opted to cancel his passport, but even though it was finally returned to him in mid-November, he still needs medical approval before he can leave the island, and he says it's proving hard to get.

The first cyclone of the season is forming off Fiji with the Tropical Depression due to be upgraded to a cyclone later today.

On its present track, it is likely to pass west of Fiji, but there is going to be continuing heavy rain, flooding and strong and gusty winds associated.

Director of NaDraki Weather service Neville Koop says that while the tourist areas west of Nadi are likely to be the hardest hit, the impact of the cyclone will be widespread.

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-12-16/fiji:-areas-west-of-nadi-likely-to-be-worst-hit-as/8126460

Hollywood actress Jennifer Lawrence has drawn scathing criticism for joking about disrespecting local Hawaiian customs.

Ms Lawrence said while filming The Hunger Games in 2013 in Hawaii, she'd "scratched her behind" on rocks considered sacred by indigenous Hawaiian people.

But some people took to social media, calling her actions insensitive and disrespectful.

Ms Lawrence later released a statement on Facebook - addressed to "the internet" - in which she apologised if she had caused offence.

But an advocate for Indigenous rights, Tina Ngata, says the attitude underlying Jennifer Lawrence's comments does real harm to indigenous people in the Pacific.

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-12-15/hollywood-star-apologises-for-cultural/8122818
link_name: Hollywood star apologises for cultural insensitivity after social media storm

Brenda Daniel was on board the Pacific Aria in Port Vila for the official launch of the new scheme.

Here's five hula tips by Noelani Le Nevez!

-  Stand up tall with knees bent for strength and stability.
-  Practice stepping your feet side to side, and moving your hips in 
a circular motion.
-  Ensure arm movements are extended, clean and graceful
- To understand and connect to the dance, research and understand the story
- And most importantly, smile!

Australia's federal opposition is asking for more information from the ABC about its decision to shut down its shortwave service to the Pacific.

Labor's spokesperson on International Development and the Pacific, Senator Claire Moore, says they are concerned that Australia's engagement in the region will suffer because of the decision.

Senator Moore was recently in the Pacific as part of a bipartisan delegation of Australian politicians visiting Vanuatu, Solomon islands and Samoa.

Ms Moore tells Bruce Hill Labor has concerns about what happens with radio broadcasting during cyclones, and whether other countries might want to fill the gap left by Australia withdrawing.

The Fiji government is distancing itself from the controversial mobile app "InstaCharge" as questions continue to be raised about its claims.

Douglas Stewart, a businessman from Las Vegas, says he's invented software to store extra energy in a phone, that can later be used to recharge its battery.

Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama was the guest of honour and keynote speaker at a launch event in Suva late last month.

But despite being heralded as the "global launch" of the app, it still isn't available, and there's little explanation of how it works.

A decision by the ABC to halt shortwave broadcasts early next year has been criticised by a former manager of Radio Australia.

The shortwave transmissions to Asia and the Pacific will cease from January 31st next year, as alternatives such as FM and internet become more prevalent.

Former head of Radio Australia and subsequently a consultant on international broadcasting in the Pacific, Jean Gabriel Manguy, tells Bruce Hill the decision is short sighted.

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-12-06/abc-decision-to-halt-shortwave-broadcasts/8097728
link_name: ABC decision to halt shortwave broadcasts criticised

status_message:
The ABC's shortwave transmission service that broadcasts Radio Australia across the Pacific is to be shutdown at the end of January.

An ABC statement says the move is in line with the broadcaster's commitment to expand its digital content offerings.

It says Radio Australia's audiences in the Pacific will to be able to listen to FM broadcasts and online and the savings are to be reinvested in a more robust FM transmitter network and increased regional content.

The move will save an estimated $2.8 million dollars a year and one of Australia's most senior diplomats in the region, James Batley, has called for this money to be re-invested into media and journalism across the Pacific

Mr Batley is a former Australian High Commissioner to both Fiji and Solomon Islands and he led RAMSI, the Regional Assistance Mission to Solomon Islands from 2004 to 2006.

He says it will be a pity to lose Radio Australia's shortwave transmission, but it's a move that reflects broader changes in the media landscape.

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-12-07/abc-shortwave:-senior-diplomat-calls-for-re/8098936
link_name: ABC shortwave: senior diplomat calls for re-investment of saved money

status_message:
Technology company Tesla has offered a glimpse of the future with an ambitious new solar project. 

For years the island of Ta'u in American Samoa had been spending upwards of $US8 million a year on unreliable diesel shipments to power its electricity generators.

But those big bills are a thing of the past now that Tesla and its recently acquired subsidiary Solar City, have completed a 5000-panel solar farm that supplies 100 percent of the islands power. 

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-12-07/tesla-offers-glimpse-of-the-future-on-american/8099022
link_name: Tesla offers glimpse of the future on American Samoan island

status_message:
The ABC will end its shortwave transmission service in the Northern Territory and to international audiences from 31 January 2017.

ABC International's shortwave services currently broadcast to PNG and the Pacific.

ABC International's Chief Executive Officer Lynley Marshall said the reinvestment from closing international shortwave services would maximise the ABC's broadcast capabilities in the region.

Read more: http://about.abc.net.au/press-releases/shortwave-radio/

Tonga's showstopper from Rio now has his eyes on 2018 Winter Olympics

The bare-chested Tongan athlete who stole the show at the Rio Olympics' opening ceremony is set to make more headlines after announcing his intention to bid for a spot at the Winter Olympics.

Pita Taufatofua is making the ambitious switch from taekwondo to cross-country skiing; the latest twist in the drive by the growing Tongan winter sports team to make it to the winter games in South Korea in 2018.

Team Tonga's Director of Sports, Steve Grundmann, says Pita's move is far more than just a publicity stunt.

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-12-06/tonga's-showstopper-from-rio-now-has-his-eyes-on/8095500

ABC International, which produces Australia Plus and Radio Australia services has announced it will be increasing its investment in content and services for Chinese, Indonesian and Pacific audiences. 

The changes - which are the result of a strategic review - mean that a number of single-person foreign language services will cease in coming months.

The closure of the Vietnamese, Khmer and Burmese language services will become effective on 2 December 2016, while the French service will continue until arrangements with France Television end in February 2017.

People from Papua New Guinea and north-east Australia carry small amounts of DNA of an unidentified, extinct human species, a new research analysis has suggested.

The analysis suggests the DNA is unlikely to come from Neanderthals or Denisovans, but from a third extinct hominid, previously unknown to archaeologists.

There are fears the Australian government's decision to stop funding HIV/AIDS programs in Papua New Guinea will leave thousands of people without affordable access to vital medication that keeps the virus in check.

Funding for current HIV and reproductive health grants from the Australian High Commission will wind up mid-next year.

The decision will affect about 20 per cent of patients who are taking antiretroviral treatments to suppress the progression of HIV/AIDS.

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-10-27/fears-for-those-with-hivaids-in-png-as-australia/7970092

The size of the Muslim population in Papua New Guinea has increased more than ten fold since the turn of the decade, rising from fewer than 500 to more than 5,000 people.

University of Melbourne honorary fellow Dr Scott Flower has been researching the rise of Islam in PNG, which he says is mainly from conversions among the indigenous population.

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-10-27/muslim-population-in-png-small,-but-quickly-growing/7970050

Five men who were accused of sorcery and held hostage by local leaders in the Kagua-Evare district of Papua New Guinea's Southern Highlands province have been released with the help of church officials.

The men were held for six weeks over the death of a local MP and were tortured. 

Catholic Bishop of the Diocese of Mendi, Donald Lippert, says the men were lucky to be freed alive after tense negotiation between police and local leaders. 

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-10-26/five-png-men-accused-of-sorcery-and-tortured/7965792

The 14 MPs serving jail time for bribery and corruption in Vanuatu may walk free due to a constitutional loophole.

The traditional Pacific Islands drink of kava is becoming increasingly popular in the west, particularly in the United States and the export industry is booming to keep up with demand. 

Prices for fresh kava in places like Vanuatu have almost tripled in the last few years, but the country is struggling to enforce quality standards. 

Vanuatu's director of Biosecurity Timothy Tumukon told the ABC's Pacific Beat program there is a push for regional-wide quality standards, but it's a long way off.  

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-10-05/booming-pacific-kava-industry-still-long-way-from/7904168

Papua New Guinea's Government says it will close Australia's offshore detention centre on Manus Island, but keep another asylum seeker facility on the island open.

In April, PNG's Supreme Court ruled the Regional Processing Centre was unconstitutional and ordered its closure.

However, Foreign Minister Rimbink Pato told the ABC's Pacific Beat program the court order applied only to the Lombrum naval base facility, not the larger centre at Lorengau. 

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-10-04/png-to-keep-refugee-facility-on-manus-island-open/7903020

60 years on from the first annual Goraka Show in Papua New Guinea's Highlands and a lot has changed. 

Back in the 1950s, many of the tribes in the Highlands were still living in isolation from the rest of the country, never mind the rest of the world.

However things changed when Australian patrol officers, the kiaps, introduced the Goroka Show creating an opportunity for dozens of groups to come together to show off their traditional culture.

Reporter Catherine Graue traveled to this year's festival and says while it's still a place for traditional culture, like much of PNG, it's also modernizing.  

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-09-19/papua-new-guinea's-highlands-tribal-culture-on/7857176

Phuong is one of 674,300 carers in Australia who were born overseas.
 
Today is the start of Multicultural Health Week. which has a focus on bringing attention to the thousands of multicultural carers in our community, like Phuong.

During the Vietnam War, the United States dropped twenty million gallons of chemicals onto the dense jungles of Vietnam, in order to cripple the North Vietnamese Army by destroying their ground cover.

That legacy lives on today, and Los Angeles-based documentary filmmaker Courtney Marsh traveled to Vietnam to document the effects of Agent Orange still being felt by Vietnamese people.

Courtney spoke to Beverley O'Connor on The World about 'Chau: Behind the Lines', which has been nominated for an Oscar.

Som Young moved to Australia from Thailand a decade ago and has been growing a variety of herbs and seasonal vegetables, including Asian ones, for nearly seven of those years.

Som enjoys the life of a farmer and working seven days a week.

"A good thing to grow all your fresh vegetables and supply to the customer and your customer is very happy, and easy to sell and a lot of people love that too," she says.

"I like to grow all my vegetables, that's how I was brought up."

Scandal-weary sports fans can find perspective from this sports success story in the Pacific.

The Pacific Sports Partnership (PSP) is an Australian government-funded development program working across nine countries in the Pacific.

Through the various PSP programs cricket has been used to reduce violence against women, table tennis to create opportunities for Fijians with disabilities and the "Mum's a Hero" basketball program in Vanuatu and Fiji has encouraged women to adopt healthier lifestyles.

status_message:
Today was the big announcement of the 25 under 25 from triple j which honours young people doing extraordinary things. 

Like Cleo Loi who recently started a PhD in Astrophysics at the University of Cambridge.

"I've always wanted to be a scientist. I've always been fascinated by the natural world — how stuff works," she says.

Cleo's undergraduate research at the University of Sydney was a major astrophysics discovery of plasma tubes in the earth's ionosphere using the Murchison Widefield Array (pictured). Her groundbreaking discovery in 2014 has had the science community buzzing ever since.

A YouTube video about her work has been viewed over a million times, and Cleo's work is having a global impact: she was invited by Australia in the United States to visit the US National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency to discuss the impact her findings might have on civilian and military navigation systems.

Cleo believes that the world needs "to be more open-minded about people who don't necessarily follow the rules. Mindsets like "you shouldn't do something because it hasn't been done" — those barriers are dangerous to progress and they need to come down."

"They mainly focused on the smooth and peaceful transfer of the state responsibilities to the future government ... to cooperate bilaterally so that there won't be any concerns among the people," said the president's spokesman and information minister, U Ye Htut.

This is Brendan Moerman and his English class in Phnom Penh.
After completing a TESOL (Teachers of English to Speakers of Other language) certificate in Adelaide, Brendan spent four years teaching English in Hanoi and is now teaching at an international school in Cambodia.

"I've had lots and lots of rewarding and interesting experiences teaching. One of the kindergartens I worked at in Hanoi would play Ricky Martin's 'The Cup of Life' at full volume and have all the children dance to it with cheerleader style pom poms -- it never failed to make me smile.

"Since moving away from Australia, things that seemed so important back home now feel trivial. It's a cliche, but moving overseas broadens your outlook and gives you a whole new set of skills. I've become more confident and feel like I can do things I never would have thought before. I'm now a lot better at driving a motorbike through crazy traffic! Before moving to South East Asia, I wish I'd have known it was so difficult to buy clothes if you're over 6 foot!

"Missing friends and family, and the general madness of both Hanoi and Phnom Penh can get to you sometimes. But I do know that if I were ever to leave that I will miss meeting new, like minded people and being able to travel very easily."

* Australia Plus Expats will be sharing more expat teacher stories like this over the coming weeks - so head over there for more!

The NRL Grand Final this Sunday night is an all-Queensland affair. The Brisbane Broncos are after their first NRL premiership since 2006, led by master coach Wayne Bennett. status_message:
This story proves how powerful social media can be:

Earlier this week, we posted this photo to a number of ABC Facebook pages, and asked people whether they knew the three Australian men.

Judy (the woman in the photo) had been trying to find them after they helped her climb the Great Wall of China, together with her carer (the man in the blue and black jacket). They carried her with her wheelchair all the way up, waited for her to finish, and carried her back down.

Judy knew nothing about the men - not even their names - but had always wanted to say thank you for helping her achieve a lifelong dream.

It's been exactly five years since this photo was taken, and thanks to these Facebook posts, we managed to track down these men! They are Dr Charles Su, Dr Kimberley Tan and Dr Thomas Hardy (pictured from right) and they're all opthamologists, who were in China for a work conference.

Dr Kimberley Tan says "it was a pleasure to help another human being, but anyone would have done the same thing."

We've let Judy know and she is thrilled. She'll be getting in touch with all three men to say a long-awaited thank you.

UPDATE on our #LibSpill coverage tonight:

On Australia Plus TV - there will be live, rolling coverage of ABC News 24 from 8.30pm AEST until 12am AEST.

On Radio Australia - there will be live, rolling coverage of ABC News 24 until 10pm AEST. That will be followed by The World, which will run until 11pm AEST.

Online, you can stream ABC News 24 (without geoblock) here: ab.co/abcnews24 or on YouTube: ab.co/abcnewsnow #libspill

Malcolm Turnbull has been pursuing greatness his entire career. He rose to fame as a barrister when he successfully defended retired MI5 spy Peter Wright, who fought for the right to publish the book Spycatcher.
In 2004, he ruthlessly pursued Liberal preselection for the seat of Wentworth, where he had lived his whole life, against sitting member Peter King. He entered Parliament for John Howard's final term in office.
He rose to become leader of the Liberal Party in opposition, before losing a challenge by one vote to Tony Abbott.
Read about his path towards the top via ABC News: http://ab.co/1Kxp87w

Prime Minister Tony Abbott says he will defy Malcolm Turnbull's leadership challenge, and has called for ballots for the leadership and deputy leadership of the party.
See all the significant speeches from this #libspill on the ABC News 24 YouTube channel ab.co/abcnews24, or follow the ABC News blog at http://ab.co/1O9Zg6b

The Papua New Guinea Island of Bougainville is going to vote to become independent in 2019.

That's the confident prediction of John Momis, President of the Autonomous Bougainville Government.

The island was the scene of a bloody and prolonged civil war over the profits from the Panguna Copper and gold mine in the 1990s, but a peace agreement formally ended the conflict in 2001 by promising a referendum on independence, which is scheduled for 2019.

President John Momis says as PNG celebrates 40 years of independence, Bougainvilleans don't feel they're part of the country.

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-09-14/bougainville-set-for-independence-says-momis/6774710

For most of Australia's post-European settlement history, the nation has been "in, but not of" Asia. 

Over the past few decades, much has changed. Immigration from Asian nations has dramatically increased, Australia's biggest markets are in Asia, and it is now the football champion of Asia. 

As heard this week on ABC RN's Life Matters, we look at how Australia can benefit from the future prosperity of the region.

One in four Australians are born overseas and over a third have English as their second language.

Interpreters are crucial in our justice system.

Their jobs can include interpreting interviews with police suspects, attending court and even accompanying police on drug raids or domestic disputes.

It's interesting work, but it can also be stressful.

New research has found that many interpreters experience what's known as 'vicarious trauma' as a result of their work, as heard today on the Law Report.

Do you let yourself disconnect, tune out and completely switch off during a holiday?

It's hard to completely disconnect on holidays with email, text, calls and social media at your fingertips on your smartphone. 

So is it time for a digital detox? And is it really a holiday, a refreshing break from the daily grind, if you're always connected?

Planning a wedding abroad?

It used to be that travelling overseas was saved for the honeymoon. Nowadays, brides and grooms are packing their bags for the wedding itself and Australia is a popular destination, especially for Chinese couples.

Have you volunteered in an orphanage or school, or helped to build something while travelling through Asia, Africa or South America?

This form of tourism seems admirable, but there's an unsavoury underbelly to volunteer tourism that's not so obvious. 

On Encounter, we find out the ethical and religious motivations of young volunteers in developing countries and how what they see isn't necessarily what's happening on the ground.

Listen on Thursday, 22 January at 1pm AEDT or online here: http://ab.co/15sNNuB

Adelaide photographer, Yvonne Hill recently won a national prize for the portrait of her husband with macular degeneration. 

It is fitting that the subject of Yvonne Hill's award-winning portrait is the person who first introduced her to photography.

"Whenever he [David] found a blazed tree he would hand me his camera and say 'please take my picture next to this tree'," Ms Hill said.

Ms Hill's photography skills have escalated since, but her love of her portrait subject remains the same.
link_name: Shooting love: Adelaide photographer wins national prize for portrait of husband

Buddhists came to Australia more than 150 years ago and today Buddhism is flourishing here. 

On Encounter, we hear the fascinating stories of the earliest Western or convert Buddhists, and their history isn't as peaceful as you might imagine: there's been a communist coup, police raids, ethnic divides, and fights for gender equality. 

We find out how these conflicts have been an essential part of Buddhism's adaptation to this land and its people.

Listen to the program on RA at 2pm AEDT Friday, or online via the link below.

Commerce: buying and selling – it's been part of everyday life for centuries. But, add social media to the mix, with its very clever algorithms, and suddenly you've got a whole new ball game.

Death, wherever it happens, is complicated. 

When a zoo animal dies, people often think it's fed to the carnivores. However, a dead animal is very valuable as an educational tool, and Leo Oosterweghel, director of the Dublin Zoo, says they sometimes display specimens in the zoo's Learning & Discovery Centre.

But what about the keepers who might have cared for this animal for a decade or more? How does it feel when you see the skull of a beloved animal displayed in public?

In this episode of Zoo Diaries, on Radiotonic, Leo prepares a specimen for eventual educational purposes and we find out how animals – both human and non-human animals – grieve.

Listen on your radio at 9pm AEDT, Wed 10 December or online here: http://ab.co/1vTgdqq

Photo: Giraffe skull (Colette Kinsella)

For years, depression has been seen as a biological condition, and medication as the best treatment. But drugs don't suit everyone and evidence shows that psychological, social and cultural influences play a strong role in the condition. 

Tomorrow (Tue 9 Nov) on All In The Mind, we look at some different approaches to treatment: clinical hypnosis and a new form of brain stimulation. 

Listen on your radio at 2pm AEDT or online via the link below. 
Ways to listen: http://bit.ly/1dzXSCb
link_name: Taming the black dog—new approaches to depression

status_message:
When Michael Park was a boy his family migrated from Korea to Sydney. 

He shares the story of his parents' unlikely marriage, remembers his family's early years in Australia, and reflects on how a racist incident in high school changed his outlook on life.
link_name: Michael Park: from Seoul to Sydney

status_message:
An update for followers in the Philippines: Typhoon #Hagupit/Ruby has weakened slightly, and has been downgraded from a category 5 super typhoon.

But it is still likely to remain destructive when it makes landfall on Sunday morning.

For the latest developments, keep an eye on the ABC News World page here: http://ausp.lu/s-WorldNews, and if you're in the Philippines, be sure to monitor local emergency services.
link_name: Evacuations underway as Super Typhoon Hagupit nears Philippines | ABC News

status_message:
Today is International Volunteer Day. 

In the regional city of Geelong in Victoria, local community radio station 94.7 The Pulse broadcasts in over 15 different languages. 
 
Their team of dedicated presenters volunteer their time to help their communities feel more connected and to raise awareness about Geelong's cultural diversity. 
 
We meet some of the people whose voices help others to feel at home.  
 
Do you volunteer in your community? Share your story in the comments below.
link_name: Volunteers a voice for diaspora communities

status_message:
When people talk about "The Asian Century", they're usually referring to the expected economic and political dominance of Asia over the next hundred years. But if the growth of Christianity in the region continues, then the 21st century could also turn out to be the Asian Christian Century.

Does the rise of Asian economic might coinciding with the rise of Christianity have the potential to alter the religious profile of our region?

We ponder this question on Encounter, Friday 5 December at 2pm AEDT.

Meet a man who had deep brain stimulation surgery: probes were inserted through his skull and he was woken up in the middle of it to answer the surgeon's questions. He had great results for his Parkinson's disease—and deep brain stimulation can be used for psychiatric conditions as well—but in some parts of Australia it's banned.

A fascinating topic on All in the Mind, Tuesday 2 November at 2pm AEDT.

"We must make sure that we don't forget that we all live in the same region and Australia and New Zealand are very much part of that region." - PNG Prime Minister Peter O'Neill speaking with Radio Australia's Pacific Beat on Friday 28 November. 

If you missed Bruce Hill's interview with PNG's Prime Minister, listen online here: http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/international/radio/program/pacific-beat/oneill-wants-australia-nz-to-remain-in-the-pacific-islands-forum/1394163

We have some important information for our listeners who tune in to Radio Australia via satellite.

From Sunday 30 November, the satellite delivery will no longer be available from Intelsat 19. Those who listen to RA directly from the satellite will need to re-tune their decoders to Intelsat 18 using the satellite parameters available via the link below. Listeners currently tuned to Intelsat 18 will also need to re-tune as the parameters have changed.

Fruit picking is a popular summer activity in Australia for both locals and tourists.

Which type of fruit would you choose to pick?
link_name: A guide to Australia's summer fruit-picking season

status_message:
If you are in deep emotional pain, the last thing you want to hear is that you are untreatable. Yet, this is very often the experience of people diagnosed with borderline personality disorder. 

This week on All In The Mind, we looked at what is probably the most stigmatised mental illness there is, ever since it was first described in the era of psychoanalysis. 

If you missed the program, you can listen online via the link below. #RAOnAir
They've been flying silently for millions of years but now owls are helping scientists to improve the way we design aircraft.

Science fiction stands on the bridge between fantasy and reality. It allows us to question our world, and think of what might be possible. In this way, SciFi showcases our greatest fears and hopes for society.

So, for the uninitiated, this classically geeky genre isn't really about Martians, warp drive or talking robots -- it's about us and where we are heading.

This Sunday on Future Tense (11:30am AEDT), Wendy Zukerman explores how alien worlds can help us wade through gender politics, dream up new economies and question the state of technology.

The unfinished and disused tunnels under the centre of Australia's biggest city, Sydney, are home to bomb shelters and an albino eel, among other things.

Rumour has it that the army sends troops down there to train for weeks at a time in the complete darkness.

Off Track has gained access to the restricted areas of Sydney's underground rail system, and will shine a head torch onto the mysteries it contains this week.

To see more photos or to hear the program online, simply click on the link below. You can hear the program on Radio Australia
on Thursday 20 November at 1pm PNG time/10am Cambodia time.

Shannon Harvey was diagnosed with an autoimmune disease when she was in her early twenties. In her search for a cure, she not only became well, but she found strong scientific evidence linking our minds and our physical health. 

On All in the Mind, we hear some remarkable stories of people adding mind body medicine to their prescription and recovering from a range of chronic illnesses, including multiple sclerosis and cancer.

You can listen to the program on Tuesday 18 November at 2pm AEDT or online via the link below.

Take a look at these photos from Brisbane as the city gets ready to host this weekend's #G20 summit, with world leaders arriving in the Queensland capital today.

You can follow what's happening at the summit on TV with Australia Plus TV: http://tv.australiaplus.com/ 

Follow the coverage online here with ABC News: http://ausp.lu/G20Bris and learn more about what all the G20 fuss is about here: http://ausp.lu/s-G20CheatSheet

In his book 'The Dark Box, the Secret History of Confession', John Cornwell argues that the ritual of one-to-one confession in the Roman Church has had largely detrimental effects on the young and on priests.

The psychology of confession, the theology of bodily impurity, and the 'quick fix' of absolving sin are some of the issues explored in a conversation with John in his London home.

You can listen to this conversation tomorrow (Sat 15 November) on The Spirit of Things, at 11am AEDT, or online here: http://ab.co/1v5F1NS

Image by Angela Marie.

This week, Encounter spends a day with Khaled Sabsabi. 

Khaled arrived in Australia at the age of 12, as a refugee from the Lebanon civil war. As a community activist, it's not surprising that  harmony and reconciliation are at the forefront of his concerns. These themes also run through his work as a visual artist and hip hop producer. 

Presented by David Rutledge, Encounter airs at 1pm PNG time/2pm AEDT Thursday 14 November. If you prefer to listen online, simply click on the link below.
link_name: A Day in the Life, pt.2 - Khaled Sabsabi

status_message:
What will a dog do for a tennis ball?

Cross-breeds Kuna, Sparky and a tennis ball are part of a relatively novel approach to locating the endangered quoll – the smallest of Australia's 'native cats' – at Carnavon Station Reserve in Central Queensland. 

We bring you the full story on Off Track, Thursday 13 November at 1pm PNG time/2pm AEDT.
link_name: What will a dog do for a tennis ball?

status_message: Australians paused today to commemorate those who died serving their country in wars past. On Remembrance Day, the nation pauses for a minute's silence at 11am. People also wear poppies to symbolise the blood spilled during battle. http://ausp.lu/1uVj6sM

One day in 2009 a 24-year-old New York journalist woke up alone in a strange hospital room, strapped to the bed, under guard, unable to move or speak.

To the horror of her family and friends, her behaviour was inexplicable and frightening. She was paranoid, delusional, and sometimes catatonic.

Hear her first-hand account of this month of madness and how the terrifying mystery of her illness was solved on All in the Mind, Tue 11 November at 2pm AEDT.
link_name: Brain on fire: my month of madness

status_message:
Andrew Pike's work in the film industry has earned him a slew of national and international awards.

If you enjoyed Strictly Ballroom, Shine, Road To Nhill, or Message From Mungo then you can thank Andrew because he played an integral role in getting them onto the big screen.

It's no surprise that Andrew owns an enviable—if not largely unmanageable—collection of soundtracks.

Andrew is our guest collector on Rare Collections, Sunday 9 November at 9:30pm AEDT.
An incredible cloud formation spotted on the weekend in central New South Wales, Australia.

'I fell in love with the labyrinth and for some reason, for me, walking mediation just does it for me, it's beautiful and it gets me into that peaceful place really easily.'

This week on Off Track, we meet Emily Simpson, who was so taken by a labyrinth she walked in San Francisco, that she spent two years fundraising 500 thousand dollars towards the construction of a magnificent sandstone labyrinth in Sydney.

Listen on air at 2pm (AEDT) Thursday or online via the link below.
Australia Plus' Bethany Keats and Claire Sheed-Finck capture Melbourne Cup 2014
Tragic news from Flemington ...
link_name: Admire Rakti collapses and dies after Melbourne Cup

How does a puffin play a piano?

Helen Mark from the BBC takes us on a journey to Coquet Island, a low lying rocky outcrop off the coast of England.

The island is the nesting site for an amazing array of sea birds, including glorious Puffins.

Each summer a group of wardens and volunteers live on the island to observe and aide the thousands of birds that use the island to nest after migrating from Africa.

In tomorrow's edition of Off Track, at 2pm AEDT Wednesday, Helen Mark joins Head Warden Paul Morrison to give us a tour of this isolated place, including the world's first puffin piano.

Image by Naggobot, courtesy of flickr.

On Monday 27 October, in a special edition of Into the Music, producer Camilla Hannan speaks to contemporary women composers in Australia about their experience of making a life in music composition.

Camilla is a sound artist in her own right, and in 2012, was represented in a book by Rosalind Appleby, called 'Women of Note: The Rise of the Female Composer'.

"While my work very much sits at the more avante-garde end of the musical spectrum, I was fascinated by those more 'conventional' composers who struggle to have their work performed, published and reviewed. Why work so hard for so little recognition?" 
Camilla Hannan. 

Check what time the program airs in your region here: bit.ly/rasched
To read more about it or to listen online, click below.

An Australian facing the death penalty in #Bali has used his time in prison to produce a series of paintings, with nearly all selling within hours of going on show... 

Via Australia Plus: http://ausp.lu/1FAC4Id

With the internet, social networking and increasing travel around the world, the way cultural globalisation spreads is now far quicker and more diverse. Cultural trends don't only flow from the US to the rest of the world, but in all directions. 

So will we end up with one homogeneous 'world-culture'? 

No – says author Doug Hendrie. He talks us through the rise of 'hybrid cultures' on Big Ideas at 8pm AEDT later today, via the RA Asia stream. 

(If this time doesn't suit - no problem! You can listen online after the show airs, just click on the link below.)
From our Australia Plus Indonesia team: Messages of support to Indonesia's new president #Jokowi from students learning the language at Monash University in #Melbourne...

Would you GPS track your pet? A new Australian start-up is producing a collar that will do precisely that! Host Marc Fennell talks us through some of the (odd) benefits tomorrow on Download This Show (9pm AEDT, Sunday 19 October).

Image by Bruce Fingerhood, sourced from flickr.

Dancehall is a broad & controversial genre, with polarised themes. 

At one end, you've got the conscious Rastafarian teachings of roots reggae. At the other, you have the materialism and narcissism of gangster hip hop. 

Dancehall is our final theme in Rick Howe's five-part series, Island Music: A History of Reggae, which concludes on Thursday 16 October at 9pm AEDT. 

Make sure you listen on your radio, as the program is not available as a podcast due to copyright. 

Image: Rick meets dancehall reggae artist Jah Vinci (supplied).

Remember the days of the radio drama? While they're not as ubiquitous as they were back in the 1940s, radio plays are still considered to be a powerful medium and a unique audio experience. 

It's a mode of storytelling that requires deeper imagination, as voices take on characters on a virtual stage inside your head.

Today, on Radiotonic, we are presenting a specially created radio drama in support of Mental Health Week. 'The Eternal Moment' tells the story of Zoe, a psychiatric patient who believes she is the Queen of Time. Zoe is confident that her map-like drawings can evoke the 'eternal moment,' in which she'll be set free of time itself.

Listen on RA at 9pm AEDT (Wed 15 Oct), or online via the link below.

It's a wicked problem, says social technologist Suw Charman-Anderson. That is, the lack of civility online when people leave comments. 

We tend to blame the poison on so-called "trolls". But does blaming others overlook our own role in reducing standards of online discourse?

In a two part series, Future Tense looks at the difficulties involved in fostering a genuine online discussion. And we question why so many comment threads quickly deteriorate into the banal, offensive and abusive.

Listen to the series on Sunday 12 and 19 October, at 11:30am Sydney/ 10:30am PNG time.

How do international students adjust to living and studying in Australia? 

A new play from La Trobe University gives voice to the fears, struggles and successes of life down under. http://ausp.lu/1uEqBCF
link_name: International students share their personal experiences of Australia on the stage

status_message:
On Island Music this week, presenter Rick Howe talks about the reggae DJ. 

In reggae, the DJ is the master of ceremonies. The DJ raps or chats over pre-recorded rhythm tracks...and this was happening in Jamaica long before hip hop even started. 

Island Music airs at 9pm AEDT on Thursdays, and is repeated at 11am AEDT on Saturdays.

Read more about how Rick delved into the archives of reggae's finest sounds to produce Island Music for Radio Australia:  ausp.lu/1E6RX8B

Just another day in #Australia....

Two kangaroos have been filmed fighting for five minutes on a suburban street on the New South Wales central coast. (video by Rodney Langham, story by ABC News http://ausp.lu/1xn12FK)
link_name: Wild kangaroo street fight Aussie style

status_message:
'The book [Family Life] was 9 yrs overdue. There was no point writing a book unless it was very good' - Akhil Sharma.

Not long after his family emigrated from India to the US, Akhil Sharma was just 10 when his 14 year old brother dived into a pool and was permanently brain damaged. 

Earlier this year, he wrote a heartbreaking, very autobiographical novel, Family Life, about this shocking loss.

He's our guest later this evening on Books and Arts Daily, broadcast from the Ubud Writer's Festival. Listen on your radio at 11pm AEDT, or you can stream or download the audio from the website below.

#uwrf14
link_name: Ubud Writers & Readers Festival: Akhil Sharma

This week, Australia is observing Mental Health Week, which includes World Mental Health Day on Friday the 10th of October.

Here at Radio Australia and Australia Plus, we are going #MentalAs... a campaign run by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) as part of Mental Health Week in Australia. You'll hear plenty of discussion about mental health throughout the week on RA - looking at the latest scientific research, first-hand experiences, common taboos, treatments and more. 

If you are feeling distressed, or need advice or support, you should consult your local medical professional.

Every Friday, our Australia Plus Indonesia team comes to work wearing #batik, the traditional fabric of Indonesia. 

Yesterday, Thursday October 2 was National #BatikDay in Indonesia and to celebrate, our team here in Melbourne and in Jakarta wore batik in vibrant colours, shades and patterns.

Tonight on RN Drive, hear our interview with legendary comedian, musician, actor and movie maker, Bill Bailey. The show commences from 6pm AEST.

Here he is with our Southeast Asia Editor, Sastra Wijaya, who looks very chuffed indeed! 

#QI #BlackBooks #rndrive

In the fourth and final lecture of the Boyer Lectures, Professor Suzanne Cory highlights the concerning scientific brain drain in this country: "We are losing women from all areas of science and the deficit at senior levels is particularly disturbing."

Hear the final installment this Thursday 2 October at 2.30pm AEST on Radio Australia, or click through via the link below.

The rivalry between Apple and Samsung is fierce, but is the competition between the world's biggest phone manufacturers intensifying? And the humble USB – is it about to become more powerful and useful than before? 

Join presenter Marc Fennell and his guests as they attempt to answer these questions on Download This Show tomorrow (Tue 30 September) at 2.30pm AEST, on Radio Australia.

Image by Arne Heijenga, sourced from Flickr.

#AFL GRAND FINAL DAY!

Listen in to all of the action on Radio Australia from 12pm today Sydney time. 

Due to broadcast restrictions, the game won't be streamed online, but find out if you can listen in on the radio here: http://ausp.lu/1vl5Nzb

(picture by Sastra Wijaya)

Ever since Stanislavsky pioneered 'method acting', actors have been tortuously delving into their psyches and memories to find a truthful way of performing.

A more recent technique is all about the body, not the mind.

Proponents suggest that it's useful for all forms of communicating, not just acting. It's based on the theory of 'embodied cognition'. So, what is embodied cognition?

Find out tomorrow (Tuesday 23 September) at 2pm AEST on The Body Sphere, or listen online via the link below.

Over the last twelve months the total number of prisoners across Australia jumped 11% to 34,000.

Why is this happening? Is it a reaction to a crime wave? 

In a Forum held in Melbourne, organised by Australian Human Rights Law Centre & Smart Justice, the four panelists agree there's no question that fighting crime is a complicated task and requires a range of strong responses. But does locking up more people build a safer community?

Find out on the Law Report tomorrow (Saturday 20th) at 10:30am AEST or listen online via the link below.

If all you know of reggae is Bob Marley, then we have a series for you!

In a brand new show created for Radio Australia, DJ and radio presenter, Rick Howe takes us on a journey through the history of reggae: from ska to roots, DJ to dancehall and everything in between. 

Don't miss the first episode tonight at 9pm AEST. The series will be broadcast at the same time each Thursday and repeated at 11am AEST on Saturdays.

In the second talk of the Boyer Lectures, Professor Suzanne Cory shows how extraordinarily important scientific research and development is for our economy.

Who would have thought that a search for black holes could lead to Wi-Fi?

Hear the second lecture today on Radio Australia at 2:30pm AEST.

We'll be broadcasting the third lecture at the same time next Thursday 25 September, followed by the final lecture on Thursday 2 October.

The Boyer Lectures are delivered annually by leading public figures, on topics of special relevance to the Australian community.

We are mourning the death of Pierre Riant, executive producer of Radio Australia's French service, who passed away on Friday following a battle with cancer.

These photos remind us of some of the great memories we have of him.

On Pacific Beat, ABC International's Head of Mekong and the Pacific, Domenic Friguglietti, remembers his colleague of 27 years: http://bit.ly/1wyp2rQ

You can be thin and unhealthy and you can be overweight and healthy. It all depends on your fitness. 

Welcome to the obesity paradox.

On The Body Sphere at 2pm AEST today, host Amanda Smith talks to health experts about this issue, and considers whether public health emphasis needs to focus more on gaining fitness rather than losing weight.

Find out how you can listen on RA in your region here: bit.ly/raregions

To our friends and listeners

It is with great sadness that we inform you of the passing of our friend and colleague Pierre Riant, who was the Executive Producer of our French service. 

Pierre passed away in Melbourne late on Friday evening, following a battle with cancer.  

Pierre started working for Radio Australia in 1983. He was a dedicated journalist and believed in the role that RA plays as an international public broadcaster. He was committed to serving the French Pacific and was dedicated to ensuring citizens across the region had access to important news and information that impacted their daily lives. He was inventive and creative, always looking at new ways to improve the delivery of valuable content. He was a wonderful colleague and nurtured the development of other staff here at Radio Australia, in particular Caroline Lafargue.

Pierre will be greatly missed and his passing will leave an enduring gap in all our lives. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family.

It's week one of the #NRL finals, and we are broadcasting the Melbourne versus Canterbury game #live  today from 1530 AEST. Melbourne are specialists at the business end of the season, while the tough tackling Bulldogs will be no pushovers. 

If you're looking for more sports news, live scores, features, analysis and photos from the world of sport, check out ABC Grandstand online, via the link below.

Tonight, an #AFL blockbuster in Perth: Fremantle versus Port Adelaide. The Dockers pushed the Swans all the way last week, but will have to be at their best to stop the free-flowing Power.

Listen live on RA tonight from 1830 AEST.

And if you're looking for more news, live scores, features, analysis and photos from the AFL Finals, take a look at ABC Grandstand on Facebook or via the link below. #AFLFreoPower

As you might have heard on Life Matters - ABC Radio National this morning, we here at Radio Australia and Australia Plus are still getting sweaty (and having lots of fun) for the #ABCGetFit challenge. 

Our latest foray into fitness: anti-gravity yoga! Check out some of the pics below and if you're doing the challenge, let us know how you're going.

Just a reminder that the challenge involves exercising for five hours a week for six weeks. To hear more, tune into Life Matters on weekdays at 9am AEST on Radio Australia.

This evening on Radiotonic, meet comedian and writer Andrew McClelland. When a young woman dressed as a pirate stole his heart on a suburban Adelaide train, Andrew approached the ensuing romance with passion and practicality...all the way to Paris.

Pirates, Eiffel Tower replicas and a French sniper – this is a real life rom-com with a twist. Hear Andrew's hilarious story on RA at 9pm AEST, or take a look at the link below.

status_message:
The multi-award winning Australian short film, The Projectionist, by Michael Bates became the heart of a project for 5 screen composers within the Juilliard School at Lincoln Center, New York.

It eventually inspired a festival of public screenings, in which the film was presented over a week each night with each new score, to curious and enthusiastic audiences.

Hear the full story at 9pm AEST on Into the Music, which offers a fascinating insight into screen composition and the power of a film to resonate with an audience over time.

Shortly on RN Drive at 6pm AEST, host Waleed Aly presents the show live from OzAsia Festival and the Moon Lantern Festival in Adelaide, South Australia.  

Join us as we meet creative talent from across Asia, and explore Asian-Australian culture, music, cuisine, and heritage.

For more program times, visit the full Radio Australia schedule here: bit.ly/rasched

It's finals time in the #AFL! This afternoon, tune into Radio Australia from 2pm AEST for live coverage as the Swans tackle the Dockers, in what many are saying could be a Grand Final preview. Later on from 6pm AEST, listen in to hear the Kangaroos face the Bombers at the MCG.  

And in the last week of the regular season of the #NRL, we're featuring live coverage tomorrow from 2pm AEST as the Knights host the Dragons and the Titans play at home to the Bulldogs. For the full schedule, click here: http://bit.ly/1BfowyJ

We have an important update regarding Australia Network. Due to Australian Government cuts, ABC International will no longer be providing this service to audiences in the Asia and Pacific region from Monday 29 September, 2014.

ABC International will still provide Australian content to audiences in the region through a limited television service, Australia Plus Television, and of course via Radio Australia as well as our websites, social media presences like this one and mobile apps. 

To find out how to access Australia Plus TV from Monday 29 September, please see the link below.

Life Matters - ABC Radio National and ABC Health & Wellbeing have started a Get Fit challenge – and some of us here at Radio Australia and Australia Plus have accepted! 

Will you join us? All you need to do is 300 minutes (five hours) of exercise for six weeks and tell us your progress on Twitter, Facebook or Instagram using the hash tag #abcgetfit

We'll share some of the images on our Facebook and Twitter to encourage everyone to get moving. 

And remember to tune in daily to Life Matters at 9am AEST on Radio Australia.

Today on the Health Report at 11:30am AEST, we take a look at whether cancer trials could be conducted more efficiently. 

According to Professor David Dilts from Division Management at Oregon Health, while they're often good science, they tend not to answer practical questions and the patient numbers involved in these trials are at times extremely low. Professor Dilts talks to Dr Norman Swan about his suggestions on how to improve the situation.

For more information about the program, see below.
link_name: A call for clinical cancer trials to be more efficient

UN Women's Beijing +20 campaign aims to rally people to the cause of gender equality in line with the 20th anniversary of the Fourth World Conference on Women. The first theme of the push is 'Girl Child.'

"A society's customs are engineered by its past generations, and in the same fashion its future citizens can redefine the culture that rules them by cultivating a new norm through education." - Nnenna Agba

status_message:
We'd like to tell you about some changes we're making here at Radio Australia. We're still on air, beaming to you, wherever you are in Asia and the Pacific. 

We're updating our program schedule. You'll be hearing new shows and some existing ones will move to new time slots – all capturing Australia and our perspectives on the world.

Of course our regional news services continue; and our flagship Pacific affairs program, Pacific Beat, will remain in its regular morning and afternoon time slots.

We'll also continue our much-loved weekend sports coverage – AFL on Saturdays, Rugby League on Sundays, all the way to the Grand Finals.

In our new line-up you'll hear more fantastic Australian music. 

Thank you for listening and for your ongoing support, and stay tuned next week for a new schedule announcement.

Don't change those dials! We hope you enjoy the sounds of ABC Classic FM this evening while Radio Australia performs some scheduled maintenance from 11pm AEST. We'll be back on your airwaves tomorrow morning.   

(Image Flickr CC: Brandon Warren)

It's a wrap for the Mornings show! The marvellous Phil Kafcaloudes has signed off Radio Australia for the last time after nine years on the program. We will miss his quick wit and wonderful personality.

Phil has been the morning host since 2005 when he and Adelaine Ng hosted what was then called The Breakfast Club. This job has capped off a 26 year career at the ABC, where he has been a radio and TV reporter; national journalism trainer and host on Radio National and local radio in Sydney and Melbourne. 

The ABC has also sent him to work in a dozen countries. But it's his time at Radio Australia that has been most special (or so he tells us). 

Phil: "A former boss once told me I had the greatest job in radio. I agree, in no small part because of the wonderful audience who have become part of my family".

It's sad to say goodbye to one of our beloved colleagues but we're choosing to celebrate the achievements of Seda Douglas, who has been heading Radio Australia's Khmer team since 1992.

Her work has even come to the attention of Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen, who praised the service. RA can be heard locally on 11 local FM stations in the country.

Under her leadership, RA's Khmer Service was awarded a United Nations Peace Prize Special Citation for its contribution to Cambodia's reconstruction efforts. 

Seda has many fans. Listeners and colleagues will miss her very much!

It just won't be the same in the office! We will miss Ryan Egan. He has done almost everything in radio, from plugging in the right wires so we can be heard to producing and presenting his show Tech Stream, to being a great manager at Radio Australia. We wish him the very best for the future and have no doubt it will be a bright one.

"I've been lucky to travel in my various roles, which includes broadcasting from Thailand, Indonesia, PNG, Samoa and Cambodia.  I always got a real kick out of jumping in a taxi or hire car and being able to switch on Radio Australia.   Of course the best thing about working at RA has been the chance to work with so many talented people and meet so many people from around the world."

(Pic: AN)
Say farewell to more of the Radio Australia and ABC International family. We will miss the voices of Tracee Hutchison, Desley Blanch and Nadia Hume!

Tune into the last week of Radio Australia's Asia Pacific program (10am-10.30am AEST)! 

Fans will miss Sen Lam (right), who has been the suave host of RA's flagship current affairs programs for Asia since 1992 (that's nearly three decades!), while esteemed senior producer Tom Fayle (left) has the reputation of being "Mr Cool" and "no dramas" on a show that investigates current affairs and responds to breaking news in the region.

Sen: "An organisation is only as good as its people, and that's certainly true of RA. I feel blessed to have worked with some talented people in the 16 years of 'Asia Pacific''s existence, especially my friends in the language services within ABC International. Wherever life takes me, I will always remember RA with much fondness." 

Tom: "It's been fun. It's a shame it didn't last".

Both Sen and Tom will be greatly missed by their colleagues.

(Pic: AN)
Meet more of the Radio Australia family:

Watch out Hugh Jackman!

Adelaine Ng has carved out a remarkable and varied career during her time at Radio Australia.

As well as presenting the Asia-Pacific and Asia Afternoons programs, she started the Breakfast Club show (now known as Radio Australia Mornings) as co-host and producer with Phil Kafcaloudes in 2005.

Adelaine: "I know it's cliché but the Asia-Pacific is a fascinating region! I have thoroughly enjoyed finding and telling just some of the amazing stories found here"

Asked if the cessation of the Morning program will signal the end of her radio career,  "I can't retire. I haven't interviewed Hugh Jackman yet".

What will she miss most? "Everybody! Radio Australia has been my second family for 10 years, so things will feel very strange for a while... I will also miss our listeners".

And we're sure they'll miss you too Adelaine!

(Pic: LG)

Heather Jarvis (left) and Isabelle Genoux have more than 50 years of broadcasting between them on Radio Australia.

Isabelle: "What keeps driving my journey? Exploring cultural diversity and, within this wealth of differences, finding the universal strands that bind us together."

Heather: "I love the idea of a world where women and men are equal, violence is a thing of the past and where Australia beats New Zealand in netball.  One of those things is already a reality so hopefully the others will follow soon." 

We wish both of them the best in their future pursuits. Radio Australia won't be the same without them. :(

(Pic: AN)

Want to see a good movie?

You don't have to take cinema seriously to know there's nothing worse than seeing a dud movie - it wastes money and time.

Fortunately for all of us, our resident film critic - the highly esteemed Leigh Paatsch, has been guiding us through all the new releases to help make the best celluloid choices.

Whether it's chick flick, horror, blockbuster, family or adult, Leigh has sacrificed many hours in the dark on our behalf.

As we draw close to the end of our Radio Australia morning programs, Leigh Paatsch, we'd like to say thank you. 

We give you 5 Stars.

Catch the last movie segment tomorrow (Thursday) 0820 AEST.

(Pic: AN)

This is a face you can trust....

Here's Dr Ron McCoy from the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners. 

For the past 9 years, Dr Ron has been a regular co-host for the 'Sound Body' segment on Radio Australia's morning program.

But sadly, tomorrow will be his swansong.  

Whilst it's a bitter pill to swallow, at least he's leaving us with his top nine list of important medical stories – one for each year he's been broadcasting.

That's something that should make us feel better!

Tune in for our last 'Sound Body' with Dr Ron from 0930 AEST Thursday.

(Pic: AN)

Don't mess with the music... Kim Taylor is Radio Australia's beloved music producer. Join her tomorrow at about 9.30am AEST on Radio Australia's Morning show for the last time when she takes us through her favourite songs of the year.

Kim has also been instrumental (pardon pun) in the setting up and running of Radio Australia's Pacific Break program, which has seen musicians from across the Pacific find new audiences across the region.

(Pic: AN)

Who are these spunks? 

You may not see them but you've been hearing them on Radio Australia's technology segment on Tuesdays at about 8.30am AEST. Join Seamus Byrne and Nic Healey from CNET Australia tomorrow for their last segment as the show draws to a close.

As for favourite tech gadgets featured on the show?
Seamus (Left):  The one giving actual feeling back to amputees through a new bionic arm design. http://cnet.co/1opOVVV

Nic (Right): The attention powered car. Designed in Western Australia, the car slows down if you're not fully concentrating! http://cnet.co/1p3sExB

Thanks guys, we'll miss you both!

(Pic: Supplied)

West Africa's Ebola outbreak remains out of control with the United States organising to send an extra 50 public health officials to Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone to help combat the virus. 

US health worker Dr Kent Brantly (pictured below) was in Liberia responding to the Ebola outbreak when he contracted the disease. He has flown to Atlanta and doctors say his health appears to be improving. More: http://ab.co/1ANV2Zz

Pic from Samaritan's Purse.

Terry Laidler is our regular co-host on mental health issues on Radio Australia's Morning program. Join him for his last "appearance" tomorrow at 9.30am AEST as the show draws to a close.

"A more inclusive, less violent, more empathic community would be better for us all on so many levels". -Terry Laidler

(Pic: AN)

"When we see community like this banding together, despite the distance they might be from home, it inspires us to do better, to build community around us and to make the world a better place because of it."

Melbourne's Burmese refugee community has come together for night of song, dance and celebration in the name of reaching out to their fellow refugees.   Watch David Kim's report via the link below.
link_name: Australia's Burmese refugees take action through celebration

status_message:
There's a bright light shining ahead for Africans who use polluting and dangerous kerosene lanterns for lighting. 

British charity SolarAid will provide modern and cheap solar lights to 110 million homes in Africa that don't currently have access to electricity. 

According to SolarAid's chairman, kerosene lanterns are sucking up 25% of household running costs, while being a fire risk to householders. More: http://ab.co/1tkjq2E

Pic:  SolarAid

PNG's sustainable development strategy is 'visionary' according to the world's largest conservation organisation. 

PNG's National Strategy for Responsible Development, launched in April by Planning Minister Charles Abel, aims to re-orient the country's entire economic and development efforts, including mining and logging, around an overriding goal of sustainable development.

Vanuatu, Fiji, Palau, Kiribati and Cook Islands are also showing leadership in regard to conservation efforts, according to the International Union for the Conservation of Nature. More: http://ab.co/1rZVyi2

With its birds of paradise, tree kangaroos and other terrestrial wildlife, and its rich marine resources, Papua New Guinea is home to a staggering seven per cent of the world's biodiversity. Pic: Tenkile Conservation Alliance.

It might be tinsy tiny, but the territory of Norfolk Island is giving the Glasgow 2014 Commonwealth Games its best shot. 

Badminton player Mick Donohoe has played four games already and will face off against Seychelles tomorrow. 

He says the team has held its own against heavyweights like Singapore and South Africa.

Go, go, go! Forget the Commonwealth Games, green sea turtles have set a dazzling new swim record. 

Using satellite tracking equipment, scientists observed a green sea turtle travel 4,000 kilometres without stopping for food. 

It's a trip similar sized mammals like dolphins or seals wouldn't be able to make without starving to death. More: http://bit.ly/1nBdyil

Pic Credit: R.D Kirkby & B.S Kirkby

Is it congratulations or commiserations to the Philippines where the population reached 100-million with the birth of this baby girl born yesterday?

The milestone is being described as an opportunity and a challenge, with about 25% of the country living in poverty. 

The beautiful baby you see pictured was one of 100 babies born in state hospitals all over the archipelago who received the symbolic designation of 100,000,000th baby.

Do you watch the TV show Love Patrol?

Gillio 'Gigi' Baxter has played the lead character Andy since season three. Andy is gay and Ms Baxter says she draws on her personal experience to play the role.

She told Pacific Beat's Campbell Cooney that Andy is challenging the stigma towards gay people.  She says Love Patrol addresses a raft of other issues too that resonate across the Pacific, from government corruption and problems within the Church to unemployment and youth issues.
link_name: Love Patrol breaks down barriers in the Pacific

status_message:
Women make up more than half of all HIV cases around the world - in fact, the epidemic's been described by experts as 'an epidemic of women'.

Catherine Graue caught up with three women attending #AIDS2014, the International AIDS conference - to find out what living with HIV is really like for them.

Find more of our coverage of issues related to HIV and AIDS here: http://radioaustralia.net.au/international/aids-2014
link_name: AIDS 2014: Three women share their experience living with HIV

status_message:
Fiji is suspended from the Commonwealth, and was banned from competing at the Games in 2010, but they are back in 2014 and they have had a strong first day.

Pacific Beat's Richard Ewart spoke with Wayne O'Connor, team administrator for Fiji at the Glasgow #commonwealthgames
link_name: Back in the Games Fiji athletes better their personal bests | Pacific Beat

status_message:
Five attendees of the 2014 International AIDS Conference in Melbourne tell us how they're creating positive change in their communities.

Around 12,000 people from over 200 countries are attending #AIDS2014. The theme of the 20th International AIDS conference is "Stepping Up the Pace," which these five individuals embody perfectly. 

Find out more about them: http://ausp.lu/1jWL175
Were you able to watch the opening of the Commonwealth Games in Glasgow?  What did you think of the little Scottish Terriers, which some say stole the show.

Radio Australia broadcasting live from #AIDS2014, the 20th International AIDS Conference in Melbourne.

Sen Lam and our Asia Pacific team met a range of people from across the region, who shared their personal stories and insights into a range of issues associated with HIV and AIDS in the Asia-Pacific.

Listen again to the full program online: http://bit.ly/1nikscp

Stay tuned for our Pacific Beat program, live from AIDS 2014, with a focus on HIV and AIDS in Oceania, later this afternoon.

"It's just the revival church that told her not to take her medication. They are responsible for her death," - Margaret Anton, president of Women Affected by HIV/AIDS, PNG.

Human rights groups are concerned that Papua New Guinean revivalist churches are pushing a dangerous campaign for 'faith-healing' of AIDS.  Read Liam Cochrane's full report:
link_name: Papua New Guinean revivalist churches push dangerous campaign for 'faith-healing' of AIDS | ABC...

status_message:
2.5 billion people live without access to an adequate toilet. Not having access to safe water and sanitation is particularly important for people living with HIV/AIDS.

This giant toilet that's been set up in the heart of Melbourne's CBD, near where the #AIDS2014 international conference is taking place.

Phil Kafcaloudes spoke with Rosie Wheen, Acting chief executive & Director of International Programs with WaterAid earlier this morning about their campaign.

Listen to this interview here: http://bit.ly/1yTN3Z5
(photo by ABC producer Lisa Greenough)

Are Scotland's uniforms for the Commomwealth Games really that bad?

The turquoise, fuchsia and navy tartan outfits designed by the textile artist Jilli Blackwood have been roundly mocked on social media. Blackwood has described her detractors as 'trolls' and told the ABC that she is looking forward to watching her design paraded at the opening ceremony.

The Glasgow Commonwealth Games start later this week.
link_name: Scottish Games uniform designer labels detractors ''trolls"

status_message:
With so much sad news this week, it's nice to share something beautiful, uplifting and positive. 

South Africa's Grammy award winning Soweto Gospel Choir took time out of its national tour to travel to the remote town of Ntaria, in central Australia, to sing with the Aboriginal Women's Choir during Sunday service in the town's chapel.
link_name: Soweto choir sings gospel with Arrente women in Central Australia

status_message:
"They devoted themselves to scientific research, to patient care, to law reform and human rights."

Former High Court judge Michael Kirby spoke on the opening day of the 20th International AIDS Conference and paid tribute to those whose journey to the event was cut short when flight #MH17 was shot down over Ukraine.  

Read more about his speech and the other opening remarks from AIDS 2014, which takes place in Melbourne this week: http://bit.ly/1wOFvDT

Follow our coverage of #AIDS2014 online here: http://bit.ly/WxXOCW

ABC correspondent Phil Williams describes the scene at the crash site for Malaysia Airlines flight #MH17 in eastern Ukraine.
link_name: MH17: ABC correspondent Phil Williams finds 'distressing' signs of looting at Malaysia Airlines...

status_message:
The U.N. Security Council is considering a draft resolution to condemn the "shooting down" of Malaysian flight #MH17 in Ukraine.

Australia - which lost 28 citizens - circulated a draft text, which also demands armed groups allow access to the crash site, and calls on states in the region to cooperate with an international investigation.
link_name: MH17: Security Council considers Australian-drafted resolution

status_message:
AIDS 2014 begins in Melbourne today, and promises to be the largest medical conference Australia has ever seen.  It brings together 14,000 delegates from nearly 200 countries, including a media contingent of 1,200 journalists.

We'll have coverage of the event all week. Our Pacific Beat and Asia Pacific programs will be broadcasting live from #AIDS2014 on Thursday July 24.

Want to know more about where we are with the battle against this devastating disease? Click through to find out.

(Photo by Samantha Sagona)

Have you ever seen a whale in the wild, or been able to take a photo of one?

link_name: New smartphone application helps data collection on marine mammals

status_message:
"This is not just a meeting of usually boring scientists and clinicians, this is a meeting of everyone affected by HIV and everyone who can make a difference."
