link_name: Melbourne prepares to host world's biggest AIDS Conference

status_message:
Russia is under mounting international pressure after a Malaysian passenger jet was shot down over rebel-held eastern Ukraine, with the loss of nearly 300 lives. 

At least 28 Australians were on board the Boeing 777 when it was apparently hit by a surface-to-air missile near Ukraine's border with Russia.  Australia's Prime Minister Tony Abbott has called for a full and impartial inquiry into the downing of the airliner.  

What do we know now about this tragedy? ABC News breaks down the facts as the world reels from the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight #MH17.
link_name: Explainer: What we know about Malaysia Airlines MH17

status_message:
Why did World War One start at all?

The first in a ten part ABC Radio National series begins today on Radio Australia.  Join us from 1pm (PNG time, 3pm Fiji, 10am Cambodia) for The Great War: Memory, Perceptions and 10 Critical Questions.

If you miss any episodes you can listen here:

A Malaysia Airlines passenger jet has crashed in Ukraine near the country's border with Russia, killing all 295 people on board. 27 Australians confirmed to have been on the flight.

Flight #MH17 was en route from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur when it disappeared from radar screens.  Unconfirmed reports say the plane was shot down by a ground-to-air missile.

DFAT hotlines: + 61 2 6261 3305 from overseas; 1300 555 135 within Australia.

Updates on air, and follow ABC News live blog as developments unfold.

link_name: Live: Malaysia Airlines jet 'shot down by missile' over Ukraine

"Children that were born two generations after the war are still being harmed. This is a continuing tragedy."

The US dropped up to 260 million cluster bombs on Laos during the Vietnam War - the equivalent of one bombing mission every eight minutes, for nine years.

The ABC's Sally Sara met some of the brave women in Laos who are helping to remove mines and unexploded bombs.

Do you eat ugly fruit or vegetables?

In Australia, between 20 and 40 per cent of fruit and vegetables grown are rejected before they reach the shops because they don't meet supermarkets' high cosmetic standards and specifications.  

Have we been trained to expect perfection?
link_name: Beauty is in the mouth of the beholder, not their eyes.

Champion swimmer Ian Thorpe has revealed he is gay in an interview with Sir Michael Parkinson, after years of scrutiny from the Australian public.

status_message:
Do you have a family recipe you are proud of?

Torres Strait Islander Janette Moulder loves to teach people how to make her banana leaf damper. Damper is a basic bread, usually made on a campfire with water and flour. 

Janette is seen here sharing her traditional methods of cooking with a group of women as part of #NAIDOC Week celebrations in Rockhampton, in far north Queensland. 

Read her story here: http://ab.co/1k4uLvr

(photo by ABC Local Radio's Alice Roberts)

A major rescue operation is underway in Vanuatu after an inter-island ferry capsized, throwing its 41 passengers and crew into the water. As we post this thirty-seven people have been rescued, but four others are reported to be trapped underneath the barge, named 'MCY'.

The ferry was travelling between Malekula and the capital, Port Vila when it capsized, around 3.5 kilometres from Mangaliliu village, north of Efate island. Updates in Radio Australia news on the hour or via twitter.com/ranews
link_name: Vanuatu inter-island ferry capsizes with 41 people on board

Will Joko Widodo be Indonesia's next president? 

Early figures show him in the lead, but Indonesia's presidential poll is unlikely to be declared until the Electoral Commission formally announces a winner on July 22.

Sen Lam from our Asia Pacific program spoke earlier with Australian analyst in Jakarta Greg Barton. Listen here: http://bit.ly/1lVG6hc

"Because Aboriginal people were not recognised for their services, they were not treated the same as non-Indigenous soldiers when they came back here where they were given land - I know that never happened." - Sandra Bolt, talking about her father who fought in World War 2.

The party kicks off today! Sunday is the start of NAIDOC week, a yearly celebration of all the ways that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people make this country great.

Indigenous bluesman Buddy Knox (pix below) will be headlining one of the many concerts over the next few days with blues music. Full list of events here: http://www.naidoc.org.au/

Do you spend your weekend catching up with close friends? 

For best friends Dora Wang and Xiao Ba Fan, every spare moment is spent finding ways to do cool things together, even though they live in Sydney and Beijing respectively.

They started a 100-day project using photography and social media to show how close they are. More on what they've been up to here: http://ausp.lu/1t4BMFU

Here's a puzzle. Where has all the plastic in our oceans gone? A global study could only find 1% of the plastic waste scientists expected.  

While that sounds like good news, oceanographers aren't so sure. More on the mystery here: http://bit.ly/1j2db0g

Photo of Australia's Great Ocean Road (Flickr CC Paper Kea)

We need some help on Radio Australia Mornings with Phil Kafcaloudes!

Australian Nick Kyrgios is despondent after his Wimbledon loss to Milos Raonic "but he'll bounce back", says his coach Simon Rea.

Is that a kick in the guts, tummy, intestines, stomach or something else? What do you call your digestive stuff? 

Loads of us have problems with tummy pain and sometimes for no particular reason. On the Radio Australia Morning Show at 9:30 AEST today, Dr Ron McCoy from the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners will explain to us what could be the cause of it.

Australia's Foreign Minister Julie Bishop has arrived in Rangoon for her first official visit to Myanmar. She will be meeting President Thein Sein and Opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi.

Manus Island on Papua New Guinea often makes news because of Australia's asylum seeker processing and detention centre located there. 

But for Airi Ingram, a Melbourne based Papua New Guinea musician, Manus Island has been the inspiration for his art.

status_message:
Health warnings on cigarette packs in the region are not new - Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand and Australia are all getting tougher with their anti-tobacco measures.

It's a different picture in Indonesia - not only does it have the highest smoking rates in the region, it also has fewer controls on tobacco advertising.

A law requiring manufacturers to display graphic health warnings on cigarette packs came into force this week. But despite being given 18 months notice, only a handful of brands were ready.
link_name: Indonesia not butting out of anti-tobacco push despite industry resistance over warning labels |...

status_message:
Do you know how to swim? When and where did you learn this important skill?

A new pilot project in Vanuatu is teaching children valuable lifesaving and swimming skills for the very first time, in a bid to prevent drowning deaths.

Bella Anis, a mother of four from Mele village, just a few kilometres outside the capital Port Vila, says drownings are a common occurrence within the community.

"There are children who have died, they've drowned because they aren't able to swim," Ms Anis says.

Full story, and more images from Catherine Grau here: http://bit.ly/1izH1sO

2014 marks 100 years since the start of World War One.

The history of the first World War is as relevant as ever. ABC Radio National bring you 25 facts you might not know about the Great War:

status_message:
Predictaroo the kangaroo may be Australia's best chance at World Cup glory. 

The intuitive Eastern Grey Kangaroo has a near perfect record picking the winners during the group stage of the 2014 World Cup. She's only tripped up once when she tipped Portugal to beat Germany. Germany won 4-0. 

Predictaroo has lived at the Australia Zoo for 10 years and keepers there say her long legs are perfect for kicking a soccer ball. 

Meet her keeper on Radio Australia's Morning Show tomorrow at 9:20am AEST. Listen here: http://bit.ly/18UzJZt

The good news is the great white shark population of the north eastern Pacific is doing better than previously thought, the bad news is swimming just became a whole lot more nerve-wracking. 

New findings by US researchers suggest there's 2000 great white sharks in the area, not 219 as research released 3 years ago had indicated. 

"If something is wrong with the largest, most powerful group in the sea, then something is wrong with the sea, so it's a relief to find they're in good shape," said George Burgess of the Florida Program for Shark Research. Full story: http://bit.ly/T2URaX

Pic: Hermanus Backpackers

We'll tame the most unmanageable of afro's and stimulate hair growth for the follically challenged on Radio Australia's Morning Show tomorrow when Namila Benson teases out the hair raising issue of how hair can define us.

On average we have 100,000 hairs on our head so why aren't we better at being comfortable with it?

Namila's guest is PNG artist Lisa Hilli who's exhibiting 'Afrophobia' in an upcoming exhibition "Where We're At: Other Voices on Gender" in Brussels' BOZAR Centre of Fine Art. 

Tune in at 0745 AEST: http://bit.ly/18UzJZt

Pic of musician Billy Preston by David Hume Kennerly - White House Photograph Courtesy Gerald R. Ford Library

Is this your toothbrush, plastic toy or other debris that was found floating in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch?

This sample of junk was taken from the estimated 700,000 square kilometre garbage patch, also known as the Pacific Trash Vortex. 

Researchers from the Algalita Marina Research Institute in California are gearing up to spend a month in the patch to analyse the impact of garbage on the ecosystem. Story: http://bit.ly/1qiSGOL

Pic: Tim Silverwood from Algalita Marine Research Institute.

The 2014 World Cup has kicked off  (Hooray!)

However, it's believed the chances of the Socceroos actually winning the competition is pretty low (Boo!)

But, there's a message of hope for the Australian team that comes from a former Brazilian World Cup player  (Hooray!)

Paulo Silas, played two World cups for Brazil (1986 and 1990) and he's now a football coach.  

He had this advice for the Socceroos team when he spoke to Phil Kafcaloudes this week....

"We're seeing a lot of surprises in the important matches. You must be strong, you must believe and you must have faith in what you're doing"

"'No-one will be comfortable to play against Australia".

So.... Go Socceroos!   and Go Silas! 

Pic: Paulo Silas

Would you live the remainder of your days in a city that floated on the ocean? 

America's Seasteading Institute is hoping a plan to create floating 'microcountries' that produce their own food and are self-governed will ride a wave of popularity.

A spokesman from the institute says half the world is a blank slate and there's potential in creating "a thousand start-up governments in the sea."

The islands of Vanuatu are not only known for their beauty. 

As it is all over the Pacific, Vanuatu is also known for it's music, which is integral to the lives of the people who live there.

New Caledonian born DJ Christophe Gargiulo has lived in Vanuatu and draws on his time spent there to produce music that blends his contemporary electronic beats with the traditional sounds of Ni-Vanuatu.

Imagine seeing this in the wild! 

A five-metre crocodile that has called central Queensland home for three decades is on its way to the Middle East.

Reptile farmer John Lever is sending "Jock the Croc" to Dubai, where the reptile will live out its days in a specially designed enclosure in a zoo inside a shopping mall.

He says Jock will help put Queensland on the map: "This will be part of central Queensland right in the busiest mall in the world".
link_name: Monster Qld croc bound for Middle East shopping mall

Cambodia growers are adding to the flavours on offer in Australia's Top End city of Darwin.

Farmer Muy Keav Ma sells southeast Asian herbs and vegetables at the local market as well as being a mango farmer. 

Local tastes are evolving and Muy Keav enjoys explaining to people how to use herbs common to Cambodian cooking, such as gotu kola (good as an anti-inflammatory and in soup) and the pungent fish-cheek mint.

More: http://ab.co/1nJtMHZ

Do you like the uniforms Australian athletes will wear at the Commonwealth Games next month?

About 500 Australian athletes will compete in this year's Games and off the field they will be clad in a range of smart casual wear that some describe as "nautical".  The Games are being held in Glasgow and start on July 23.

Full story: http://ab.co/1rKvjiI

Is there something you'd like to ask one of the world's greatest environmentalists? Here's your chance.

Dr Jane Goodall is in the studio with Phil this morning and will answer your questions, so post them here and we'll pass them on. 

Dr Jane was the first primatologist to discover that chimps have minds, emotions and personalities.

Dr Jane is also known for her humanitarian and conservation work and is a UN Messenger of Peace. 

Pic compliments of The Jane Goodall Institute Australia

You can listen to Dr Goodall and Phil here at 8am AEST: http://bit.ly/18UzJZt

An NGO working in Cambodia is urging the Australian government to fulfil a commitment to fund a national nutrition strategy.

The Australian arm of NGO, Results International, say a change in government and changes to AusAID have left them uncertain about the future of the $40-million nutrition strategy. 

Malnutrition rates in Cambodia remain stubbornly high with almost 40% of children chronically malnourished, according to the World Food Program. Full story: http://bit.ly/1iSsjY9

Pic thanks to Results International

'Atua: Sacred gods from Polynesia' are the subject of an exhibition at the National Gallery of Australia.

The exhibition explores Polynesian spirituality and the concept of Atua, Polynesian gods and the ongoing influence of ancestral spirits. 

The art works, physical manifestations of ancestral spirits, were scattered around the world by explorers, missionaries and collectors and were a challenge to bring together. 

Full story: http://bit.ly/U8urWm

Pic: Fisherman's god, or 'Oramatua' Rarotonga, Cook Islands, central Polynesia 18th or early 19th century wood 42 x 16 x 16 cm Staatliches Museum für Völkerkunde, München Photograph: Marietta Weidner

Who wants free beer? 

You'll have to endure Beijing pollution off the scale in order to be eligible for the 'Airpocalypse' beer from Jing A Brewery, a small scale brewery who is cashing in on the cities smog worries. 

The brewery's partners say the beer is a tribute to the people of Beijing. 

Story: http://ab.co/1ucjZtw

The Australian-Indonesia relationship looks robust despite allegations Indonesian journalists were allowed to eavesdrop, and subsequently report on, a telephone conversation between the two leaders. 

It's believed Mr Abbott did not know the journalists were in the room. 

In Australia, the Journalists Code of Ethics stipulates: "Use fair, responsible and honest means to obtain material.  Identify yourself and your employer before obtaining any interview for publication or broadcast." 

Mr Abbott says the important thing is the conversation was "very genial" and a good conversation. 

What do you think?
link_name: Revelations Indonesian journalists allowed to listen to Abbott call

status_message:
Passion, bloodshed, desire and death – it's all part of the burgeoning multi-million dollar cockfighting business in the Philippines.

It's even proffered that "some breeders give more attention to their chickens than their wives."

Hundreds of years ago, Spanish colonisers got Filipinos hooked on the sport that many say is an engrained part of Philippine culture. Learn more: http://bit.ly/1hP6fgP

Pic: Amshudhagar

It's not a good statistic. 

Five Pacific nations are among the ten fattest countries in the world, according to a global obesity study. 

Almost a third of the world, or more than two billion people are considered fat.  Story: http://bit.ly/1u6He8k

"We're not only looking at food security here, we're also looking at livelihoods... We're hoping maybe by using the nursery, growing the vegetables but also other crops, that will help the communities move forward and maybe get to a better stage than they were before Cyclone Ian."

Communities in Tonga are receiving help to recover and rebuild their crops after they were devastated by a cyclone earlier this year.
link_name: Vegetable nurseries help with Tonga cyclone recovery

In just under four months Fijians will head to the polls in the country's first democratic election since the military coup in 2006.

ABC Reporter Liam Fox travelled to Suva, and found plenty of domestic support for Rear Admiral Bainimarama, his policies and his new political party, Fiji First.

Dr Mobumo Kiromat wants women in PNG to be educated and empowered to decide how many children they want to have.  

The pediatrician has spent many years working for PNG's department of health before taking on the challenging role of country director for the Clinton Health Access Initiative.

Jemima Garrett spoke with Dr Kiromat, who is this year's winner of the public sector category of the Westpac Outstanding Women Awards.
link_name: Award-winning PNG doctor tackles big problems and inspires the young | Pacific Beat

status_message:
Squish that mozzie! 

Australian researchers are doing just the opposite, they're breeding the Asian Tiger Mosquito as Australia prepares for a mainland invasion. 

This mosquito species is one of the most aggressive and potentially dangerous on the planet and has helped spread the chikungunya virus through PNG. 

Named for its striped body and aggressive bloodlust, let's hope researchers fly to a conclusion sooner rather than later. 

Read about the research here: http://bit.ly/SSTdJ6

link_name: How to save the Samoan Language | ABC Radio Australia | ABC Radio Australia

status_message:
Where do you think this beautiful picture was taken? 

It could be the Pacific, Indonesia, Thailand, Sri Lanka, Australia or any perfect tropical beach in our region. 

It's a good example of how countries can be similar, while being unique and different at the same time.

This glorious sunrise is remote Chilli Beach on the east coast of Cape York in Far North Queensland. Pic snapped by ABC audience member Vanessa Gillen.

Look, it's a "global selfie"!

US Space agency NASA has unveiled a "global selfie", a mosaic of more than 36,000 pictures uploaded to social media showing people and places around the world. 

On Earth Day last month, users on every continent snapped away and after weeks of collecting and curating the more than 50,000 submissions, this "global selfie" has been released. 

More details here: http://ab.co/1mqPHju

Pic from NASA

Happy 20th birthday World Wide Web. Can you imagine a world without it? 

When Tim Berners-Lee launched the world wide web on May 25, 1994, he was hoping it would enable users to better share information. Little did he, or his employer CERN, know about the possibilities it would bring in the years ahead. 

The ABC documents the history of the www: http://ab.co/1mmw1gz

Pic:  CERN (the European Organisation for Nuclear Research)

Congratulations Atiu, Cook Islands for your myna fightback!

Atiu, the 3rd largest of the Cooks 15 islands, is on the verge of eradicating the pesky myna bird. Five years ago, there were 13,000 myna's on Atiu, now less than 100 remain and if all goes to plan, their days are numbered. 

The aggressive common or Indian Myna bird is one of the greatest threats to native birds in Australia and the Pacific, stealing their territory, nesting sites and food.  Full story from the Cook Islands: http://ab.co/1nk3o4B

Pic: Richard Taylor

What does it take to encourage more young women to consider a technology-related career?

Heather Jarvis spoke with ICT specialist Salanieta Tamanikaiwaimaro, who helped organise a special "Girls and Women in ICT" event at the University of the South Pacific. She says there is a global shortage of 2 million women working in the industry.
link_name: New digital alliance to encourage more Pacific women into ICT careers

status_message:
Adam Goodes is the Australian of the Year. But this title, and his desire to be outspoken about indigenous rights, makes him a target for racist attacks.

The Sydney Swans great was racially abused again at a recent game.  But he continues to confront racism in a very public way. He's pictured here wearing his club's first Indigenous guernsey, designed by his mum for the upcoming AFL Indigenous round.

Full story: http://ab.co/1t0tDwO

What music are people listening to in the Cook Islands in the South Pacific? George 'Gdub' Williams is a DJ with radio station 88FM boomboom baby COOK Islands  and he's got all the lowdown on the music scene there. Plus, he shares one of his favorite local tracks at the moment with us on Pacific Break this week. Check it.
link_name: The spin on the Cook Island music scene | Australia Plus

status_message: The ABC's Liam Fox is in Fiji at the moment, and reports on plans by Electoral authorities to recruit thousands of people to work as polling officials.
link_name: Civilians, not public servants, to man Fiji polling stations

status_message:
Two US military Boeing B-52's have arrived in northern Australia ahead of multi-national war games hosted by the Australian Defence Force. 

Weighing more than 125,000 kilograms each, the B-52's normally operate from Andersen Air Force Base in Guam as part of US Pacific Command rotational presence in the Pacific. 

Rotations of military equipment and personnel in the Pacific region by the US, are designed to enhance America's ability to train, exercise and operate with Australia and other allies and partners across the region.

Do you think Pacific bluefin tuna fishing should be banned? 

A US based environment group is taking legal action to stop fishing of endangered Pacific bluefin. 

The Arizona-based Centre for Biological Diversity says the worlds insatiable appetite for sushi, especially in Japan, has caused Pacific bluefin tuna stocks to drop by as much as 96%. 

The group is hoping the legal action will mobilise other countries to reduce their catch of Pacific bluefin. Story: http://ab.co/1m6JMzI

Pic: OpenCage

This Lucky Iron Fish is being used to reduce anemia in Cambodia, where millions suffer from a lack of iron in their diet. 

Boiling the iron fish for 10 minutes releases 75% of daily iron needs. The fish is placed in the pot during the cooking process. 

The Lucky Iron Fish Project has been in clinical trials for five years and over that time, iron deficiencies have pretty much disappeared in the trialled regions. 

The fish is a special formulation of iron that is safe to ingest. More: http://ab.co/1sSjiCU

G'day Samurai, what are you doing on Australia's northern beaches? 

He's here for a Yabusame competition of course! Yabusame is a form of mounted archery, Japanese style, and has great spiritual and historical importance. 

Din Mahidin from Malaysia won the Port Douglas Carnivale competition after beating 5 Samurai from Japan, 7 competitors from Australia and 2 fellow Malaysian horseback archers.

 ABC Far North have more details: http://ab.co/1thyGec

Fears of more riots in Solomon Island's capital, Honiara, has caused many businesses to close their doors today. 

Rioters threw rocks and burned shops on Friday night, with further disturbances again on Saturday. 

Police say most of the troublemakers were people affected by last month's flood disaster, who are unhappy with the government's relief program.

Twitter Pic: Elisabeth McLeod @lisMcLeod

There's good news ahead for this baby loggerhead turtle. An international team of researchers discovered sea turtle populations will likely increase as a result of warmer temperatures. 

Warmer beaches produce more female hatchlings than males, but male sea turtles breed more frequently than females.

The research team combined sand temperature measurements with hatchling sex ratios and operational sex ratios (actual numbers of males and females breeding at any one time), then compared them with more than 150 years of air temperature records and predicted warming scenarios. 

Details here: http://ab.co/1hWBMNC

Love music from the Pacific Islands and didn't get the change to listen to our new Pacific Break program? Well, good news for you! Each week, you'll be able to hear the program on Soundcloud where we upload all the best island sounds. Be a part of it:  follow, like and share Pacific Break.
link_name: Pacific Break, with Namila Benson: Program 001. 16 May 2014

status_message: Meet Namila Benson, the host of #pacificbreak. We thought you might like to know a little more about her. Her background in music, whats in her playlists at the moment? Ladies and Gentlemen I present Ms Namila Benson! *rapturous applause*
link_name: Pacific Break radio program makes its debut | Pacific Break | ABC Radio Australia

status_message:
If you love Pacific music, if you make Pacific music, tune into Radio Australia today to hear fresh sounds from across the ocean as Pacific Break makes it's debut on the airwaves with host Namila Benson. Tune in at 4pm AEST. 

Not to be missed!

What do you do to enrich other people's lives? 

Volunteers play a vital role in keeping the Australian community ticking along, with more than 6-million Aussie's lending their time to a multitude of organisations around the country. 

Winschurill from Hong Kong volunteers with the South Australian Country Fire Service and protects people and property from fire, while making new friends at the same time. 

As a celebration of 25 years of 'Australian Volunteers Week' you can read about Winschurill and other wonderful volunteers here: http://ausp.lu/1oV0jax

Dr Mark Ziembicki, from James Cook University in Far North Queensland, has been working on conservation projects with communities in the YUS area of Papua New Guinea since 2010. 

Dr Ziembicki spoke with Isabelle Genoux about the online art auction he has organised featuring drawings and photographs which will raise funds for much needed maternal health projects in PNG.
link_name: Online art auction to fund community health projects in PNG | ABC Radio Australia

status_message:
Woohoo, Island music fans are you ready? 

Pacific Break is back and it's revamped and better than ever. 

A weekly radio program will play your music across the Pacific and Australia. Tune in every Friday at 4:05pm PNG time, starting tomorrow, to hear host Namila Benson play Pacific Island music uploaded by you.

To upload your music or find out more:  http://on.fb.me/1lqDuYI

Imagine living in a city of 100-million people. 

China's top economic planning body intends to transform Beijing into a 'megalopolis' of 100-million residents. Urban planners are working on forming an economic zone that would stretch to include neighbouring Tianjin and Hebei. 

A draft plan will be ready in two months. Details: http://bit.ly/1g4yBIj

Pic: CobbleCC

Have you had the pleasure of meeting Robyn Loau?

Robyn's the daughter of a Samoan village chief.  

In an earlier life, she was the lead singer of pop group, 'Girlfriend'  (Australia's answer to the 'Spice Girls').....

....before becoming the face and voice of the South Pacific world music project, 'Siva Pacifica'.
 
And NOW she's...

Well, we can't give it all away - you'll have to listen in to find out what she's doing now.

Robyn Loau (pictured below) joins Phil Kafcaloudes,  Wednesday from 0730 AEST.

Debt, deficits, estimates, nominal GDP... what does it all mean?

Decoding the words used when talking about a country's budget can be tricky. ABC News Online explains the economic jargon to help you understand what is being said.

This evening Australia's Treasurer Joe Hockey will deliver his first budget.  You can listen to his speech from Parliament House at 7:30pm SYD/POM time on Radio Australia, followed by analysis from the ABC Current Affairs team. Coverage also on Australia Network.

Do you watch Australia Network TV? It's the television equivalent of Radio Australia.

The Australian government might remove the funding for Australia Network, its overseas TV service, in tomorrow night's budget. Do you watch it or will it affect you if it is no longer on air?

Hey! Keep out! 

Australian borders are set to become harder to penetrate when a newly integrated body 'Australian Border Force' starts work next July. The Force will bring together customs and immigration operation offices to deal with people smuggling as well as the full range of threats. 

The Australian government has been criticised by humanitarian groups for having hardline border protection and immigration policies. What do you think? 

More details on Australian Border Force here: http://bit.ly/1quE2op

Pic: Ken Hodge

Is this the wurst beard you've ever seen? 

Austrian drag queen, Conchita Wurst, has arrived home to a heroine's welcome after winning the Eurovision Song Contest on the weekend, but the victory is not without controversy. 

Isn't music and the arts meant to challenge us? More: http://ab.co/1mPUHgw

Pic: Ailura

Take some time on Mother's Day today to reflect on the miracle of childbirth, a time we all shared with our mothers.

Save The Children estimates that five women die each day during childbirth in PNG. The London-based charity has released a new report that states PNG is one of the toughest places to be a mother. Details here: http://ab.co/1nkl3eb

This picture of a woman in Sierra Leone was snapped by John Atherton.

Are you interested in exploring Antarctica?

Chances are your country is. Approximately 30 nations now have a declared Antarctic science and research program while China, South Korea and other nations are rushing to establish a presence in Antarctica before the Antarctic Treaty is reviewed in 2048.

Antony Funnell investigates why: http://ab.co/1kHM71W

Pic: Rodrigo.Argenton

Need a weekend getaway? How about a trip into space?

Before takeoff, consider the potential side effects of microgravity and the weightlessness of the final frontier:

1) A swollen face and skrunken legs.
2) A stretched sciatic nerve.
3) A loss of bone density and minerals.
4) Eye damage.

Need more reasons to think twice about space travel or to find out more: http://ab.co/1s561Xl

Pic: NASA

"There are lots of dead people among the wreckage; fathers, mothers, sisters, brothers, children, babies ... many will remain for days in the place where Haiyan left them, the level of shock so great that a kind of paralysis sets in."

Today marks six months since Typhoon Haiyan, the strongest storm ever to make landfall, swept through the Philippines, leaving thousands dead and a trail of destruction across the country. 

ABC Correspondent Zoe Daniels reflects on arriving in Tacloban 6 months ago:  http://ab.co/Qg5SE5

Australia's High Commissioner to the Solomon Islands says the country is slowly recovering from its most devastating flooding in living memory. 

Australian High Commissioner Andrew Byrne says the recovery process is moving in the right direction but thousands remain in temporary shelters.
link_name: Solomon Islands recovering from floods: Australian High Commissioner | ABC Radio Australia

status_message:
Thailand's Constitutional Court has found Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra guilty of abuse of power and ordered her to step down from office. 

The court ruled Ms Yingluck violated the constitution when she transferred the National Security council chief Thawil Pliensri in 2011. Nine cabinet members implicated in the violation must also be removed from office.

More: http://ab.co/SyVqJZ

Pic: Rob Irgendwer

Have you ever had the pleasure of spending time with an elephant? 

Asian elephants in Laos have long associations with culture and national identity, but an Australian study is sounding alarm bells, suggesting their days in Laos may soon be over. 

Laos was once known as the Land of a Million Elephants with their images adorning street signs and relief carvings in temples, testament to their revered role in Lao culture, but the study estimates only 480 captive working elephants remain. More: http://bit.ly/1g76hQd

Who or what is Boko Haram? 

They're the group that has claimed responsibility for kidnapping 276 schoolgirls in Nigeria last month. Read more about Boko Haram on Radio Australia's website:
link_name: Nigerian schoolgirl abduction: Boko Haram claims responsibility for kidnapping 276 students |...

status_message:
Are you immunised? What about your children?

The World Health Organisation has declared polio a public health emergency of international concern after detecting the virus in 10 countries. 

"If unchecked, this situation could result in failure to eradicate globally one of the world's most serious vaccine preventable diseases", according to the WHO. More: http://bit.ly/1iRCBME

Has your curiosity about MH370 waned yet?

Investigators appear no closer to finding the Malaysian plane that disappeared on March 8 with 239 people aboard. In this picture, Australian Navy vessel Ocean Shield is deploying the Bluefin-21 underwater vehicle that Australia announced today will be central to the next phase of the search mission. 

Do you think a dedicated team of vessels from Australia, China and Malaysia will ultimately find MH370?

Pic: US Navy
What is attracting property investors from Asia to Australia's most livable city?
link_name: Affluent Asian investors buying up Melbourne property

status_message:
Do you listen to Radio Australia on shortwave or FM? 

Some changes this afternoon for you - we'll have two games of AFL today.  Join the ABC Grandstand team from 1pm Sydney time (1pm PNG, 10am Cambodia, 3pm Fiji).

First, North Melbourne vs Gold Coast.  Then West Coast vs Fremantle.   Don't forget that live AFL coverage is also on Australia Network television too.  Live scores via the ABC Grandstand website below.

Our sharks are notorious, but what else is lurking in the Australian environment, and what are the chances of you getting on the wrong side of one of these creatures?  

Check out this handy Australia Plus guide to the deadly Australian animals you'd be very unlikely to meet if you came Down Under.
link_name: Natural dangers: how to be safe with sharks and other Australian deadly creatures

status_message:
Today is World Press Freedom Day.

International media freedom watchdog Reporters Without Borders has announced its inaugural list of the world's most courageous journalists. 

Tongan broadcaster Kalafi Moala is one of two Pacific representatives on the list, along with East Timor's Jose Belo. Mr Moala was jailed for publishing seditious material in the 1990s.

He told Pacific Beat that Tonga and nations across the southern Pacific are still unused to a media that criticises authority, but that this was changing.

"Over the years as independent media comes into the scene and starts challenging power with truth, exposing irregularities that are happening in our governance systems - this is something new."
link_name: Tongan publisher named 'information hero' by media freedom watchdog

status_message:
Brothers Pene and Amitai Pati, and their baritone cousin Moses Mackay are SOL3 MIO

These three opera singers from Samoa are in Australia right now, winning people over with their honey-smooth voices and Pacific charm.

They spoke to Phil Kafcaloudes earlier today about their training, background and ambitions.   Listen via the link below.
link_name: Three Samoan tenors come to Radio Australia

status_message: Iraqi-born Australian actor, Don Hany talks to Phil Kafcaloudes about becoming unhealthy for his role in his new movie 'Healing' all about a prisoner who reconnects with himself as he cares for birds of prey.
link_name: Film star Don Hany talks about his new film 'Healing' with Phil Kafcaloudes on Radio Australia

status_message:
Can Australia's national rugby league team make history?

The world champion Kangaroos are favourites to beat a depleted New Zealand team at the Sydney Football Stadium on Friday night.

Radio Australia will be carrying the game live from 7pm Sydney time (9pm in Fiji, 4pm in Cambodia).

A new movie, Canopy,  is a World War Two thriller set in the Singapore jungle occupied by Japanese forces. It has very little dialogue and instead concentrates on the atmosphere and horror of being stranded in the jungle. Phil Kafcaloudes spoke to the director Aaron Wilson.
link_name: New movie challenges our reactions in a war | ABC Radio Australia

status_message:
Leading banks in Australia are funding companies accused of land grabbing and illegal logging in Cambodia, Papua New Guinea and Indonesia, according to Oxfam. 

Australia's big four banks are among the most profitable in the developed world.

Would you change banks if your bank was involved in unethical funding?

Read more: http://ab.co/1mPSUch

It takes bravery and guts to stand up to an abuser. 

Time magazine has named an Indonesian maid allegedly tortured by her Hong Kong employer as one of the world's 100 most influential people.

Erwiana Sulistyaningsih reported months of abuse but spoke out against her employer and pushed for laws to better protect foreign helpers in Hong Kong. 

The 23 year old helper is delighted at the news of being named on Time's list.
link_name: 'Tortured' Indonesian maid named one of Time's most influential people

status_message:
What are the benefits of studying at Australia's elite universities? 

Chandarany Oouch (below) from Cambodia is studying for a PhD in Economics at Monash University in Melbourne because the course offers "advanced training beyond the research-only PhD". 

Australia is a study destination for many from around the world, with 39 universities offering a world class education. Eight of these are considered a step ahead in terms of international reputation and research outcomes. 

More international student stories here: http://ausp.lu/1l5iRo9

Samoan-Australian boxer, Alex Leapai, has been warming up for his heavyweight world title fight with Pacific Beat host Richard Ewart. 

Leapai has dismissed suggestions he'll need one "lucky punch" to beat Ukrainian Wladimir Klitschko in this Sunday's (Australian time) contest in Germany. 

From all at Radio Australia, we wish you the best of luck Alex. 

See some of the media conference in Germany earlier this week:  http://ab.co/1gSFA1H

Countries across the region are remembering fallen soldiers today on Anzac Day. Something that gets forgotten is the story of indigenous people in war. Today US historian Noah Wiseman spoke to Phil Kafcaloudes about the effect of war on the first peoples of PNG and Australia.
link_name: Remembering indigenous peoples' experience of war on Anzac Day - Radio Australia

status_message:
Are gangs of Pacific Islanders on the rise in the USA? 

Questions are being asked after 25-year old Siale Angilau, allegedly a member of the 'Tongan Crip Gang', was shot dead in a Salt Lake City courtroom earlier this week.

One time American gang member now turned criminologist, Douglass James Fort, spoke to Phil Kafcaloudes from Radio Australia's Morning Show about Pacific Island communities in California. Listen to the full interview:
link_name: Gang expert Douglass Fort on the rise of Pacific Islander gangs in the USA - Radio Australia

status_message:
Join Radio Australia tomorrow for comprehensive coverage of Anzac Day activities and commemorations across Australia and overseas. 

Coverage will begin at 5am AEST with the Dawn Service from the Australian War Memorial in Canberra. 

This year is the 100th anniversary of the beginning of WWI, join us for this significant event. For details of the full days schedule: http://bit.ly/1jDFUSM

Meet Dan Sultan, a Melbourne based singer/songwriter whose new album 'Blackbird' has made its debut Top 5 in the Australian music charts. Dan dropped by our Radio Australia studios to perform a song from the album, a very heartfelt ballad of longing called 'The Same Man'. 

Dan's been described as a 'superstar in the waiting', what do you think?
link_name: Dan Sultan live at Radio Australia

status_message:
Is this India's funniest man?

Rohan Desai had 2,000 people laughing out loud at the Melbourne International Comedy Festival last week and says it was the best night of his life.

Listen to some of the show's highlights and an introduction to Rohan Desai.
link_name: Rohan Desai Makes Comedic Mark In Melbourne

status_message: The Pierce Brothers are multi-skilled, often playing didgeridoo, guitar, harmonica and drum at the same time and there's only two of them. They learnt these multi-tasking skills as buskers. Hear them play on Radio Australia in about 20 minutes!

Pius Wasi, from the East Sepik Province region of Papua New Guinea, performing at the inaugural Boomerang Festival, held late last year near Byron Bay in NSW.

Pius was part of Wantok Sing Sing, a group which includes the likes of Frank Yamma, Djakapurra, Vika and Linda Bull, Arieleke, and Kas tha' Feelstyle, brought together by a passionate advocate for Pacific  music, David Bridie.

We are featuring this live performance today on Radio Australia at midday and 8pm PNG/Sydney time.  Find out more here: http://ab.co/1l4Qadz

Hey Mom, kick it to me! 

Mums in the tiny Pacific nation of Guam are leading by example. The Soccer Moms League is run by the Guam Football Association and boasts more than 200 players and 10 teams. 

With team names like the Lady Crushers, Crush Hers and Queen Cobras these Moms are giving the boot to the stereotypical view that soccer Mums are destined to stand cheering on the sidelines. 

The Moms are taking a break this weekend due to Easter but play will resume next weekend. Read more here: http://bit.ly/1t3fQIB

"One lady turned up wearing a dress made out of rubber laundry gloves." 

Australia's colourful Queen of the Desert Festival is hoping to make it into the record books today, by being the longest street parade in the world. 

Organisers are hoping the parade will stretch a whopping 40-kilometres and promise plenty of tinsel, rainbow colours, fishnet stockings, make up and party music. More: http://ab.co/1m6y6PU

Hungry for something other than chocolate this Easter? Perhaps I could interest you in some marbled angus beef or carpaccio of abalone, as pictured here?

Both ingredients featured prominently during an Asian chefs tour of the Australian state of Victoria this month. Watch the 'Chef's on Tour' or find more info here: http://bit.ly/1iXpaXJ

Are you ready to live on another planet? 

Scientists have found an Earth-sized world orbiting in a life-friendly zone around a distant star for the first time.

The discovery, announced on Thursday, is the closest we have come so far to finding a true Earth twin.

What is the difference between saying a prayer and singing it? 

We're featuring a special Encounter radio program today for Good Friday. We'll visit churches, synagogues and places of worship to meet singers and songwriters, and talk about the importance of bursting into song. Listen to some life changing chants, gospel music and modern Australian compositions as well. 

(photo by Marko Vallius, flickr)

Three young Tongan-Australians from Western Sydney are bringing traditional unaccompanied Tongan gospel alive for a new generation.

Listen to their angelic voices here: http://ab.co/1mfOpHk

It is Good Friday, a holy day for Christians around the world and a public holiday in Australia. This is one of the many special radio programs we are featuring today. Listen to Radio Australia live online: http://bit.ly/1bYPJee

The search for survivors from the South Korean ferry that sank with 462 passengers and crew continues today. 100 navy and coast guard vessels and aircraft, and a US navy ship are involved. But efforts could be hampered by strong rain and wind and fog.

Most of the passengers were teenagers and their teachers on a trip from Danwon High School in Ansan, a suburb in Seoul.
link_name: Search resumes for hundreds missing in South Korean ferry disaster

status_message:
The cast of Faulty Towers The Dining Experience dropped by Radio Australia's studios, this time, bringing a dust-buster and chocolate muffins. They are part of the Melbourne Comedy Festival 2014.

Click on the video link to watch some of their mischief!
http://bit.ly/1l9DH3L

The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and their son, Prince George, have arrived in Sydney for a 10-day trip down under. 

While in Australia, the baby prince will have a bilby enclosure at Taronga Park Zoo named after him. The royal trip will take in Sydney, Adelaide, Brisbane, Canberra and the iconic Uluru, where they will meet Indigenous artists and students.

Royal visit itinerary and more here: http://ab.co/1npwC0B

(Photos by the ABC's Lawrence Champness and John Donegan)

The Premier of NSW, Barry O'Farrell, has resigned following a difficult hearing at the Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC). 

It's alleged Mr O'Farrell received a $3,000 bottle of Grange Hermitage wine but failed to report it in his pecuniary interests declaration for the period. Details here: http://ab.co/1h1pgep

"If you spoke to people living with HIV and ask them what they expect from us, the scientists, they will tell you immediately: a treatment - a cure."  

Scientists haven't lost the sense of urgency to find a cure for HIV-aids. 

The woman who co-discovered HIV in 1983, Professor Francoise Barre-Sinoussi, says after first identifying the virus 31 years ago, scientists naively thought a vaccine and possibly a cure would follow shortly after. 

35-million people around the world are living with the virus and the search for a cure is as vital as ever. Full story: http://bit.ly/1hDJjo6

Australian electronica musician Chet Faker made quite a splash on the Australian and international music charts when he released his 2012 EP 'Thinking In Textures'. 

So much so, his debut album 'Built On Glass' is one of the most anticipated releases in recent years, and it's finally dropped. Join Chet Faker in conversation with Phil Kafcaloudes coming up on the Radio Australia Morning Show. Listen in here: http://bit.ly/18UzJZt

Sursdei Chhnam Thmei!

Happy New Year Cambodia! Take care and have fun during your three day new year festivities.

Pic: Sam Sith

"It's hard to describe what I feel when I'm with a whale," says photographer, Bryant Austin. 

Austin spends months with whales off Tonga, Dominica and the Great Barrier Reef and is currently exhibiting at the Australian National Maritime Museum in Sydney. To photograph the whales, the American artist snorkels on the ocean's surface and lets the whales come and investigate him. 

Bryant Austin's 'Beautiful Whale' life size photography collection is open until February, 2015. View the gallery here:  http://ab.co/1eyoTNO

Drastic human changes are needed to prevent global temperature rises, according to the latest report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).

Current efforts to reduce carbon emissions are not having an impact with greenhouse gas emissions now reaching unprecedented levels. 

The report warns that energy efficiency improvements have not kept up with economic growth and says delaying action until 2030 could force reliance on technologies to extract greenhouse gases from the air. Read the details here: http://bit.ly/1iKHQcX

This pic by ABC audience member Brendan D'Arcy

This week on Australia Network's #TalkAboutIt program Del Irani speaks to one of Australia's biggest popstars, Jessica Mauboy, and also meets some young Indigenous Australians forging their path to the future. Watch again here:

Hey it's the weekend, let me have some peace and quiet!

This waterlogged Galah is from the Australian state of New South Wales. Also known as the rose-breasted cockatoo, it is one of the most common and widespread of the cockatoo family, and is found in almost all parts of mainland Australia. 

This pic was taken by Sophie Frazer and submitted to the ABC Open Feathers project. From all at Radio Australia, we hope you have a peaceful weekend.

The latest on Cyclone Ita, the category-five system bearing down on the far north Queensland coast, which is showing no signs of weakening.  Ita is expected to make landfall this evening or tonight between the towns of Cape Melville and Cooktown.

The cyclone has very destructive winds of up to 300 kilometres per hour near the core.   The outer edges of the weather system is also impacting on PNG.

A cyclone warning is current for coastal areas from Cape Sidmouth to Innisfail, including Cooktown, Port Douglas and Cairns, and extending inland to areas including Kalinga, Palmerville, Mareeba and Chillagoe.
link_name: Cyclone Ita shows no sign of weakening as it nears far north Queensland

status_message:
The drenched south eastern tip of PNG can expect rain to begin easing overnight as Tropical Cyclone Ita moves towards far north Queensland. 

Australia's Bureau of Meteorology (BOM) warns Ita has "a very, very destructive centre" and that due to a large convergence of rain, some areas of PNG could receive up to 300mm. 

Emergency crews in far north Qld are ramping up preparations as Ita is expected to reach landfall around Cooktown tomorrow night.

The BOM released this graph early this afternoon.

IT'S THURSDAY! 

Tonight, about 300 Samoans will turn up at Maluafou College in Apia for a fund-raising Zumba session, led by Fana Apineru and her team of about 15 Zumba instructors.

"(Zumba) is motivating Samoans to be healthy and happy," says Ms Apineru. "We've got one of the highest diabetes rates in the Pacific"

Zumba is one of the most popular ways in Samoa to lose weight. Ms Apineru's class is free for Samoans who can't afford the cost. The classes are fund-raising events for the local church.

Australian government aid is being unloaded by Defence personnel in the Solomon Islands. 

Aid distribution is a priority with half the residents in Honiara, the capital of Solomon Islands, still without fresh water. Australia has pledged $3-million in aid to help the flood recovery. 

Harrowing accounts of last week's unprecedented floods are beginning to trickle through. Read more here: http://bit.ly/1lLkS8v

Pic from Tony Bransby in Solomon Islands.

A centuries-old Stradivarius, or a shiny new violin? 

Aficionados claim they prefer old over new, but when 10 highly talented soloists were tested, new violins outscored the old. The new instruments scored highly for playability, articulation and projection and were at least equal to old in terms of timbre. Read more here: http://ab.co/1g5AxOy

Pic thanks to Jose Zaragoza.

Click, click go the cameras. Click, clack go the high heels.

Australian Fashion Week is underway in Sydney where more than 70 designers are vying for a share of an estimated $44 million in sales to domestic and international buyers. The Australian fashion landscape has changed over the past couple of years as local designers struggle to compete against large international companies. 

More on fashion week here: http://ab.co/1n2d4iA

"The simple fact is, there is no reliable evidence that there is an effect of homeophathy". 

Australia's National Health and Research Council have been researching the effectiveness of alternative medicines in relation to 68 health conditions and concluded there is no clinical evidence that homeopathy is more effective than a placebo. 

What do you think?

Thanks to Hanabishi for the picture.

Honiara and the whole island of Guadalcanal in Solomon Islands has been declared a disaster zone after torrential rain caused massive flooding, the loss of 23 lives and 9,000 homes. 

"What we need is reconstruction – mere rehabilitation will not work in the long term", says the chairman of the Solomon Islands National Disaster Council. 

Permanent secretary Melchoir Mataki says infrastructure such as roads and bridges need to be rebuilt, not just repaired.

Is that a three sided bat?

12-year old Luani Faausu (pictured right) uses a 'pate' to smash the ball a long way in Kilikiti, Samoa's unique brand of cricket. Kilikiti is mostly confined to the shores of Samoa, but over the weekend a tournament took place in Australia. The full story can be heard on the RA Morning Show. Listen in: http://bit.ly/18UzJZt

"The first detection was held for approximately two hours and 20 minutes," confirmed the leader of the international search effort for Malaysian Airlines flight MH370. 

Australia's Ocean Shield defence vessel has detected signals consistent with those emitted by black box flight recorders. Retired Air Chief Marshal Angus Houston says the information is encouraging, but urged caution until it could be verified. Read more here: http://ab.co/1fZyqbN

More than 7-million Afghans braved poor weather and Taliban threats to vote in an election that will bring the first ever democratic transfer of power to Afghanistan. 

Due to difficult terrain, 3,000 donkeys were needed to carry ballots and voting boxes to Afghanistan's most inaccessible areas. It could take up to six weeks before a result is announced.

Running a finger over Fiji's constitution? 

Fiji's government has released a braille version of its constitution. Members of Fiji's visually impaired community will be able to read the constitution to help better inform them before this September's general election. Read more here: http://ab.co/1ihxr78

Did you hear our broadcasts from Apia, Samoa last week?

Read some of the reflections from our guests on life in Samoa, the challenges facing the country and the many positive aspects of life in a Pacific paradise.
link_name: Reflections on life in Samoa | Australia Plus

status_message:
The ABC's Q&A TV program is on the road this Monday, broadcasting live from #Shanghai, China!

Watch live on Australia Network or listen on Radio Australia on Monday evening from 9:35pm POM/SYD time.

On the panel:
Former Ambassador to China, Dr Geoff Raby
Businesswoman and media executive, Mei Yan
Program Director Greenpeace East Asia, Ma Tianjie
Television Presenter, Cheng Lei
Chinese Australian artist, Guo Jian

Learn more about the panelists here: http://www.abc.net.au/tv/qanda/coming_up.htm

And if you're in Shanghai, or know someone who is, you can still register to be part of the audience here: 
http://ausp.lu/s-QandAShanghai

Thank you, Samoa, for an amazing time. We loved meeting you and hearing your stories.

Our Samoa broadcast team is home safe. This was the last photo captured, taken at Apia's Faleolo airport. It shows how much gear we need to transport to make the broadcast happen!

Flash flooding in Solomon Islands has swept away entire residential districts and at least 23 people are missing. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) has confirmed 17 dead in the disaster, with the toll expected to rise.

The Australian government has announced it will provide $AU250,000 in emergency relief supplies to the flood-hit country, in response to a request for assistance from the Solomon Islands government.

Major infrastructure including the sewerage systems, water supply and main bridges have been badly damaged or destroyed. Electricity and communications have also been severely affected.

Aid workers fear outbreaks of disease in the city and are waiting for Honiara airport to reopen so emergency relief supplies can be flown in.
link_name: At least 17 dead in Solomon Islands flood disaster

status_message:
How do you get kids eating healthy local food rather than packaged foods that lack proper nutrition?

April Turner is an Australian volunteer in Pohnpei.  She has been working with teachers to bring healthy eating advice to children as young as three in a fun but educational way.  April spoke with Radio Australia's Heather Jarvis about how to make local food "cool" for kids.
link_name: Micronesian preschoolers learn the value of healthy local foods

status_message:
Do you find it hard to remember things you did, or places you have been if you didn't take a photo?

Antony Funnell investigates our relationship with photography in the social media age.  Antony's program Future Tense is heard each week on Radio Australia.

"We're very pleased to have been getting the support from PNG and Nauru that we've had and we look forward to further support from other countries in our region including from Cambodia." says Australia's Prime Minister Tony Abbott.

Do you think Cambodia should accept asylum seekers from Australia?

Australia's Immigration Minister Scott Morrison is in Cambodia, where he has held talks with the country's interior minister to follow up on an earlier request for the country to help resettle asylum seekers.
link_name: Prime Minister says Government would welcome decision by Cambodia to accept asylum

status_message:
It's Friday!  We've been in Samoa this week, working up a sweat behind the microphone and in this zumba class. Time to unwind from the week that was.

Thanks to everyone who joined us at the Samoa Tourism Authority's fale. We had the most amazing time and will miss you all when we return to Australia.

We hope everyone, everywhere has a safe, relaxing and healthy weekend.

"This is unprecedented, and I've seen earthquakes and tsunamis and other very bad flooding incidents. But this flash flooding is unlike anything that I've seen previously here in the country"

Oxfam Solomon Islands country director Katie Greenwood told us that the floods are causing unprecedented damage.  

16 bodies were recovered on Friday morning and an unconfirmed number of people are still missing. Flooding has caused road blockages in and around Honiara, with Henderson International Airport experiencing flight delays.

Government spokesman George Hemming has told the ABC that search and rescue efforts are ongoing, but are hampered by heavy rain and the huge waves that have been battering the coastline.

Our thoughts with all those affected and with everyone in Solomon Islands for the weekend ahead.

(image by Kim Litera, via twitter)
link_name: Flash flooding in Solomon Islands leaves at least 16 dead, thousands homeless | ABC Radio Australia

status_message:
It's our third and final broadcast from Apia, Samoa today. It's been an eventful start to the program due to very heavy rain but the team, and their mobile studio, are dry and safe in the fale next to the Samoa Tourism Authority. 

Samoan radio host Lady Lala is sharing hosting duties with Phil and they'll be talking the 'clean and jerk' and the 'snatch' with Samoan weightlifting star's Mary Opeloge and Vaipava Nevo Ioane. Listen in here: http://bit.ly/18UzJZt.

Terrible flash flooding occured in Honiara, Solomon Islands this evening. 

Government spokesman George Hemming says entire residential areas and settlements were washed away when the Mataniko River burst its banks. Mr Hemming says a flood alert remains in place.

"The government actually issued a warning yesterday (Wednesday) asking people living along coastal areas as well along big rivers and streams to move to higher ground."

Follow latest updates online here: http://ab.co/1fOgz7s

(Photo below via @AnnaPowles - twitter)

"We'll continue to work closely with the Australian Government to draw up a comprehensive agreement on the search. The search area is vast and the conditions are not easy. But a new refined area of search has given us new hope."

Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak speaking earlier today after arriving in Australia.  He has been briefed on the search for missing flight MH370 at the Pearce RAAF base in Perth.

Mr Najib personally thanked the search crews involved, saying the continued efforts of 26 nations in the search for the missing plane will not be forgotten. He singled out Australia's efforts in coordinating the search and described the country as a "good friend".
link_name: Malaysia Airlines MH370: Malaysian PM Najib Razak briefed on search efforts

status_message: Indonesia is having both parliamentary and presidential elections in 2014. How does the electoral system work and who gets to stand for president? ABC News explains.

Postcards from a Pacific paradise! Radio Australia is broadcasting from Samoa this week. Below are some photos from our second day in Apia.  

We had a great co-host in Keni Lesa from the Samoa Observer, who took part in fascinating conversations about organic food, women in business and healthy living.  Phil even got a chance to stretch himself in a zumba class!

If you are in Samoa come down and see us on our final day tomorrow at the fale, near the Samoan Tourism Authority.

Radio Australia is broadcasting Island style again today. Tune in to hear the Editor of the Samoan Observer, Mata'afa Keni Lesa share the hosting duties with Phil Kafcaloudes. 

On the show today: organic farming, women in business and food, Samoan style.

Listen live here: http://bit.ly/18UzJZt

Chris Solomona gets to share his passion for Samoan culture with visitors to the cultural village in Apia, Samoa. He joined Phil Kafcaloudes on the first day of our broadcast from Samoa to talk about why tourism was important to his country.

Join Phil this morning from 11:30am Apia time (7:30am in PNG, 9:30am in Fiji) for more fascinating conversations.  Why is there a doctor shortage here and what kind of food to people love to grow and eat? Listen live to find out.
link_name: Chris Solomona, Samoa Tourism Authority, on the importance of tourism to Samoa's economy.

status_message:
"Samoa has it's own culture and it's important we maintain that way of doing things for our young people of the future so we can transmit to them the institutional and cultural memory of our people to understand the way they lived and did things in the past."

The National University of Samoa Vice Chancellor Professor Asofou So'o joined Radio Australia's Phil Kafcaloudes in Apia on the first day of our live broadcasts in Samoa.  Join us again this tomorrow on 102FM in Apia, and across the Pacific on our local frequencies.

status_message:
Photos from our first day broadcasting live in Apia, Samoa. 

We had great conversations about tourism, volunteering, tattooing, preserving Samoan culture, and the important links between Australia and it's Pacific neighbour. 

Phil Kafcaloudes is back at the fale, near the Samoan Tourism Authority tomorrow, live from 11:30am Apia time. If you are in town come down or listen locally on 102FM.

Find out more about our broadcasts here: http://bit.ly/1kqZlQT

There has been a magnitude 8.2 earthquake off the coast of Chile. 

The Pacific Tsunami Warning Centre says waves have been measured in Chile at 1.7 to 1.9 meters.  A tsunami warning is in place for Chile, Peru and Ecuador, while a tsunami watch is in effect for Colombia, Panama and Costa Rica. 

So far there are no tsunami warnings in place for Micronesia, Polynesia or Melanesia, nonetheless the Pacific Tsunami Warning Centre has issued a map indicating possible travel times in the event a tsunami was to travel across the Pacific.

Did you hear this conversation with host of The World, and former South-East Asia correspondent Zoe Daniel?

Listen again here, as she discusses her book "Storyteller" with Richard Fidler.

Our morning host Phil Kafcaloudes on local TV in Apia, Samoa last night.  He's speaking here with TV presenter Toleafoa Pili Afamasaga Asiata who has the most fantastic chilli lei don't you think! (they are actually seeds of the pandanus tree, thanks Chee Kim -ed)

We'll be broadcasting live tomorrow morning from the fale in the centre of town, next to the Samoan Tourism Authority.  If you are in Apia, come down and join us from 11:30am.

"I think this is a time for the Japanese to reflect and to understand the importance of this decision - to respect the decision and then to make the right decision themselves".

Ian Campbell, a former Environment Minister in Australia, with his reaction to International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruling that Japan must immediately stop its whaling program in the Antarctic.

The ICJ supported Australia's argument that Japan's whaling program was not in fact designed and carried out for scientific purposes.   

Do you think this will change Japan's approach to whaling?
link_name: Japan ordered to immediately stop whaling in Antarctic

You might not know this... Up to 70,000 kangaroos are culled in state of Victoria every year and currently the carcasses are buried. Now, some of those kangaroos will be turned into commercial pet food as part of a new trial approved by the Victorian Government. 

The kangaroo meat industry says it's a great idea, but environmentalists say the industry is not sustainable.  Find out more via ABC Rural | Bush Telegraph : http://ab.co/1jlcUFg

(photo by Jpp)

Not even a cyclone threat could put a dampener on Tiwi Islands grand final day, where the Tuyu Buffaloes beat the Marrawurri Magpies. 

The game took place on Bathurst Island, about 80km to the north of Darwin, where the Arafura Sea joins the Timor Sea.  

The Tiwis love their football, and they're not afraid to show it. The crowd began roaring from the second the teams ran onto the ground and didn't stop.  Hear more: http://ab.co/1gxtPkh

World's biggest weapons importer? It's still India! 

India imports nearly three times as many weapons as the world number two and three, China and Pakistan. And just in case your were curious, fourth and fifth place belong to the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia, respectively.

Are we moving towards a post-human world, where technology will become as much a part of us as flesh and blood? 

Some people say yes, and they're pretty darn happy about it. They're called transhumanists, and they think technology is the answer to making us faster, stronger, smarter and maybe even immortal.

As almost anyone who has tried to sleep in late knows, birds sure do like to sing. But do you know why?

Charles Darwin thought it was mostly male birds who sang to attract mates, and that female birds mostly listened. But new research shows that might be wrong, and female birds can and do sing just as well (and as loudly) as their male counterparts.
link_name: Was Charles Darwin sexist when it comes to Aussie birds?

Daisy Alik-Momotaro and Yoshiko Yamaguchi are both strong advocates for women's and youth rights in the Marshall Islands. They first got to know each other at a Catholic Church retreat when Yoshiko was in secondary school.

Since then, Daisy has mentored Yoshiko - through a young pregnancy, university studies and now in her career. 

Yoshiko says "without her I wouldn't be as strong and confident as I am today. We need more women like her in the RMI."

Every day, women are working together to help create change in the world. Along the way, they are also changing each other's lives.

Read more about Daisy and Yoshiko here: http://bit.ly/1e3JBPI

When it comes to music, women rock (and roll and rap and croon and...) Listen again to our conversation on women who have changed the face of the music world. And get involved! Which female musician has influenced you?

There's a major victory for women in politics in Papua New Guinea right now...

Sohe MP, Delilah Gore has been appointed Minister for Higher Education and now joins the member for Lae, Loujaya Kouza, who is Community Development Minister. This is the first time in PNG history, that two women have been appointed as Ministers of State.  

Delilah Gore will be speaking to Phil Kafcaloudes tomorrow morning.  0745 Port Moresby time.

Thousands of people have held candlelight vigils around Australia for slain asylum seeker Reza Berati, who died in violence at Manus Island detention centre last Monday.

A crowd of 5,000 people gathered in Melbourne's Federation Square while 4,000 more rallied at Sydney's town hall, with candles lit for the 23-year-old man. More: http://bit.ly/OrkwbQ

Up next, the Paralympics!

Can you guess why this artist placed over 200 plastic fish on the beach? (This might help: http://ab.co/1jiClnB)  

And yes, she cleaned them up!
Yohan Goutt Goncalves, East Timor's first Winter Olympian ever, will race in alpine skiing tomorrow. Good luck, Yohan! We'll be cheering you on!

Do you remember when you caught your first fish? Or maybe you've never been fishing before? 

Anyways, it must have been a pretty amazing feeling for this little one, when she caught her first fish in south-west Western Australia. Now that's the kind of feeling you want to carry you into the weekend!

For many years English teacher David Menasche taught at a Miami high school and his students loved his classes. But eight years ago, at the age of 34, he was diagnosed with a terminal brain tumour.

As his health deteriorated, and his vision and ability to walk started to falter, David made the audacious decision to travel across America to see what had happened to the lives of his ex-students since they had left his classroom.
link_name: The Priority List: A teacher's final quest to discover life's great lessons

status_message:
The Queen Mary 2 is currently circumnavigating Australia as part of her tenth birthday celebrations.  

Taking a cue from this, Phil Kafcaloudes' morning program will be  playing all types of sailing songs this Friday. 

We welcome all your suggestions - from sea shanties to yacht rock and boating blues to pirate punk.

Would you eat parrot-friendly almonds?

The endangered Regent parrot is usually considered a pest for almond growers. But could farmers make more money by keeping these birds on their crops?
link_name: Farmers working with nature for increased profits

status_message:
Happy Thursday morning! 

Thanks to Mike Smith for sharing this photo of a dog fishing at sunrise at Golden Beach in, Queensland. Wonder if he caught anything?

Sometimes, laughter is the best medicine. Clowns Without Borders Australia is heading out to disaster zones and under-privileged areas across the Asia-Pacific to help children.

So far the group has been to refugee camps in Myanmar, parts of the Philippines ravaged by super-typhoon Haiyan, and remote Indigenous communities in Australia.
link_name: Clowning around to bring joy to disadvantaged in Asia-Pacific

status_message:
Update: A Thai police officer has been shot dead in Bangkok street clashes. Thai police arrested around 100 opposition protesters during an operation to take back government buildings from demonstrators in Bangkok.

Yesterday demonstrators poured buckets of cement onto a sandbag wall in front of a gate to Government House.
link_name: Thai opposition protesters arrested in Bangkok after huge police deployment

Is the processing centre worth the financial gain for PNG?

Beryl Newton is over 100 years old. She was raised by her mother, a strong woman who taught her that women are every bit as capable and relevant as men. This short video gives you a glimpse into her life and incredible wisdom.  (Thanks, ABC Open!)

In Australia, it's definitely NOT raining men. There are 100,000 more women in the country, which had Phil asking 'are we in the grips of a man drought?' 

He spoke with social researcher Mark McCrindle to find out more. Listen again at the link!

Members of Aatma Dance Company, a Melbourne-based Bollywood dance group, at One Billion Rising. Doesn't it make you want to get up and dance?

An athlete competes at the ASP Pro Junior Women surfing tournament at Sydney's Manly Beach.

This is Eleanor's story. She lives in Barunga, a remote community about four and a half hours south of Darwin.

She works at the community library and as a reading mentor with the Northern Territory Library. What's your favourite story to share with others?

Imagine smashing a clay pot to bits, and then slowly putting it back together. That's what Cambodian-American artist Amy Lee Sanford does in her piece 'Breaking Pots.' It's an incredibly powerful statement about the consequences of war.  Read more here: http://bit.ly/1btYdMQ
link_name: Amy Lee Sanford on breaking pots and piecing together the past

status_message:
How much would you pay for a painitng by a real live meerkat? 

Paintings by three of the Canberra National Zoo's female meerkats, Mbali, Makena and Sekai, are being offered for sale to raise funds for wildlife conservation.  More: http://ab.co/1jdd25D

Will you be our Valentine? RA Mornings presenter Phil Kafcaloudes showing his love for everyone out there in radio land (and Facebook land, too!)  Have a wonderful weekend. We're looking forward to spending time with you on air again on Monday!

February 14 isn't just Valentine's Day. It's also the day when men and women around the world come together to call for an end to violence against women in One Billion Rising.  We take a look at events in Indonesia, Fiji and Australia, and talk to some of the people who are using today to make a difference: http://bit.ly/1btNTVd

status_message: Just in case you might be thinking of popping the question today.... We take a look at the most romantic places in the world to propose. (But to be honest, if you're in love, any place will do, right?)

Modest fashion is vibrant, fresh and exploding across the globe - and it's not just Muslim women. US photographer Langston Hughes is travelling the world to document it. We brought you some of his photos earlier in the week, now you can hear him talk about the project in his own words.

Caroline Tiriman, Bethany Keats and Kenya Kala from our Tok Pisin service celebrating World Radio Day.

Do you remember when you first heard radio? Caroline told Phil this morning that when she first heard the radio as a small girl in Papua New Guinea, she couldn't believe how a big person could get into the tiny box. Now she does that every day! 

Hear more: http://bit.ly/1kDl2Ap

Happy World Radio Day! 

Meet Alex Khun from our Cambodian service. He says  "I love radio, it lets people's voices be heard. I listen to radio every day either via traditional means, in the car, online or mobile.

"Despite the rise of the internet technologies, radio is here to stay for years to come, especially in the developing nations."

Go, Alex!

Are you prepared for Valentine's Day? 

How will you be showing your love for that someone special?

Leave your comments, gestures of love and pictures here and we'll feature the best ones in a photo gallery.

The Thai election stands ,and on April 27 there will be re-runs in constituencies where voting was disrupted by protesters.

The results of this month's election will not be announced until polls have been held in all constituencies.

But there is still no decision on what to do about 28 constituencies that have no candidates because demonstrators blocked the registration process
link_name: Thai opposition loses bid to annul election

Grace Wadi used to run a coffee shop in South Sudan, before she became a refugee and came to live in Australia. Several years ago she bought a business in Wagga Wagga, New South Wales, that specialises in braiding, dreadlocks, hair extensions and cornrows. 

It's one of only two African hair salons in region, so Grace attracts clients from all over.

Would you be interested in an insurance policy against school bullying? They say it will help cover costs for physical injuries as well as counselling fees for those traumatised by school violence.

status_message: The world continues to watch Thailand, where the situation is far from over. Are you there? And even if you're not, are you hopeful for a peaceful resolution?

Political tension in Thailand continues despite yesterday's election. The main opposition party boycotted the poll with voting disrupted in 18% of constituencies nationwide according to the election commission. Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra will remain caretaker PM with no policy authority until results are announced.
link_name: Thailand election: Voting closes but legal, legislative challenges could see division continue...

status_message: A fisherman who left Mexico in a 24-foot fiberglass boat in late 2012, has washed up on a remote Pacific atoll on the edge of the Marshall Islands. The man claims he survived his year adrift in the Pacific by eating birds and fish caught with his bare hands.
link_name: Castaway washes up on remote Pacific atoll

status_message: Wow, what a life. This flamingo (named "Greater") lived to be 83 years old, and spent most of his life at the Adelaide Zoo, in South Australia. It was the oldest animal in the zoo and the last flamingo of its type in Australia.
link_name: Flamingo believed to be world's oldest dies at Adelaide Zoo aged 83

status_message:
Happy Lunar New Year!

It is now the Year of the Horse.  "Horses" are direct people and get to the point, making them excellent communicators. They are also described as being self reliant, sometimes impulsive, and they'll try things without thinking, which can occasionally get them into trouble! 

We compiled a list of famous Australians born in the year of the horse. Guess who is on it...

In what year were you born? Are you a dingo, or a kangaroo, or maybe a wombat?

This new Aussie zodiac was developed by the Australian Chinese business community. It pairs each of the traditional animals in a 12-year lunar cycle with an Australian animal equivalent. 

We are about to start the year of the horse, which is also the year of the kookaburra!  Listen to Wayne Tseng explaining this new zodiac http://ausp.lu/1b3I3XO

Good morning!  We are performing regular maintenance at some of our shortwave transmitters today. 

We will be off air on most shortwave frequencies between 8am and 4pm Sydney time. This is 7am-3pm in Port Moresby, 9am to 5pm Fiji time and 4am to 12pm Cambodia time.  

Our FM and web audio streaming is unaffected and some of our shortwave frequencies to Asia and the Western Pacific remain active - 9660kHz and 12080kHz. Myanmar is not affected.

On the eve of their departure Syre & Fresko shared their story and their expectations of their upcoming trip to Beijing. Watch the video below and stay tuned for more of their amazing journey.

"I believe we are all connected whether we like it or not. We are all equal and the same in so many ways. My hope is that we as a nation can break down the silos between races, break down those stereotypes of minority populations, Indigenous population and all the other minority groups."

Aboriginal AFL player and anti-racism campaigner Adam Goodes has been named the 2014 Australian of the Year.  

Goodes was chosen for his leadership and advocacy in the fight against racism both on the sporting field and within society - a stance which has won him the admiration and respect of people around Australia.

status_message: Twenty-eight people have been injured, seven of them seriously, at a rally in central Bangkok after two explosions occurred within minutes of each other.
