link_name: Bangkok anti-government protest rally rocked by explosions, 28 people injured

status_message:
"It is like no other day. 

The smell of the clothing, the feel of the fabric and the motion and noise of the washing board. 

Then the breeze arrives and the wind moves the clothes line around and around...the sound of the mechanics of the line...the soft aroma from the fresh clothes mix with the wind and dust particles. 

The colours seem to exaggerate themselves and as they blow in the wind it looks like an ancient Burmese Flag dance...I think I can hear the sound of drums.

The clothes are dry, it has only been seven minutes. 

Once a week, for seven minutes, I feel as though I am somewhere special...somewhere others want to be, somewhere I will remember when I am old. 

I like this place for seven minutes a week...on wash day."

- Steven Powell, ABC Open

It's been very hot across a lot of Australia this week. How hot? So hot, it's hard to eat an ice cream before it melts. We conducted this very scientific experiment to see just how long it takes for one to disappear.

Australian Open - the extreme heat edition. Temperatures are soaring to 42 or 43 degrees this week, and somehow the players are still hitting the courts! Some fans are keeping cool by enjoying the misting fans. But the question remains - how hot does it have to be before they cancel the matches?  

More photos of the tennis here: http://bit.ly/JX1uaC

New research shows a lack of affordable student housing makes foreign students more vulnerable to falling victim to crime. Is it time for Australian universities and other educational institutions to step up and provide better accommodation for international students?
link_name: Calls to help international students with accommodation

status_message: Congratulations to Cate Blanchett, who took home a Golden Globe for best drama actress. She won the award for her performance in Woody Allen's 'Blue Jasmine.' Have you seen it?
link_name: Cate Blanchett wins Golden Globe award for Woody Allen's Blue Jasmine

status_message: This is the difference that 20 years of work can make to the lives of millions.

status_message: Here comes the tennis! The Australian Open kicks off in Melbourne today. We've got a great photo gallery to help get you in the mood.

Disaster management officials in Tonga say they have serious concerns for residents on more than twenty low-lying islands battered by Cyclone Ian.

There's been extensive damage to the islands and at least one person was killed.

Authorities still haven't been able to make contact with smaller out-lying islands, so the full extent of damage or injuries is still unknown.
link_name: Relief efforts underway after destructive Cyclone Ian hits Tonga

status_message: More than 25,000 people have fled their homes following a series of eruptions and lava flows from Mount Sinabung on the western island of Sumatra in Indonesia. The eruptions sent hot rocks and ash up to 5,000 metres in the air several times on Saturday.
link_name: More than 25,000 flee as Indonesia's Mount Sinabung erupts, spews volcanic ash and lava

status_message:
Texting on a jeepney in Manila. Jeepneys are the most popular mode of public transport in the Philippines. Have you ever been on one? 

Esti Feuermann shared this photo with Radio Australia - My World. Thanks, Esti! What's happening in your world today?

Sometime during the next week, Western Australia is set to start a cull on sharks bigger than 3 metres in response to 7 deaths from sharks since 2010 and numerous other attacks. 

Debate over the plan is becoming increasingly divisive, and is being closely watched by shark attack victims and their families who, like the wider community, are divided on the issue.

Preparations are under way for Operation Occupy Bangkok, set to take place this Monday. Major intersections are being blocked across the city. Next to this blockade, there is a very large well-serviced camp where people have been staying for a few months. Toilets, showers and stalls service the residents. Artan Jama shared these photos with us from Bangkok.

Are you there now? What are you seeing?
Two million SUVs, also known as 4WDs, were sold in China last year - 25% more than in the previous year.
link_name: Chinese drivers hitting the road in 4WDs

status_message: That's not snow. It's volcanic ash. You won't believe these incredible photos from Indonesia's Mount Sinabung. It's been erupting since September last year. In the first week of 2014, it erupted 200 times.
A glimpse into Tiananmen Square, Beijing. Our music producer, Kim Taylor, is in Beijing right now and sent back this incredible photo. Thanks Kim!

Precious and Tumble are bare-nosed wombat joeys who are lucky to be alive. They became road orphans when their mothers were hit by cars. A specialist  wildlife rehab centre in New South Wales is hoping to help animals like Precious and Tumble recover.
link_name: Helping injured wildlife get back on their feet

status_message: What happens when the world's largest consumer of tobacco moves towards banning smoking in all public places?
link_name: China aims to ban smoking in public places by end of 2014

status_message:
Two Australians are riding a motorised rickshaw across India. 

They hope to raise $10,000 for Indigenous health research in Australia and a conservation charity in India during their 3500 km journey from the north to the of south of the country.

More: http://ab.co/1dRF0Te

(Photo courtesy Alice Plate)

Cambodia's Opposition says it's preparing to file a complaint to the International Criminal Court against Prime Minister Hun Sen. 

It follows the government's crackdown on striking factory workers last week that left at least four dead.

The ICC prosecutes individual for genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes. Sam Bolitho speaks with Virak Ou, president of the Cambodia Centre for Human Rights, and Sam Rainsy, leader of opposition: http://bit.ly/1ifyQ0k

Happy Birthday to the King of Rock 'n Roll! Elvis Presley would be 79 today. Lana Webber of Rockhampton, Queensland, has created a shrine of Elvis memorabilia, which she has been collecting since her early 20s. Check out her video here: http://ab.co/1dQfnlI

(thanks to ABC Open!)
Dennis Rodman is in North Korea.... again. Is it time we all started paying less attention? Or do you think he might actually do some good by putting the spotlight on the country?
link_name: Rodman in N Korea for Kim Jong-un's basketball birthday bash

Australia has thrashed England by 281 runs to complete a remarkable 5-0 Ashes clean sweep on day three at the SCG.

Thanks to ABC Grandstand for providing live commentary of the last three tests to our audiences in Asia and the Pacific. Have you been listening?

What was one of the first photos you took in 2014? Was it a sunrise, a shot of a family member, or perhaps your first meal of the new year? Radio Australia - My World wants to know! Show us where you are and what you're doing. Let's get to know each other a little bit better.

(Fireworks off the Sydney Harbour Bridge by Alan Davis.)
Globally, each of the past 13 years since 2001 have ranked among the 14 warmest on record. 2014 is shaping up to be no different.

Deer milk cheese? What will they think of next?

Would you eat it?

status_message: There's just something about a new year that makes us all feel hopeful - like we can change, be better people, live better lives. What are your hopes for 2014?
This is what the year looked like for us here at Radio Australia. Here are some of the photos we took in 2013 that best capture our year.
Relaxing on a hammock at the Woodford Folk Festival. More than 100,000 festival goers are expected at the festival on the Sunshine Coast to dance, party, eat, drink and welcome in the new year.
For ABC Open contributor Paul Fox, this was the moment that defined his year. What was yours?
From all of us here at Radio Australia, we wish you a very Merry Christmas. Good tidings to all of you and best wishes for you and your families.

Tens of thousands of lights, countless man hours and a big power bill; these are what go into creating a fairy-tale Christmas lights display.

Across Australia many people are decorating their houses for Christmas. Some go to extremes with lights, statues and decorations, and whole streets are often lit up at night.

Rob Jessett's Christmas lights display brightens up Piccadilly Street in the remote mining town Kalgoorlie (photo by Rebecca Brewin)

A Christmas tree by the side of a lonely highway in north west New South Wales is lifting spirits in this drought-affected region of Australia.

Listen to Trena Hoffman's story. She's a cotton farm at Burren Junction, and she made the tree to bring Christmas cheer to her family and travellers: http://ab.co/1cPTin1

It's one week until Christmas, so we're playing Christmas tunes this morning on the Morning Show.  What's your favourite Christmas song? 

Is it 'Last Christmas' by Wham or 'Do they know it's Christmas' by Band Aid? SMS Phil on +61 427 72 72 72 and tune in to hear our favourites: http://bit.ly/18UzJZt

Pic courtesy of Muscle Mixes.

Can you tell your left from right? 

Science revealed in 2013 that dogs can distinguish left from right even though many humans struggle to do so. Phil Kafcaloudes is talking weird science facts on the Morning Show and we're wondering are you right/left challenged? Feel free to share another weird science fact from 2013?

Thanks to Evan-Amos for the pic.

What is your favourite party song?

We'll aim to play them on Radio Australia on Monday, 16 December, which is the anniversary (1984) of music magazine Smash Hits' publication of favourite party songs of stars like Morrissey and The Cure's Robert Smith .

(Flickr photo: Flavijus. License http://bit.ly/1cfOzXY)

What do you think has been the biggest story of the year?

Radio Australia will look back at some of the big news events of the year at 11.30am Australian Eastern Time. What do you think has been the most significant story? Spying revelations from Edward Snowden? The new Pope? The new Royal? Political upheaval in Thailand? Typhoon Haiyan in the Philippines? Fiji's new constitution?

Feel like a bit of vocal jazz? No Sense Of Direction are a four-piece a capella group from Melbourne whose delicious four-part harmonies, flair and style all combine to provide a musical punch like no other.
link_name: No Sense of Direction - live at Radio Australia

Three Rosellas enjoy a bath at a house in Bungendore, New South Wales.

Did you see Bananas in Pyjamas performing live at the Paradigm Mall, Kuala Lumpur last weekend?  (They'll be there again this weekend!)

Should governments support local industry or should they let the global free market determine which sectors survive?

Australian carmaker Holden has announced it will fold in 2017, leading to a loss of almost 3,000 jobs. There are calls to support Holden with government money to prevent its demise but the government says Australia's car industry can't compete globally because it's too expensive to make them in the country.

Indonesia's answer to Banksy - the renowned Jakartan street artist DARBOTZ - teams up with Melbourne fashion label Fame Agenda, to create a unique and distinctly cross-cultural range of clothing for a show-case event for Multicultural Arts Victoria's "Mapping Melbourne" series.
link_name: Jakartan urban artist Darbotz takes Melbourne

status_message:
Meet 'Lufsig.' He's sold out at Hong Kong's IKEA stores, after becoming an unlikely symbol of opposition to the city's unpopular government. 

He flew off the shelves within hours, days after an anti-government protester threw one at the city's leader Leung Chun-ying during a weekend public meeting.
Thousands of Cambodian opposition supporters and activists, including Buddhist monks, have taken to the streets to mark Human Rights Day and call for improvements in the kingdom's rights record.
link_name: Thousands take to Cambodia's streets on Human Rights Day

status_message:
The world gathers to say goodbye to #NelsonMandela. Australia Network takes you there. We will have coverage of the National Memorial Service, live from Johannesburg from 20:00 AEDT / 9 UTC today.

You can check what time coverage will begin where you are at http://australianetwork.com/guide/ep_00183504.htm

As leaders from around the world gather for Nelson Mandela's memorial service, we are reminded that today is World Human Rights Day. We hope you'll take time today to remember everyone around the world who is struggling for human rights - for themselves and for others.

Photo courtesy United Nations Human Rights

Violence against women affects everyone. So what can you do to help fight it? 

A Samoan-born Melbournian is using her passion for weaving to inspire others to help end violence in the community. She's gathered thousands of woven stars from around the world to create a striking message. #orangeurworld

Is there something you're obsessive about? 

Some people are obsessive about wearing different coloured socks at the same time. Others need to check that the door is locked 10 times before going out.

We discuss Obsessive Compulsive Disorder on Radio Australia today at about 9.20am Australian Eastern Time.

Reckon you know Australia? Then put it to the test.  Test your knowledge of all things Aussie and get the latest on entertainment, lifestyle and travel with the Australia Plus Mobile App. You can polish your English (or your Chinese) and unlock some pretty cool extras like the Aussiegram. http://ausp.lu/1fbFmUy

They've discovered a treasure trove of photos from 60 years ago, and need help to identify people and places from the region. Please let us know if you can help! We'd love to talk to you, too. 

Here's our story on it:http://bit.ly/18GVf6j

Which cultural delicacies would you add?

Local photographer Trav Lord says he had to contend with "strong winds turning vertical rain into horizontal rain bullets." Now that's dedication!

status_message:
It's a sad day here at Radio Australia as we farewell our two guests from Papua New Guinea's NBC who have been with us for the past eight weeks. 

Thanks for all the memories Ahimsa and Jack, we hope you had a great time!

Zoe Daniel ABC Southeast Asia Correspondent took these photos yesterday in #Bangkok, where #protests against the government have been high. Tensions are easing after two days of violent clashes. Here's the latest news from #Thailand: http://bit.ly/1gD8Yug

Mornings presenter Phil Kafcaloudes is in PNG right now to help mark 40 years of NBC National Radio of Papua New Guinea.

Here he is interviewing Sam Koim, Chairman if PNG's anti-corruption agency Task Force Sweep. Australian Federal Police and PNG's top corruption fighting body have signed an agreement to work together to bring corrupt officials to justice. Read more: http://bit.ly/IDekJS

The Special Olympic Asia Pacific Games are underway this week in Newcastle, NSW. And the National Open and Veteran Fencing Championships begin in Canberra tomorrow - bringing together the cream of fencers from as far away as the United States.

These are only two of the major events on the sporting calendar in the Southern Hemisphere at the moment, but we're sure there are many more out there. But what are they?  What sporting events are taking place in your part of the world?

Have you seen your world turning a bit more orange? #orangeurworld is a campaign of 16 days of activism against gender violence. 

Can you make a change?

What sea creature do you fear the most? 

In Australia we've had two fatal shark attacks in the past week, but other Australian sea creatures like the Irukandji jellyfish and the blue ringed octopus are amongst the most venomous marine creatures on the planet.  What's your biggest ocean fear?

Where do pianos go to die? In York, Western Australia, they go to an olive grove. Since the early 2000s, the owners have accepted around 35 pianos from those who can't bear to dump their beloved instruments on the rubbish tip.

Read more: http://ab.co/1aSNFFk

It's summer! And the temperatures are rising. What's your favourite way to keep cool when the heat is on?

Sir Michael Somare was the guest of honour at the launch of 40th anniversary celebrations for Papua New Guinea's NBC yesterday.

There are celebrations all this week and Radio Australia broadcasters Phil Kafcaloudes and Caroline Tiriman are in Port Moresby for the occasion. More: http://bit.ly/1aojKPF

There's something great happening in Somerset, Queensland - koalas are thriving! It's giving scientists hope for the survival of the species in that part of Australia.

Not everyone is raving about it. Some think she should have done a better job of  addressing issues like religious violence and the rule of law.

What did you think?

If Justin Bieber puts graffiti on a wall, does that make it art?

Gold Coast Mayor Tom Tate says 'no'. He'd like the pop star to clean up his mess after he graffitied the wall of a hotel in Queensland.  The hotel says it welcomes Bieber's artwork as a wonderful addition to the Queensland art scene. What do you think?

More: http://ab.co/1a6507L

Ethnic Mon children dressed in traditional costume to welcome Aung San Suu Kyi. 

The Myanmar opposition leader has appealed for Australian support in her bid to become president. Full story: http://bit.ly/1cOKPhE
Melbourne's Alexandra Gardens have been transformed into a night market filled with Asian hawker-style food. What's your favourite dish?

PNG is set to summon Australia, Indonesia will summon South Korea and Singapore, Malaysia has already summoned Singapore to explain allegations of spying.

How much damage do you think has been made to regional relations because of whistleblower Edward Snowden?

Do you remember the first time you heard a radio? 

Caroline Tiriman, from RA's Tok Pisin service, thought very tiny people lived inside her radio receiver. Caroline has been talking with Morning's Host Phil Kafcaloudes about the history and heritage of PNG broadcasting ahead of the NBC's 40th anniversary celebrations that kick off this Sunday.

Bright colours, new materials and ancient weaving techniques: contemporary bilas, inspired from PNG body adornments, found their way to a fashion show celebrating Melbourne's rich and diverse cultural landscape. 

Tune in tomorrow morning to hear Isabelle Genoux speak with two inspiring members of Melbourne's multicultural community.

It's White Ribbon Day today, a day to say 'no' to violence against women.

New research from the World Bank Group says domestic abuse of women also causes an economic drain. It's hoped the findings will spur governments into mobilising greater investment in addressing and tackling domestic violence. More: http://bit.ly/1duTHxS

Is it tougher being a teenager today than ever before? 

This morning Radio Australia is hosting a team of experts who will answer your questions on teenage issues. Are you concerned about teenagers and social media? What about body image, behavioural problems or mental health issues? Post your questions here for our panel of experts. Tune in at 11:30am AEST http://bit.ly/HBiyfP

(Flickr: escapedtowisconsin)

"Marriage isn't a lovey-dovey thing for 80 years," 

"You learn to accept one another's ways of life, agreements, disagreements - disagreements on our children, preparation on bringing up your kids. That was the main interest was your children."

This is Ann Betar's advice. Tomorrow, she and her husband John will celebrate their 81st wedding anniversary.  Read more: http://ab.co/1fkZ1Ec

No kidding around, this photo has not been staged.

A real-life friendship has developed between a baby goat and an 800-kilogram Brahman bullock on a cattle station in central-west Queensland. The goat plays and runs on the bullock's back while it sits, and even sleeps on it. Have you ever had an unusual friendship? 

More: http://ab.co/1baRrKz  
Photo by the animal's owner - Tracey Walker.
Jakarta-born Karina Utomo is a punk princess. She's taking audiences in Australia and Indonesia by storm as the lead singer of Melbourne band High Tension. Check her out!

For the last fortnight we've been reporting on the devastation in the Philippines and beyond wrought by Typhoon Haiyan. We've been touched by the stories we've heard and the people we've spoken to, so it's time we did some more to help.

The Radio Australia and Australia Network family held a bake sale today to raise money for victims of Typhoon Haiyan. We've raised over $600 so far. Counting is still not yet complete.

The National Museum of Samoa has launched a new exhibition documenting the country's voyaging past.

The exhibition, called the 'Art of Voyaging', aims to remind Samoans of their seafaring legacy and highlight the achievements of the country's forefathers.

Find out more: http://bit.ly/HYcjbh
We thought it would never come! But the weekend is finally here. So get it kicked off with a live performance of one of New Zealand's hottest bands Sons of Zion
link_name: Sons of Zion live at Radio Australia

Meet Aibar. Once a personal bodyguard for Aung San Suu Kyi, he came to Australia as a political refugee in 2008. 

He shares his story of working with Aung San Suu Kyi, and how she came to be the special guest at his wedding. 

Aung San Suu Kyi will be in Australia at the end of this month to attend a series of events and meet with the Burmese community. What would you like to tell her?

Competitors race during the Kids in Need Dragon Boat Festival held on the Queensland/New South Wales border.

What's it like to be an international student? Australia is the most popular place for Indonesian students to come to study - but when they arrive, there are quite a few challenges. 

Meet two students who are juggling the pressure of study and managing the basics of day to day living in a very different city, a long way from home.

Have you got a degree but can't find a job? 

This morning on Radio Australia we're talking about improving your chances to land a great job. Does it help if you're qualified? What about if you want to change jobs? Are you working in a job that isn't challenging you? Share your experience her on Facebook or SMS Phil K on +61 427 72 72 72.

Step into a woolen wonderland where everything from the trees and the flowers to the sugar gliders have been knitted by hand. 

The Yarning Our Country exhibit is the project of the small town of Gloucester, New South Wales, and brings together two years of work from over 200 knitters.  More from ABC Rural: http://ab.co/1bZVdTq

First steps: a Tasmanian devil checks out its new surroundings on the safe haven of Maria Island.

The first group of Tasmanian devils born and raised on mainland Australia have been taken home to Tasmania and released into the wild.  Maria Island is a safe haven from the deadly facial tumour disease that has killed so many devils, it has pushed the marsupial close to extinction. More: http://bit.ly/1dOHot6

Do you durian? The 'king of fruits' was celebrated by around 1,250 fans at an event hosted by the Malaysian Consulate General in Melbourne. 

Raymond Loh, chairperson, Malaysian student council of Australia-Victorian chapter, gives the fruit a big thumbs up. Have you ever tried it?

Barry Pang, part owner of winning horse Fiorente, our Tracee Hutchison, and the Melbourne Cup!

Watch Tracee's profile of Barry Pang: http://ab.co/1ee4v2M

The stage is set for the 153rd running of the world's richest handicap, the $6.2 million Melbourne Cup. Who will be victorious?

We've got everything you need to know about this year's race right here: http://ab.co/1gjYxya

Hong Kong born fashion student Cathy Yuen has her sights on some of the world's biggest catwalks: Paris, London, New York... and Flemington racetrack. That's where budding fashionistas get their chance to shine at Australia's premier horse race, the Melbourne Cup.

Okay, that's our best caption for this photo. Can you top it? (It's not too hard!) Tell us what you think is happening here in the comments.

Photo submitted by ABC audience member Dana Cameron.

It's the race that stops the nation - but does it stop the rest of the world? Or maybe slow it down? Join our Melbourne Cup celebrations this Tuesday, November 5.

Are you having a special lunch? A party? Dressing up with hats? Picking a horse?

If that's you, we'd love to see it. Post your photos right here on our Facebook page. You might even get featured!

Do you have a tattoo? Do you love it or regret it?  

Well, there may be a new reason to be wary of getting inked. An ABC investigation has found that a number of tattoo inks being sold in Australia contain toxins, including potential carcinogens. More: http://ab.co/1aJQHIr

Every week, women from all around the world gather in a small kitchen in Australia. They all speak different languages but have one thing in common: they love to cook.  

That love is translated into wider conversations - on medical issues, legal issues, home life, and parenting.

Read more: http://ab.co/H3iYjL

After 25 years, the Shanghai Quartet has returned to perform in Australia. Take a look into the creative process and internal interactions between the members of the quartet, as they rehearse for their Australian performances.

After 16 months of rehabilitation in Queensland, Phillip the turtle was released back into the sea. Hundreds gathered to wish him well.

Phillip was found close to death floating off an island in June last year.

This is what harmony, love and life look like for one child. What do they look like for you? 

An Australian businessman has published a calendar of poems and drawings to promote cross cultural understanding between Australia and Asia. More: http://ab.co/1h4ocw1

(Thanks to Anthony Chiminello for supplying the image!)

Happy Diwali! Here's a Diwali-themed horse carriage on Melbourne's Swanston Street.

On behalf of all of us at Radio Australia (and the carriage's driver Jesse Whittaker), our very very best wishes to you and your family.
Over the years, more and more people in Australia have been celebrating Halloween - and not everyone thinks that's a great thing! Is Halloween celebrated where you live? What's your opinion on it?

Are you scared of snakes? 

We've got deadly species in our region that would put fear into any intelligent person. Tune into Radio Australia now to hear how our fear of snakes has developed over the generations.  http://bit.ly/HBiyfP
Lia Tabrah turns the frightening into fashion with jewellery inspired by crocodiles, cane toads and much, much more. Be warned - it's not for the faint-hearted!

A crew from Beijing TV hit the streets of Melbourne to film some of the city's hottest unsigned music acts. Photographer Xaio Peng and Director Gao Xi weave their magic in a famous Melbourne laneway with artist N'fa Jones

Vietnamese activist Dinh Nhat Uy and supporters celebrate after his release from custody. Mr Uy was convicted of using Facebook to spread criticism of the government, but the court suspended his 15-month sentence. 

Mr Uy had posted messages on Facebook critical of the treatment of his brother who in June was sentenced to eight years in prison, reduced to four years on appeal, for anti-government propaganda.

More: http://bit.ly/1aALwdE
Jordie Lane has an absolutely incredible voice and an undeniable ability to craft a great song. He knocked us all over when he stopped by earlier today. Here he performs the song 'Lost in You'.

After the end of the Vietnam War over a million South Vietnamese fled their country, piling onto small fishing boats, and set out on the South China Sea in search of safety. 

Many of them made it to countries like Australia, but the UN estimates that over 200,000 Vietnamese asylum seekers were lost at sea.

The Vietnamese Community Association has now unveiled a monument in Perth to remember those who died, as well as celebrating the welcome they got in Australia. More: http://ab.co/1hoW3gZ

Love it or hate it, iconic Australian spread Vegemite turned 90 years old this week. 

Have you ever tried it? And if you're a fan, what's your favourite way to eat it?  More: http://ab.co/HkFepd

Do you have a favourite bird? The kookaburra? Or maybe the galah? It's National Birding Week in Australia. Time to put a bird on it!

Australia has about 800 species of birds. Find out more here: http://ab.co/1eOSDSo

(Photo by Lorrain Phelan)

Buskers in Australia might be different from the buskers that you would typically see in Asian countries. Buskers in Australia are considered street performers and they have to pass through an audition process to get there. Watch this video to find out more about buskers in Australia.

Read more in English: http://bit.ly/Hb1jqU
More in Khmer: http://bit.ly/19tBYBL
                         http://bit.ly/1gDEtrJ
                         http://bit.ly/17JULG7
link_name: Thousands protest in Cambodia over July's election

status_message:
Charmaine Scotty is only the second woman to be elected to parliament in Nauru since independence in 1968.  She was disillusioned with politics and decided to run for parliament because she believes there is no reason she can't do a better job than the men. 

She's at the 12th Triennial Conference of Pacific Women in the Cook Islands this week, and is hoping to inspire young females to be leaders in all areas of life.  Hear her interview with Heather Jarvis: http://bit.ly/1aeFK35

There's gold in them thar trees! Geoscientists in Perth have discovered gold particles in the leaves, twigs and bark of eucalyptus trees, claiming a "eureka" moment which could revolutionise gold mining.  But is it a good thing?

Full story: http://bit.ly/1a6lKBw

Israel Folau fans, don't miss Pacific Sport 360 on Australia Network tomorrow (Thursday) night! The rugby superstar will be interviewed by #PS360 host Jay Laga'aia and sporting stars Mo'onia Gerrard and Nigel Vagana. 

http://bit.ly/13BCZWJ

Hot and tough backburning work facing the brave firefighters in the Blue Mountains of New South Wales. 

Crews are working to gain the upper hand on several blazes burning across New South Wales, amid warnings tomorrow's weather could be more dangerous than first thought.

Photo by 702 ABC Sydney's John Donegan.

Jamayza Adeang is a volunteer with the Pacific Youth Council in Nauru, and also a member of the Pacific Young Women's Youth Alliance.  She says she is involved in leadership because she wants to teach her people, especially young girls, about standing up for their rights.

Heather Jarvis is at the 12th Triennial Pacific Conference of Pacific Women. Read more here: http://bit.ly/184lvAk

Malaysian Opposition Leader Anwar Ibrahim speaks with the ABC's Waleed Aly.  He was in Adelaide recently to talk about the dispute around his country's recent election results and the campaign for democratic reform. 

Watch the full interview: http://youtu.be/yyEo_oyPNE8

Eid at Jama Masjid, the principal mosque of Delhi. Natty Singh shared this photo with Radio Australia - My World

What's happening where you live? Share your world with the rest of the world. Upload your photo on the My World Facebook page or on Instagram with #ramyworld

Happy birthday Sydney Opera House! It's been 40 years since Queen Elizabeth II declared the iconic building officially open. Have you visited?

Read more about the history here: http://ab.co/1fMg9m3

(Photo from ABC Archives)
A man lies in a park in Maldives, underneath a selection of flags representing opposition parties. The country will head to the polls in presidential elections today.

Perth-born chanteuse Tanya-Lee Davies has just recorded a new album under the moniker of Superdarling. She brought in bass player Pat Quinn and recorded this track for you live in studio at ABC Radio Australia.

"Bushfires again - this photo doesn't do it justice but the sky looks like the Apocolypse is coming and the sun is a flaming red ball." 

Thanks to @undercover_ewok for this picture of the bushfires in New South Wales, Australia with #ramyworld on Instagram. Thousands of New South Wales residents are dealing with scenes of "utter devastation" as dozens of bushfires continue to burn out of control across the state. More: http://ab.co/19NVSGD

The Mother Goddess Durga in Kolkata, where she is a central part of celebrations during Navratri, a nine-day Hindu festival celebrating the feminine form of the divine.

Thanks to Santanu Datta for sharing this picture with Radio Australia - My World. What's happening where you live? #ramyworld

Einey Smallridge, Sam Jones, Kylie Deane, Jessamie Walsh, Jess Scott and Jackie Scott create history as the first all-woman group of jockeys competing in this year's Landor Cup, a 92-year-old horse race in Western Australia.

More: http://ab.co/1as6M54

Have you ever had a wildlife emergency?

Here are Wildlife Victoria volunteers Ella Rowntree and Geoffrey Fuller with the kangaroo they captured in a chemist inside a Melbourne Airport terminal this morning. 

Photo via 774 ABC Melbourne

Fashion and faith go hand in hand in an exhibition now at Melbourne's Immigration Museum.  

Tasneem Chopra is the curator. She spoke about celebrating the diversity of Islamic dressing, from an Australian perspective: http://bit.ly/16957UR

(Photo courtesy of Museums Victoria)

Dancers perform in Pohnpei, Micronesia while a hopeful protege dreams of joining them one day. thanks to Bill Jaynes for sharing this photo with Radio Australia - My World.

What's happening where you live? #ramyworld

Have you ever met a clown doctor? They work in hospitals across Australia to inject humour into the lives of sick children and patients in palliative care.

Read more about them: http://bit.ly/1gEwNmE

Who stole the chickens?

Around 300 chooks from the Nuriootpa High School in South Australia were taken by thieves who cut their way into a shed at the High School. The hens are a part of the school agricultural study program, and the students are reportedly very disappointed.  Full story: http://ab.co/19IyojX

Đỗ Quốc shared this gorgeous photo of students on their way to school during a period of seasonal high water in Vietnam. Thanks!

What's happening where you live? We'd love to see it. Share your world with the rest of the world on Radio Australia - My World or on Instagram with #ramyworld

Congratulations to Vance Joy! He won two awards at this year's Australian Independent Music Awards – Breakthrough Independent Artist and Best Independent Single/EP. 

We were so proud to have him perform for us a couple of months ago. Check it out!

Based on Puccini's opera Madame Butterfly, Cho Cho is a cross cultural collaboration between Chinese and Australian producers and actors. 

It's a bilingual drama that combines puppetry, poetry, drama and music as it explores the cultural differences which exist among people from different lands. More: http://bit.ly/GWlgBZ
link_name: Cho Cho - Chinese and Australian theatre comes together

status_message:
Happy Monday! Start your week off with a challenge - do you know what game is being played in this picture? 

(Photo: Lucie Bell)

Yohan Goutt Gonsalves wants to become the first person to represent East Timor in the Winter Olympics, and he's hoping that training in Australia will help get him there. 

Read his story: http://ab.co/19hrbex

What's the biggest problem in a 3,000 km solar car race? Toilet breaks. 

The solar-powered car, Tokai Challenger from Japan's Tokai University enters Alice Springs in the Northern Territory during the 3000km World Solar Challenge from Darwin to Adelaide. http://bit.ly/1hGbRt5

Photo by Ann Jones

Everyone knows that a good song can really change your mood. But music can actually be more effective than anti-anxiety or pain relief drugs and can help recovery from severe brain trauma. 

It's fascinating. Read more about it: http://ab.co/1c6j0Ci

Today is International Day of the Girl Child. This year, the focus is on education.

What advice would you give a young girl today?

Thanks to Bethany Keats for the photo.
More live Australian music coming your way. Meet Miss Eileen & King Lear - brother and sister duo from Melbourne whose sweet harmonies and folk/country music make this a mighty fine family affair.

status_message:
A platypus that hitched a 15-kilometre ride wedged inside a car engine has been released back into a Canberra creek.

Remarkably, the female - now nicknamed Hilux - was uninjured. Read more: http://ab.co/1bIiwpk

Could you live without money? 

Mark Boyle, a man who 5 years ago decided to live without money, is surviving and thriving. He has plans for a new venture and he just got engaged. His story: http://ab.co/17f3Lma

Photo by Jose Lasheras

Children take a look at some of the debris in the flooded Sangkae River in Battambang, north west Cambodia. It's estimated more than 375,000 people have been affected by recent flooding, with over 9,000 homes evacuated. More: http://bit.ly/18IOIEn

Audience photo by Morgan Macdonald.

What's is like to be a young Indian in Australia?

This week #TalkAboutIt is in Sydney, a gorgeous backdrop for some great conversation.

Do you meditate? 

Research shows mindfulness and meditation can be useful for teens and young adults, too, and help deal with anxiety and depression. More: http://ab.co/12ihCuu

Flickr photo by RelaxingMusic.

What's different about this photo? 

There are not 2, but 3 teams on the field playing Australian Rules Football. Confused? Find out more from the woman behind the idea on Radio Australia this morning at 10:20am Sydney time.

Listen live here: http://bit.ly/HBiyfP

High school students on their way to school in Gant Gaw township, Myanmar. Due to heavy rain and mud, they had to take their shoes off to walk. 

Thanks to Phoe Khwar Pwl for sharing this photo with Radio Australia - My World What's happening where you live?

Bollywood superstar Shahrukh Khan talks about Bollywood and cricket with #TalkAboutIt, before offering Del Irani a few tips on those famous hip-shaking moves.

Shah Rukh Khan #TalkAboutIt #Bollywood — with Del Irani - Presenter, Australia Network & ABC News and Shah Rukh Khan at Paramasala.

status_message:
Can you guess what this is? Give us your best guesses below. We'll let you know what it is before too long!

Audience photo by Paul Freeman.

Meet Peter Barnes - the only mechanic in Birdsville, home to one of the biggest racing carnivals in Outback Australia. Every year the town grows from 180 to almost 8,000 people who travel thousands of kilometres to be there! 

So what happens when your car breaks down out in the middle of nowhere? You call Peter. He's rescued hundreds of travellers since 1984.

Seda, Chhieng, Sovathara & Vymala from our Khmer service celebrating Pchum Ben - Ancestors' Day.

Did you know we have a Radio Australia - Khmer facebook page?

Watch out for that monster! Australian puppeteers and Indonesian artists collaborate on the production 'Wedhus Gembel.' 

It's a story about a young couple trying to have a child, but when they are blessed with one from a sacred mountain, it turns into a monster and gobbles up all the villagers. More: http://ab.co/18xxzNK

(Photo via Snuff Puppets)

Pallavi Sharda is on the brink of Bollywood stardom, and she's also the pride of Melbourne! She's playing the female lead in one of the biggest Bollywood productions of the year, a Hindi film called Besharam. 

Read more about how she got to the screens in the world's biggest film industry: http://ab.co/1dVIYcp

(Twitter photo by @pallavisharda)

Chinese officials are warning Chinese tourists not to pick their noses or urinate in pools as part of a guidebook on do's and don't on travelling.

It also dictates visitors in Germany should only snap their fingers to beckon dogs, and that ladies in Spain should always wear earrings in public, or be considered naked. What advice would you give tourists? 

Full story: http://bit.ly/GzOEwI

Can you bring art and culture back from the brink of extinction? Chief Jerry Taki Uminduru and the people of Vanuatu's Erromango Island say 'yes.'

A collection of traditional and modern artworks from the island will be displayed in Cologne, Germany, as part of the largest exhibition of Pacific bark painting ever staged. Full story : http://bit.ly/1fHPt6W

Happy Batik Day! 

Marcus Tantau is an Australian who loves collecting Batik shirts from Indonesia. He has more than 15!

He says, "I like wearing Batik. Every time I wear it, it brings my memories back to Indonesia where I met good friends, ate good food, and learned great cultures."

This photo was taken when he was volunteering as teacher at an elementary school in West Java.

Life can be beautiful. Two humpback whales breach in waters off Queensland's Gold Coast. 

Audience submitted photo by Steve Woodfine

We promise this hasn't been digitally altered!

 ABC Open contributor Margaret Wong snapped this great picture during a recent workshop. Find out how she did it: http://bit.ly/19ROmZU

Julia Gillard gives her first in-depth interview since leaving office, with Anne Summers Reports. What would you ask her?

Tune in to hear it tonight at 6:30pm AEST / 8:30am UTC: http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/international/listen


(Photo: Sophie Deane / Museum of Australian Democracy collection)

Adelaide comes to life at night during OzAsia, a festival celebrating the connection between Australia and Asia. 

Thanks to Daniel Taylor for sharing this photo with #ramyworld. What's happening where you live?

Would you be a foster parent to a bat?

That's what conservationists in Queensland are asking people to do. But before you get up close and cuddly, you need to be vaccinated against Australian bat lyssavirus, a rabies-like disease that has killed three people. More: http://bit.ly/19hLXH5

Caption challenge! What do you think is happening in this photo?

(Image from ABC Open contributor camwow15)

Then and now -  Sydney Central Station in 1946 and present day. 

Thanks to ABC Open contributor Street Photos1 for this little gem.
About 90,000 people turned out for the traditional parade in Melbourne's CBD in sunny but cool conditions. More: http://bit.ly/1bg1VJj

This weekend, Melbourne is transformed into a sport lover's paradise as the Australian Football League Grand Final. How well do you know your Aussie Rules? Amanda Shalala from ABC Grandstand gives a snapshot of the AFL in 90 seconds.

Do you know the viola? It looks like a slightly larger violin. 

Katie Yap will join 105 fellow Australian classical musicians in the Australian World Orchestra under the baton of Zubin Mehta when she performs at the Sydney Opera House and in Melbourne next month. She treated Radio Australia to a live performance of the first movement of Telemann's Fantasia no. 10. Ordinarily, in the key of D major, Katie transposed this piece for viola, so here it's in G major.
link_name: Kate Yap - Live at Radio Australia

status_message:
By next year, Asia will have the most millionaires in the world.

A new report from Royal Bank of Canada says the wealth of the region's millionaires will grow by an annual average of nearly 10 per cent and reach about $US16 trillion in 2015, fuelled by strong growth in the region and high savings rates.  More: http://bit.ly/1b8Po6X

Children dress up in traditional wedding clothing as part of a cultural parade in Java, Indonesia. Thanks to Pratiwi Rahayu fro sharing this with Radio Australia - My World.

What does it look like where you live? Share your world with the rest of the world. #ramyworld
Designers from around the world come together to show off their fashions. Take a closer look at this World Fashion Runway, part of Melbourne Spring Fashion Week.

Xiao Xiong Zhang is one of the Cambodia's most celebrated performers. His life story is shaped by wars, revolutions and developmental difficulties as he was growing up.
 
His life story is the basis of a new performance which premiered at the OzAsia festival in Adelaide, Australia. Hear the full interview: http://bit.ly/1bdFpkc
Fourteen baby pandas have made their debut in China. Fourteen baby pandas in one crib. Cuteness overload? Watch the video here: http://bit.ly/15Srhsp

Do you know how kimchi is made? The national dish of Korea is delicious, but so smelly that many Koreans keep it in a separate fridge!

Korean master chef Chung Jae Lee lets RN Drive in on the kimchi secret as part of OzAsia Festival in Adelaide. More: http://bit.ly/1fwDc2G

She's a little bit country, he's a little bit rock and roll.

Australian Country music chanteuse Sherry Rich and Australia's premier rock guitarist Ash Naylor record under the name of 'The Grapes'.

They've just released their second album 'Western Sun', and popped into our studios to play a track live, especially for you. The song's called 'Lily Darling' , a beautiful ode to Ash Naylor' young daughter.
link_name: The Grapes - Live at Radio Australia

status_message:
Sixty per cent of Queensland is officially in drought. Prayers for rain were held last month on a drought-affected property near Charleville in south-west Queensland. Thanks to Lynda Worrell for sharing this photo. 

More pictures here: http://bit.ly/15O58eJ

Nevermind the digital age, vinyl is back! In Australia vinyl album sales increased by more than 70 per cent last year. Do you buy vinyl? How do you listen to music?

Full story: http://bit.ly/1b6aAxF

Indonesia - What do you think needs to change in Indonesian football? #TalkAboutIt

Your country has the same talent pool as Brazil but has failed to qualify for the World Cup since 1938.

Share your thoughts/comments below.

This neighbourhood is really going to the... kangaroos?  

What's the strangest thing you've ever seen near your home? ABC Open's Brad Marsellos took this photo in Woodgate, Western Queensland, where kangaroos are everywhere... Even at the beach!

Tall ships from around Australia and as far away as England have gathered in Hobart for a five-day festival.

The ships will be docked in Hobart until September 25 and will then head to Sydney for the Australian Navy's centenary celebrations.

Getting every last drop out of that watering can. Despite a dry winter, Toowoomba, Queensland, is in full bloom for the annual Carnival of Flowers. No wonder they call it Australia's Garden City!

More photos here: http://bit.ly/15Nx3LS

A happy story, to start your weekend. 

This lucky "swamp wallaby" baby (called a joey) was rescued from a creek near Byron Bay, where it was swimming to escape from two dogs.

A local tourist pulled him from the water and blew into his little mouth and gave CPR. The joey was revived and is now recovering in a wildlife rescue centre.

Read more: http://bit.ly/14oSQbB

Australian graffiti artist Dash88 finds inspiration in his Malay-Chinese heritage and his international upbringing for his artwork. 

Dash88 is creating street art as part of the OzAsia Festival in Adelaide this month.

Hear more: http://bit.ly/1drmDDd

Photo by Jennie Lenman.

An inflatable kangaroo stands outside a McDonald's restaurant in Chicago.

Residents in a small town in regional Australia have been fighting the development of the fast-food restaurant in their area.  They have taken their fight to Chicago, but it might be too late.

Will they win their battle, what happens if they lose, and what does McDonald's say about the protests and development?

Find out: http://bit.ly/18wrvYi

A love story set during the fallout of East Timor's independence struggle with Indonesia is the backdrop for the country's first feature film. 'A Guerra Da Beatriz' is set to premiere in Dili tonight and is the first movie filmed and produced in East Timor. 

More pics and full story: http://bit.ly/187VFgL

In Australia we love pets. We love them so much that Australian's are second only to the US for the number of pets in the country.

Losing a pet can be just as painful as losing a family member :(

So we are celebrating past and present pets of the Radio Australia family :)
A collection of the world's most ugly animals as voted by online supports of the Ugly Animal Preservation Society. Which do you think is the ugliest?

Some of the biggest names in the music industry have recognized her talent, and now Australian audiences will get a taste of Malaysian born, LA-based singer Yuna, when she performs at the OzAsia Festival in Adelaide next week.

Yuna told our Asia Pacific program that she stumbled into her musical career after training as a lawyer! http://bit.ly/1g2yPK3
Colourful umbrellas brighten up a Melbourne shopping centre, and signal the arrival of spring! Thanks to Seb Ian for the photo.
There's just something special about a real letter. Here are Cheri and Mu from Radio Australia - Myanmar, and the 106 letters they received from Myanmar last week!

At Radio Australia we love live music!

The Tealeaves dropped into the RA studio to perform one of their new songs, 'Wake Me When It's Over', off their new album 'No More Can You Be Here'
Yeojin Bae is one of Australia's hottest designers. Her clothes mix elegance with a bit of edge. We take a closer look at her spring collection.
link_name: Yeojin Bae at Melbourne Spring Fashion Week

status_message:
Are you addicted to the internet?  #TalkAboutIt

It's been reported that around 13 million Australians spend up to 19 hours a day online. How about you?

Would allowing the public to carry weapons curb gun crime?

David Leyonhjelm from the Liberal Democrats is one of the handful of newly-elected Australian Senators that will represent minor parties. He says allowing people to carry weapons is one way of curbing gun crime in western Sydney.  More: http://bit.ly/1cWw2lY
Here it is! Alana Conway - Singer and harpist performs 'Songbird' live at ABC Radio Australia.

Now back to the elections in Cambodia - yesterday, the election commission announced the ruling party of Prime Minister Hun Sen won. But the opposition continues to disagree. Is it time for an independent investigation? We interview Mu Sochua, Opposition CNRP MP: http://bit.ly/17QlRMF
Alana Conway - Singer and harpist will join Phil for a live performance this morning. A bit of relaxation after an election filled weekend! Tune in here: http://bit.ly/GQ1iXR

Gentlemen, which style suits you best?

For the first time, Melbourne Spring Fashion Week dedicates an entire evening to men's fashion.

"I now look forward to forming a government that is competent, that is trustworthy, and which purposefully and steadfastly and methodically sets about delivering on our commitments to you, the Australian people. 

"Something very significant has happened today. Today, the people of Australia have declared that the right to govern this country does not belong to Mr Rudd or to me or to his party or to ours; but it belongs to you, the people of Australia."
   - Tony Abbott, the next Prime Minister of Australia.
Voting in the election is serious business. All the more reason for a little sweet reward at the end!

Polls are now closed in the eastern states of Australia. We're expecting to see the first trends in voting within the hour. 

Can't wait that long? Watch the seats get filled in real time here: http://bit.ly/1eopr5n
Kevin Rudd and Tony Abbott cast their ballots today. As voting starts to wrap up across the country, Australians now wait for election results to start coming in.

"This country, which can manage its political differences peacefully and conduct the most vigorous of debates peacefully and resolve our politics peacefully and with civility, that is why this country is such a great country. 

"And that in this marvellous tapestry of modern Australia, the mosaic of our multicultural nation that which fashions such unity out of diversity, therein lies the great Australian miracle. Which is why we are all proud to be Australian."
  - Kevin Rudd, conceding defeat

The ABC's Election Analyst, Antony Green, has called the 2013 Australian Federal Election for the Coalition - the LNP. Kevin Rudd's Labor government has fallen

What does this mean for you? Do you think Australia's new government will have a different relationship with your home country?

Does voting make you hungry?

If you're an Australian, chances are the answer is 'yes'. Grabbing a quick snag (that's a 'sausage' in Australian) after casting your ballot is a much loved tradition. And it helps support community organisations, too.

More of what you need to know (but never knew to ask) about voting in Australia: http://bit.ly/15Dfiko
Indigenous Fashion Unearthed blends fashion with culture and tradition as part of Melbourne Spring Fashion Week

Do you know what a donkey vote is?

Australia has preferential voting. We number candidates in order of preference. A donkey vote is when you just number the candidates 1-4 from top to bottom. It looks a bit strange but it's still a valid vote! 

More of what you need to know about voting in Australia here: http://bit.ly/15Dfiko
Australians head to the polls today in the federal election. So what's it really all about? Can you sum it up in 90 seconds? We give it our best shot.

Thief? Vandal? Nope! He's an artist! 

A street artist climbs a wall in Rutledge Lane, a well-known street art location in Melbourne. 

Photo by Keith O'Brien

The cultures are ancient, but the fashion is red hot. Pawi Wynyard and Tracey Brown from Maori design label Te Whare A Rangi talk about their collection for Indigenous Fashion Unearthed at Melbourne Spring Fashion Week. Which outfit is your favourite?
Beautiful weather for Melbourne Spring Fashion Week has seen the style conscious move into their spring wardrobe with winter boots being banished to the back of the cupboard.

Cooking oil made out of foxes?

Sixteen people have gone on trial in China accused of a scam which saw waste from animal parts of chickens, ducks, pigs, cattle and foxes used to make cooking oil.

It is the latest case to highlight poor food safety standards in China, a growing source of anger for many. More: http://bit.ly/1ahdkb9

Comfort or style? 

Melbourne's fashion set are dressed to impress this week with strappy high heel sandals making their first appearance of the season. Watch some of the highlights of MSFW and let us know if you dress for style, or comfort?

You might love weddings, but do you love them enough to watch them 24 hours a day? 

If the answer is yes, and you live in India - good news! A 24-hour wedding television channel is headed your way. Would you watch it?

The world famous Harlem Globetrotters dropped into the Radio Australia studio to show our producer Artan Jama how professionals handle a ball...now we know why the first Globetrotter is named Handles, but we still don't know why the other one is named Moose?!

Is fashion important to you?

Melbourne Spring Fashion Week has come to Radio Australia's hometown and fashionable locals are enjoying the opportunity to dress to impress.  This picture is of Grace Scriva who was outside the MSFW Hub in the city centre. 

Keep a look out on Radio Australia's FB page this week for more MSFW pics.

In Australia, today is also the first day of spring and National Wattle Day. The Wattle is our national floral emblem. 
Here's how to celebrate:
1. Wear a sprig of wattle or Australia's colours of green and gold, 2. greet each other with "Happy Wattle Day!"
3. Have a picnic

Happy Wattle Day!

Photo by Vera Rayson.
Happy Father's Day! What's the thing you love most about your dad?

From Banks, NSW to Swan, WA - view photo essays profiling some of the federal electorates from around Australia. 

ABC News | http://bit.ly/16UtEpX

What role should Australia play in the world? Should we give more money in foreign aid? Do we already give too much?

Tune in to Radio Australia at 7:30am AEST / 9:30pm UTC to hear
a discussion on foreign policy and the Australian election.

Beware! It's magpie swooping season in Australia, a time when the black and white bird becomes very aggressive and can dive and attack! They do it to protect their nests and new baby birds, but it can be quite frightening.

Have you ever had a frightening encounter with an animal?

Flickr photo by Ed Dale

What do Australians really think? 

More than 900,000 Australians have weighed in on ABC's Vote Compass. #TalkAboutIt looks at this exciting new tool, and you too can give it a go at http://abc.net.au/votecompass
link_name: Taking the pulse of the election

Haitham Dawood is one of the many faces of the Australian electorate. He is a refugee from Iraq. He's also a painter who lives in a home built out of old shipping containers. There is a strong focus on the arts and the environment where he lives.

More faces and stories of Australian voters here: http://bit.ly/19OhKTb

Food fight! Thousands of revellers are seeing red after the annual tomatina fight in Spain. 130 tonnes of tomatoes thrown in one hour.

More: http://bit.ly/16S6q7x

Robots are becoming smarter and smarter. Is it time to give them rights, too? 

More: http://bit.ly/19Y10MT

Good morning! 

The sun rising over ski slopes at Mt Buller in Victoria's high country last weekend.

Photo by Tim Byrne

Just over a week before Australia heads to the polls, Prime Minister Kevin Rudd and Opposition Leader Tony Abbott will meet tonight for the third leaders' debate, this time in western Sydney. 

Watch coverage right now, wherever you are: bit.ly/abcnews24

Or tune in online from 8:30am UTC / 6:30pm AEST: http://bit.ly/GQ1iXR

Do you sleep as soundly as this little guy? Apparently, how well you sleep can also be determined where you were born. Find out more about the impact of culture on sleep: http://bit.ly/1doQFuP

Flickr photo by Paulo Ordoveza

Where do you feel at home?

Christopher Burchett left the UK to find a new home in the Indian city of Varanasi, traditionally a destination for Hindu pilgrims.

He's one of many foreigners putting down new roots in the city. More: http://bit.ly/1ffL6KN

More than 1000 people march through Brisbane during the Rally for the Reef protest highlighting the threat mining places on the Great Barrier Reef. 

Photo by David Lowe

Is captivity making the Tasmanian devil dumber?

Marissa Parrott of Zoos Victoria says many animals become less intelligent when bred in captivity, owing to "a brain size reduction" of up to a third in such animals as pigs and horses.

Full story: http://bit.ly/1dgJJ1Y

A dancer performs at the ASEAN Australia Youth Summit 2013. 

The summit was held over the weekend to bring together student leaders from the ASEAN countries and Australia for a discussion on issues affecting the ASEAN region and Australia.

Melbourne is famous for its graffiti-covered laneways. But for 45 minutes yesterday, one lane was given a makeover. 

Artist Adrian Doyle used 150 litres of what he calls "empty-nursery blue" paint to complete the project, which he says represents his past. Full story: http://bit.ly/12CCzPq

(Photo supplied by Adrian Doyle)

Have you ever had social media regret? According to a new survey one in four young adults have posted something they wish they hadn't.

So how do you fix it? And what are the consequences? Find out on #TalkAboutIt: http://youtu.be/ejU9U7TWtEQ

Flickr photo by Sarebear:)

Australian musician Sophie Koh is on her first tour of China, connecting with her fans and her roots there. She's sharing a photo blog of her journey with us here. Join her as she takes an adventure of discovery.

status_message:
It's the 'Month of the Hungry Ghosts'! A time when many Chinese communities mark a large traffic of 'mischievous spirits' and try to appease them with burnt paper offerings. 

But all the spirits haven't scared away the tourists, as interest in the festival is growing. Full story here: http://bit.ly/177crvL

A Labor election board is spotted in Hong Kong. The city is the second largest overseas booth for the Australian election after London. 

Photo from ABC reporter Andrew Greene's twitter.

A teacher at Carisbrook Primary School, north-east of Melbourne, rides a miniature bicycle and entertains young students.

Photo by Andrew Lighten

Have you ever experienced racism in your country?

This week Australia Network's  #TalkAboutIt tackles that issue, as well as social media faux pas and voting in the Australian election.

Here's a sneak peak of this Thursday's show with host Del Irani - Presenter, Australia Network & ABC News

See broadcast schedule for your region at: http://bit.ly/13H5Md3

This morning AM (ABC Radio) met Victor Lee. He's a resident of Logan, Queensland, and came to Australia as a refugee from Cambodia.

"My journey's quite long. I left Cambodia when I was about 16. We had to walk overnight across the jungle between Thai-Cambodian border. And then, yeah, it was quite a risky journey there. We could have been shot down by Thai army while trying to get into a refugee camp.

I believe Australia can take double the number of refugees if assessed properly because we are a rich country, we can help them."

For more on this story head to the AM website: http://www.abc.net.au/am/content/2013/s3830226.htm

Meet Max the dog. When Ying Ying arrived to start a new life in Sydney from Hong Kong she never imagined a stray dog would become one of her closest friends and teach her the true meaning of life.

Have you ever head a close relationship with an animal?

Hear more about Max and Ying Ying's friendship: http://bit.ly/14Z2xjZ

Students at Queensland's University of the Sunshine Coast share their lunch break with a laid-back mob of kangaroos. 

Photo by Jo Joyce.

Do you like music? 

Coming up on-air Phil Kafcaloudes will look at some of life's more peculiar instruments. He'll be making music with spoons, a wobble board and may even whistle the programs opening theme. 

Australia's Uncle Herb Patten thinks music makes the world go round and has been making music out of gum leaves for 60 years:

How far would you go to send yourself or your children to Australia to study? 

Australia is now the most expensive country in the world for international studies, according to HSBC. 

Neal Wang's parents sold a house to send Neal to study Commercial Cookery in Australia. Read the full story here: http://bit.ly/16Ykz1L

How is Australian multiculturalism different from other places around the world?

Compared with the UK, France and Germany, Australia has a record that is largely unblemished by ethnic tensions, violence and ghettoes. Is this because in Australia, immigrants are invited and indeed expected to become citizens of the nation?

More: http://bit.ly/1aWqcUg

People have been brewing beer at home for millennia, but what did it taste like way back then?

The University of Chicago's Oriental Institute has teamed up with a micro-brewery to recreate an ancient recipe drawn from a hymn to a Sumerian goddess scribed on a 4,000-year-old clay tablet.

More: http://bit.ly/1bNYjdO

The last apple on the tree - 750,000 fruit trees were torn up and burnt after a cannery in the Australian state of Victoria decided not to renew contracts for fruit supply this year.

The trees have to be torn out to prevent disease from rotting fruit and unsprayed orchards spreading to neighbouring orchards. Growers are devastated.

More: http://bit.ly/16s33GA

Is there footy where you live?

The Australian Football Asian Championships were held this weekend. The Hong Kong Dragons beat the Philippine Eagles for the title.

Full story: http://bit.ly/14agJ6W

What's your game? Join in Radio Australia - My World's latest photo challenge. 

It could be a sport, a board game, something you play on your computer, or more. Share your world with the rest of the world by uploading your photo here or on Instagram with #ramyworld. Don't forget to say where you are!

Good morning! A rowing crew approaches the Victoria Bridge during a training session on the Brisbane River in the pre-dawn.

Photo by Errol Ruddy

A new study says singing can help you learn a foreign language.

Have you ever tried it? We'd love to know what you've learned from  singing.

Full story: http://bit.ly/1cR8aCQ
YouTube sensation Keenan Cahill was on air this morning and Phil Kafcaloudes challenged him to a bit of a lip sync battle to Keenan's song 'Hands Up'. Who do you think came out on top?

status_message:
Canadian Ronnie Burkett is a world-renowned master of marionettes. He'll be chatting with Phil Kafcaloudes tomorrow about his beautifully dark apocalyptic comedy, Penny Plain.

What would you like to ask him?
YouTube sensation Keenan Cahill will join Radio Australia's Morning program tomorrow. Catch him performing live for a video recording with Phil Kafcaloudes!

One Australian school class has decided to buddy up with an Indonesian school so they can learn more about each other. So how did it work? 

We visit both schools to find out: http://bit.ly/1cvE8W0

Grant Hanrahan competes in the rope and tie event at the Mt Isa Rodeo in north-west Queensland. Hanrahan won the event with runs of 11.95 seconds and a final round run of 9.80 seconds for a total time of 21.85 secs.

Photo by Stephen Mowbray

There is hope new pictorial dictionaries will help preserve Indigenous languages in outback Queensland.  The dictionaries will be rolled out to local schools and libraries.

What's your favourite way to learn a language?

Thanks to Nedia Guswina (@nedya22) for sharing this with #ramyworld on Instagram. 

Radio Australia - My World has a new photo challenge - My Game.

What's your favourite game? It could be a sport, a board game, something you play on your computer, or more. Share your world with the rest of the world. Don't forget to tell us where you are!

Tonight, Australia's Minister for Immigration Tony Burke and Shadow Minister Scott Morrison debate their party policies on people who come to Australia via boat to seek asylum.

You can hear the debate online from about 7:45pm AEST / 9:45am UTC: http://bit.ly/GQ1iXR  

What do you want to hear them talk about?

Can you handle the truth?

ABC Fact Check gets behind the spin and determines the accuracy of claims by politicians, public figures, advocacy groups and institutions engaged in the public debate. www.bit.ly/167CRhR

Happy National Science Week! All week, Dr Karl is sharing great moments in science. Today, do you know what dark energy is?

"You might have come across the concept that the universe is expanding," says Dr Karl.

"What dark energy does is make the expansion accelerate." 

Find out more about the science of 'dark energy'.

ABC Science | http://bit.ly/1cwk6KY

What does multiculturalism mean?

The word first entered Australia's vocabulary in 1973 and has been a subject of strong debate ever since. Has multiculturalism made us a better country—or brought out the worst in us? Mongrel Nation takes a closer look: http://bit.ly/1d9kJoI

The morning glory cloud forms over Sweers Island in the Gulf of Carpentaria, Queensland. 

The rare formation occurs every year, but came much earlier this year. Locals say they usually aren't seen until mid-September.

Photo by Sarah Martin

Fijian visual artists Ben Fong and Ledua Peni are in Melbourne to explore new ways to share their stories with printmaking. 

The artworks feature in 'First Editions', an exhibition showcasing a selection of linocuts from 9 Fijian artists made during the inaugural Australian Print Workshop Collaboration with the Oceania Centre for Arts and Culture in Suva. 

The exhibition runs until September 24.
link_name: Fijian visual artists Ben Fong and Ledua Peni

status_message: The Wikileaks Party hopes to win three seats in the Senate at this Australian election. Julian Assange is campaigning for one of the seats and says he will fight for government accountability and transparency, all done from the Ecuadorian embassy in London. Do you think his reputation will help or hinder his chances?

Australian musician Sophie Koh is on her first tour of China, connecting with her fans and her roots there. She's sharing a photo blog of her journey with us here. Join her as she takes an adventure of discovery.

Red-necked wallabies forage for grass after a snowfall in the Gudgenby Valley, south of Canberra.

(Photo from ABC Canberra: leo_qbn)

Congratulations to Seaman Dan! He was inducted into the National Indigenous Music Awards' Hall of Fame over the weekend. 

Seaman Dan is a Torres Strait Islander who was born in 1929, but didn't release his first album until the year 2000. He sings a fusion of music from Australia, Melanesia, North America, Africa and Polynesia, most notably the Thursday Island 'hula' style of music.

Hear him perform here: http://bit.ly/13Swbkp

It's cops versus cowboys! Every year the Harts Range police in the Northern Territory challenge local pastoralists to a horse race. They've been running the race since 1947. 

This year the police won - read more: http://bit.ly/16tXRQF
マクイーン時田　深山 Miyama Mcqueen-tokita plays the koto - an incredibly beautiful Japanese instrument. Watch her captivating performance in the ABC Sound Library.

Michael Rowland explains the Australian election in 90 seconds
Australia is going to the polls for the 2013 Federal Election.

Want to know what it's all about? Here's our 10 point guide: http://bit.ly/17ADIpi

status_message:
Meet Miyama McQueen-Tokita. She's a virtuoso of the koto, a Japanese stringed instrument. 

Have you ever heard it? Well, you will tomorrow! She'll joing Phil Kafcaloudes live in the studio tomorrow morning for a chat and a performance, too!

It's showtime! #TalkAboutIt launches on Australia Network tonight.

Join Del Irani - Presenter, Australia Network & ABC News as we discuss the #BurkaAvenger, celebrate the end of #Ramadan and welcome #Eid, and catch up with Malaysian actress, model and busy mum, Wardina Saffiyah.

Tune in 1830 in East Asia, 1730 in Bangkok & Jakarta, 1930 in India or check http://bit.ly/13H5Md3 for local times.

Prayers outside Lakemba mosque in Sydney to mark the end of the holy month of Ramadan.

Roads around the mosque were blocked off to allow the congregation to fill the area.

Families and children left the service with pockets filled with sweets, as is custom at Eid al-Fitr.

More: http://bit.ly/194r8BP

India goes to the polls next year. For the first time, social media is expected to play a big role in the election.

Where do you get your political news from? 
Watch: http://youtu.be/PH_Pgfc8P6k

This week, Phil Kafcaloudes spoke with Dr Stephen McKenzie about mindfulness at work. Being present in the moment is a lot harder than it sounds! What are your tips for slowing down to enjoy life?

Brad Canning (@brradjack) shared this photo with #ramyworld on Instagram. Show us what's happening where you live!

Did you miss the Q&A with Foreign Minister Bob Carr yesterday? He answered four hot questions, posted and voted on by people like you. Read more and watch him talk about asylum seeker policy, arts and cultural diplomacy, helping bring about peace in Sudan, and the Julian Assange case here: http://bit.ly/13FgtfW

Let the debate begin! In just over 30 minutes time, Australia Networkwill be featuring a foreign policy debate between Australian Foreign Minister Sen. Bob Carr and the Deputy Opposition Leader Julie Bishop, LIVE from the Lowy institute in Sydney. A panel of three journalists will ask questions.

The debate will run from 5.45-7pm AEST.

You can watch the live stream of the debate here: http://bit.ly/watchANlive

Ever wonder how you get the news from all across the campaign trail? Journalists sit in the back of PM Kevin Rudd's election campaign C-17 Globemaster in Sydney as they follow the PM around the country.

Follow the day's developments here: http://bit.ly/1ctTR71

Jasmine Rae is one of Australia's leading country music artists.

This year she was awarded America's Country Music Association Global Artist Award....a great achievement!

She popped into the Radio Australia studio today to speak with Phil Kafcaloudes about her new album 'If I Want To'.

Hot rod fans, motorcycle enthusiasts and glamorous rockabilly lovers flocked to Brisbane for the 14th annual Greazefest. 

The Rocklea Showgrounds were packed with bearded bikies, Elvis impersonators and hundreds of vintage bikes and cars.

Photo by Nic MacBean

Australian musician Sophie Koh is on her first tour of China, connecting with her fans and her roots there. She's sharing a photo blog of her journey with us here. Join her as she takes an adventure of discovery.
