status_message:
Ten years ago, Saeid Safavi was in an asylum seeker detention centre in Woomera, South Australia. Now he's a cafe owner who has won the region's barista of the year award for three years straight. 

His story here: http://bit.ly/1cq3yDy

Photo by Eloise Fuss.

India's Supreme Court is calling on the government to improve the conditions of abandoned women in the 'City of Widows', Vrindavan.

An estimated 20,000 widows live there, in little cabins or in charity homes that dot the busy city. Many have fled the social stigma they have had to endure following the death of their husbands.

More: http://bit.ly/17sUl62

Photo by Murali Krishnan

Prime Minister Kevin Rudd has called the Australian federal election for September 7.

Five weeks after he seized the Labor leadership back from Julia Gillard, Mr Rudd announced the date via an email to supporters, beginning with the phrase: "It's on".

"Australians now face a choice. And the choice couldn't be starker," Mr Rudd said in the email message.

More: http://bit.ly/190QzYw

The children are the future. 

Today in Australia, it's National Aboriginal and Islander Children's Day. Talisha Parker is proud of her indigenous ancestry and is one of many children out celebrating her cultural identity.

Talisha is taking the opportunity to call for equality and an end to racism.

Healthy snacks in a vending machine?

A north Queensland banana grower is claiming a first for Australia, installing a vending machine for his fruit in the centre of Brisbane.

More: http://bit.ly/17QoRJo

Want to know more about the music of the Seychelles? 

Grace Barbe is from the small Indian Ocean island and is in Melbourne to perform her Afro-Creole style of music with a 300 voice mass choir. She joins Phil Kafcaloudes tomorrow on Radio Australia Mornings. She's even going to sing for us live!

Starting up a small business can be a daunting prospect.  First you need an idea, and then there's finance, basic business skills and often lots of red tape to deal with.

We talk through some of the issues facing small businesses in the region, from outdated policy to lack of business literacy skills: http://bit.ly/16llJpr

Flickr photo by Ian @thepaperboy.com

Would you eat meat grown in a petri dish?

On Bush Telegraph today we'll hear from a biotechnologist involved in making the first test tube burger. Coming soon to a barbecue near you?

When Julia Powell's pig farm went bust she had one last option to save her bacon - social networking.

She took out a $5 ad on Facebook asking locals to help her reopen a small local abattoir. They've been able to reopen the local abattoir and also build an onsite processing room and a smokehouse. Read more: http://bit.ly/1e9QKNT

Photo by Marty McCarthy

A pelican moves across one of the lakes at the University of Queensland campus in Brisbane. 

Photo by Louise MacMillan.

Do you own a small business? Or would you like to? What's the biggest issue you have with getting started? Or maybe you have some tips to share?

Phil Kafcaloudes and Heather Jarvis will be talking about the issues facing small businesses tomorrow morning and they'd like to hear from you. They'll share as many comments as they can on air, so get talking!

Good news today - the number of Nepal's endangered Royal Bengal tigers has risen 64 per cent to 198 in just four years.

Experts attribute the sharp rise in Royal Bengal tigers in the wilds of Nepal to a crackdown on poaching and a government pledge to double their numbers.  Full story: http://bit.ly/12zyj5F

Photo by Bjørn Christian Tørrissen.

Thousands of new Australian citizens are preparing to cast their vote for the first time in the looming federal election.

In preparation, the Australian Electoral Commission holds regular voter education sessions where new citizens practise how to vote.

For many, the coming election will be the first time they cast a vote that is properly counted. Read more: http://bit.ly/15qckvL

Go, goat, go! Jack Arnold urges Whobegoatyou on during the Old Goats No Glory race at the Barcaldine Goat Expo and Race in Queensland.

Photo by Trevor Howie.

In Cambodia, Hun Sen's ruling party has claimed victory in Sunday's elections. 

The news hit Facebook first. It was posted by Cambodia's Information Minister on his Facebook page. The count was still underway, but the result was soon confirmed by the country's Secretary of State.

The party is likely to have a much reduced majority. The opposition says the election had the kingdom's worst ever poll irregularities, including missing voter names and thousands of people who turned up to find someone else had used their ballot.  

Full story: http://bit.ly/19ruPnO

Australia Network's Auskar Surbakti is currently in Cambodia, reporting on the upcoming elections. He says the atmosphere is like a carnival. 

Thousands of government and opposition supporters are hitting the streets to drum up last minute support . See his full story: http://bit.ly/16gw7wL

It's Burka Avenger! She's a new cartoon superhero disguised in a flowing black burqa, fighting for girls' education. She'll make her debut on Pakistani television next month in an animated series.  

Read more: http://bit.ly/13fqMCD

The island country of Niue has a goal - to be 'smoke-free' by 2025. 

And they just might do it. Smoking rates have fallen to 11.6%. 

Do you think your country could ever go cigarette free? If not, why?

More: http://bit.ly/1c4xzH9

Are you prepared for the next global pandemic?

Australian scientists are working with scientists from across the world to pre-empt and prepare for the next human pandemic. They say the threat is very real and it's time for a new approach to security. Read more: http://bit.ly/1447mbl

Flickr photo by Diego Cupolo

Crying - we all do it. But did you know that modern scientists believe it's a distinctly human trait? No other animal breaks down in tears. 

So why do we do it, and why do we change the way we cry as we grow older? 

More: http://bit.ly/166jqo2

Are you considering studying in Australia? Or maybe you know one of the 470,000 international students studying here already. 

We've got 5 Top Tips to help international students enjoy student life: 
1. Keep an open mind 
2. Engage with the community 
3. Volunteer 
4. Study hard 
5. Manage parental expectation. 

What are your tips? Read more here: http://bit.ly/15HgwWM

It's like a scene out of an Alfred Hitchcock movie. Thousands of birds have been flocking to a town in Queensland, causing blackouts and stripping trees, according to the local mayor.

It is thought the galahs are being attracted to the town in their search for water as the state's extensive drought continues.

Read more: http://bit.ly/1bL2863

Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge's new son has made his first public appearance. What will his life look like compared to babies who share his birthday across the globe?

Those born in Japan are expected live for more than 84 years. But babies with the same birthday in Uganda are unlikely to live past their mid-50s. Compare the outlook for newborns around the world here: http://bit.ly/1636AsN
The ferocious Tasmanian devil, as captured by ABC Open contributor EzDingo.

Can you guess what's happening in this picture?

If you guessed horse soccer, you're right. Thanks to Jenny Underwood who shared this photo of a horse soccer match at Hughenden, in north-west Queensland.

Disturbing numbers of koalas are being killed and injured by loggers in timber plantations across south-east Australia.

Thousands of koalas have taken refuge in the plantations, but as the trees mature and start being harvested, many koalas are being wiped out, too. 

More: http://bit.ly/11aCd1K

Students in Uttar Pradesh eat their free midday meal, part of the world's most ambitious free school feeding program.

Despite the deaths of children in Bihar state, India's school meals program has been praised for improving attendance and enrolments. It provides a hot lunch to 120 million students, many of whom come to school without having eaten anything. More: http://bit.ly/15aopFs

Photo by Murali Krishnan

Hundreds of people have rallied in cities across Australia against the Federal Government's new policy of sending asylum seekers who arrive by boat without a visa to Papua New Guinea. Today, Immigration Minister Tony Burke confirmed asylum seekers sent to PNG could be held in detention indefinitely if they are not found to be refugees.

Full story: http://bit.ly/1b5KOJB

Would you ever visit a spiritual healer?

Omanisa Ross is a naturopath and spiritual counsellor living in the Northern Territory. She specialises in sketching, reading and healing people's auras. She's fascinated by the connections she finds between her work and certain scientific fields. Watch her story: http://bit.ly/1bV1ulc

A Tokyo beauty salon has a new, all-natural wonder product - snails! They say the slime makes your skin supple and removes dry patches. Would you try it?

Watch: http://bit.ly/12Am0jX
Are you marking Ramadan? Step inside a family house in Granville, New South Wales, as the sun goes down and the community break their fast.   Full story here: http://bit.ly/13fT58f

What's the strangest thing you've ever had in your ear?

A British woman back from holiday in Peru heard scratching noises inside her head. She had maggots living in her ear!

Full story: http://bit.ly/12xM7Ip

(Flickr photo by Travis Isaacs)

Congratulations to Brisbane-based artist Robbie Miller who won triple j Unearthed's National Indigenous Music Award!

Hear his song "Don't Go Walking Away" as he chats with our Heather Jarvis at the link: http://bit.ly/1bqAkns

A phone powered by human urine? British scientists say they've figured out how to do it, but they admit it's not very efficient or, well, practical.  Would you give it a go?

Read the full story: http://bit.ly/17mbbWc

A traditional dance from Banyuwangi, Indonesia. Here Grade 3 students welcome visitors to the area. 

Pratiwi Rahayu shared this photo with Radio Australia - My World. Do you have a travel photo you'd like to share with the world? We'd love to see it.

Water surges down the Margaret River in Western Australia on Monday, after four days of heavy continuous rain.

Photo by Christa Walsh.

How long does it take the Earth to revolve around the sun? 

If you can answer that, you're better off than 40% of Australians, according to new study by the Australian Academy of Science.
More: http://bit.ly/1aNErdR

The Royal family is expecting a new prince or princess any day now. What name will Prince William and Kate Middleton choose? Will it be Princess Alexandra? Or Prince Alfie? 

Send us your best (and worst) baby names. Phil Kafcaloudes will be reading them out on air this morning.

When you think of 'eating disorder', chances are you think of thin, young girls. But new research shows many people with eating disorders are in their 30s and 40s—men and women struggling with ageing and other issues.

Have you ever felt pressure to drastically change your appearance? Why? And what did you do about it?

Full story: http://bit.ly/10XGN3j

Apple says it will investigate claims an iPhone electrocuted a Chinese woman. She was making a call while charging the device.

The state news agency Xinhua said on Sunday that local police had confirmed Ms Ma died of electrocution but "have yet to verify if her phone was involved".

Full story: http://bit.ly/12t0cXt

Any idea what this is? It's a beekeeper suit for dogs! 

Beekeeper Josh Kennett came up with the suit when he began training a black Labrador named Bazz to sniff out bee disease. Read more: http://bit.ly/163T5Ws

A picture says a thousand word. Thanks @arsisto for sharing this beautiful photo with Radio Australia - My World. 

Share you travel pictures with us. Where in the world have you been?

Cattle and culture combined: these Indonesian students visited Australian cattle stations to learn the business side of things, but both the students and their hosts have ended up learning so much more from each other.

We'd like to introduce you a new world scientists are calling HD189733b. This planet appears blue and is found beyond our solar system, some 63 light years away.

"It's very direct, not very deep nor complicated." - Chinese sculptor Xu Hongfei wants people to interact with his "Chubby Women" and leave his first Australian exhibition with new ways to think about beauty.    
Would you like to see more plus-size figures in contemporary art?  Video: http://ow.ly/mPhiv

Three weeks ago, he was facing possible deportation after his claim for asylum was rejected a third time. Now Pakistan-born Fawad Ahmed is officially an Australian after the government fast tracked the spin bowler's citizenship application. 

He could now play for Australia if he's called to England where the first Ashes test opens tonight. He's celebrating anyway: "I came here for a safe life, not for the cricket.'' http://ow.ly/mOZsA

We're celebrating Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture in Australia with NAIDOC specials from 1pm AEST each day this week. Joel Wenitong from The Last Kinection, one Australia's top Indigenous hip-hop groups, presents New Music while Awaye! features Redfern Station, Archie Roach and The Medics in music specials for the next 3 nights from 1705.

Listen here: http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/international/listen

A surfer says he feels lucky to be alive after being knocked unconscious by a whale "the size of a bus" at Sydney's Bondi Beach on the weekend. 

Read more and watch video of the whale here: http://ow.ly/mJICe

Have you had any unexpected close encounters with marine life?

At the age of 10, Jian Wang starred in the 1981 Academy Award-winning documentary From Mao to Mozart: Isaac Stern in China. In this conversation with ABC Classic FM, Jian recalls that life changing experience. Listen now: http://bit.ly/12yS06I

You might not have been a child star, but what events have been life changing for you?

Have you ever seen a seal grooving to a sax? Check out Casey the leopard seal from Sydney's Taronga Zoo being serenaded outside his tank - all in the name of research. 
 
Find out more http://ow.ly/mG72d and check out the seal's moves here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EgRq7wKkRp0
