Photo: Denny Herlambang

Kevin Rudd is visiting Indonesia on his first overseas trip since returning as Australia's Prime Minister last week and tonight Q&A will broadcast live from Jakarta, Indonesia - the first time the show has left Australia. 

What issues do you think the panellists should discuss? Have your say and tweet #QandA while you listen or watch live 9.35pm AEST on Radio Australia, Australia Network or online, anywhere in the world: http://ow.ly/mEarS  

Read more about tonight's panellists here:  http://ow.ly/mEcoE

How do you make sex education hip? And help get young people over what's often an awkward subject? 

Try holding a hip hop competition. The only catch is the song must contain a message about sexual health. It's part of a 5 week program to teach inner city students in Melbourne how to prevent sexually transmitted diseases.  

Watch A.D. perform his entry "HIV" and find out more here : http://bit.ly/122wuff

"If the demands of the people are not realised within the defined period, it will be incumbent upon (the armed forces)... to announce a road map for the future." - General Abdel Fattah al-Sisi.

Egypt's military has given the government a 48-hour deadline to share power after hundreds of thousands of Egyptians took to the streets demanding President Mohammed Morsi quit. Eight people were killed and hundreds more wounded in the mass protests - the biggest since the Arab Spring uprising that ousted President Hosni Mubarak in 2011. 

Click on the link to see the protest in pictures and read more.

Can you imagine a world without the atomic bomb, the Cold War, Vietnam's American War, America's War on Terror?

Academy Award winning director Oliver Stone says these events were not only avoidable, they're all linked to America's decision to use atomic bombs on Japan. But he says U.S. schools are teaching a sanitised, Walt Disney version of American history. 

Are you interested in the history of the last century?
Read more here http://bit.ly/15ZVxgG and hear Phillip Adams' exclusive interview for Late Night Live tonight on Radio Australia: http://ow.ly/mzzYD

"Since 1980, we've shifted about $400 billion from the bottom 99 per cent to the top 1 per cent." - Federal Labor politician, Andrew Leigh.

The former economics professor at the Australian National University has written a book about the history of income equality in Australia, and says globalisation and technology have increased the gap between rich and poor in Australia.  http://ow.ly/mx0lo 

Do you think the global economy, or modern technology, are increasing the divide between rich and poor where you live?

Photo - Takver (Flicker)

It's official.

Kevin Rudd has been sworn in as Australia's Prime Minister – for the second time. He's now the 28th and 26th Australian PM. Watch the ceremony before Governor-General Quentin Bryce in Canberra here: http://youtu.be/G4GDss8UxYU

Follow our live blog here for updates, more video and analysis: http://ow.ly/mqkiR

Is the Australian leadership change big news where you live? Click on the link to tell us what you think of all the political drama.

Are you one of the half a billion gamers who live in Asia and the Pacific? Find out all about the huge E3 expo in L.A. and all the latest releases when the hosts of Australia's hit show Good Game answer your questions tonight!

It all starts on the Australia Network page at 8.30pm AEST, 4pm India, 5.30 pm Jakarta, 6.30 pm Hong Kong, 7.30 pm Seoul.
Are you game?

It will be easier for the next woman and the woman after that and the woman after that." - Julia Gillard speaking at a press conference tonight about being the first female Prime Minister of Australia. 

Julia Gillard did not lose a general election, she lost a ballot for leadership of the Australian Labor Party. Former PM Kevin Rudd will now lead the party. 

What do you think about the way this leadership change has happened, and how will Julia Gillard's leadership be remembered?

He's back. Kevin Rudd has won a dramatic Labor leadership ballot, defeating Julia Gillard 57-45 and paving the way for him to return as prime minister of Australia. 

Listen online now, for analysis and updates with Tracee Hutchison until 10pm AEST: http://bit.ly/KGtwT2 and follow ABC News updates here: http://bit.ly/1ckxlsM

Have you met Bajo and Hex yet? They're Australia's most popular gamers and they want to talk to you! The Good Game hosts are doing a live chat on the Australia Network Facebook page at 8.30 pm AEST on Thursday so this is your chance to ask all your gaming questions! 

Don't forget Good Game goes to air on Australia Network on Wednesday and this week Hex has all the news on the huge E3 gaming convention in Los Angeles. So there's lots to talk about!  http://ow.ly/mlVgc 

What will you ask?

How hot is the weather where you live at this time of year? Cool down with this story from ABC Open about the perils of driving on the Antarctic ice!
http://ow.ly/mjq4i

Have you heard of yarn bombing? It combines the vandalism, social commentary and self-expression of graffiti, with a twist - usually of brightly coloured wool to decorate sterile public spaces. Read one yarn bomber's tale of public decoration by stealth for ABC Open: http://ow.ly/mjoS5 

What other traditional handicrafts apart from knitting are enjoying a funky revival?
Marking the shortest day - and the longest night - with a giant bonfire to light up the winter dark on a bend of the Yarra River, just a few kilometres from the centre of Melbourne's CBD.

Look into the sky tonight and you'll see a supermoon. The moon will travel closer to earth tonight than any other time in 2013 and will appear bigger and bolder than usual. 

Report back to us what you see from your part of the world. Thanks to audience member Andrew Reid for this picture of a supermoon over Newcastle, Australia in 2012.

How would you like to go to a blockbuster sporting match - for free? More than 100 international students will go to a national netball match in Melbourne tomorrow - part of a GloBALL program to give overseas students the chance to see top level sport, including cricket and Aussie Rules football. Volunteers look after each student - and explain the rules! Read more here: http://ow.ly/mfivO

Which sport would you love to see in Australia  if you had the chance? Aussie Rules football? The Australian Open tennis? Aussie Masters golf?

A New Zealand architectural team has won a competition to design a new official residence for the Australian Prime Minister.

Architect Jack Davies from the winning design team says, "We see Australia as a country that isn't ashamed to celebrate its ambition." 
How would you describe Australia?

Read more about the top 3 designs to replace Canberra's leaky old Lodge here: http://bit.ly/11qc0g7

(Image: Jack Davies)

In Australia, refugees and new migrants are queuing up to learn about Aussie Rules Football. 

A football game between two teams of recent graduates who've completed a 5-week crash course took place to coincide with World Refugee Day. Story here: http://bit.ly/11zKf1g

What other short courses would you recommend to new arrivals? Swimming? Bird watching?

Today is World Refugee Day. Here in Australia the day comes in the middle of 'Refugee Week' which this year is themed 'Restoring Hope'. 

Dancers from the Australia-Burma Society took to the stage during last weekend's Emerge Festival to kick start the weeks celebrations. Full story here: http://bit.ly/11kJYCL

Sri Lankan born author Michelle de Kretser has won the 2013 Miles Franklin Award, Australia's most prestigious literary prize, for her book Questions of Travel.

She was one of five authors on an all-female shortlist for the award, with the winner announced at the National Library of Australia in Canberra today.

Full story here: http://bit.ly/1bTWLgG

Years ago, children had pen pals to make friends in other countries. These days they can talk to each other in real time on the internet. 

These students from Marlborough Primary School in Melbourne are skyping their sister-school, MIN Cempaka Putih in Jakarta, as part of a project by the Australia-Indonesia Institute and Asia Education Foundation to give students from both countries the chance to learn about language and build intercultural understanding. 

Do you think these cross-country conversations make a difference to kids' education?

How important is art in building cultural understanding?

Ayleen O'Hanlon is an Australian musician who has performed in Indonesia and Rani Pramesti is an actor from Indonesia who is now studying in Melbourne.

In the middle is Radio Australia's Tito Ambyo, who spoke with them about building artistic collaborations between their two countries.

Read and listen to the story in Indonesian: http://bit.ly/1bPEdxY

Have you ever been the victim of an online scam?

New figures show Australians reported losing more than $93 million to scams last year. 

Delia Rickard from the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission says the most common form of scam is "advance fee fraud".  She says many people do not know they have been scammed until it is too late.

"You might get an email out of the blue telling you that you've inherited $1 million from a long-lost aunt in the United States, but you have to pay this fee to get it out," she told the ABC.

Do you get emails like that? They're likely to be a scam!

(photo from Flickr by Cimexus)

A seven-metre long dinosaur sculpture made out of barbed wire and scrap metal has been installed in a tiny outback Queensland town. The dino is nicknamed 'Barb'. What would you call it? 

Read more: http://bit.ly/142rNjH

Thanks to Milynda Rogers for the photo.

In Australia, famous Aboriginal artists can sometimes be taken advantage of by unscrupulous dealers. It's a sad reality. 

Now a group of community art centres is tackling the issue themselves by creating an innovative pop-up studio for artists visiting from remote communities. More: http://bit.ly/13yEUdm

The chilled out Pacific reggae tunes of bobby Alu are sure to get your weekend off to a great start.

We love music at Radio Australia, and we're lucky enough to get a lot of great musicians into our studios. Check out more live performances at the link: http://bit.ly/11dteNP

Police in London have arrested a man after a spray paint attack on a painting of Queen Elizabeth II by Australian artist Ralph Heimans.

A fathers' advocacy group says one of their members was responsible. It says the man painted "Help" on the picture as part of a desperate appeal to the Queen on behalf of fathers denied access to their children.

Full story: http://bit.ly/14zOVZ5

While driving home last night, Gold Coast ABC Open Producer Solua Middleton saw a great ball of fire in the sky. 

What do you think it was?

Read her story: http://bit.ly/14zB4lz

This weekend King Kong will premiere in Melbourne. The musical features cast of 49 actors, singers, dancers, and arguably the most technologically advanced puppet in the world - a six-meter tall giant King Kong will be an epic theatrical experience. ABC's Jon Faine met King Kong on the stage, find out more here: http://bit.ly/13VRkwM

Burqas, veils and hoodies - a new exhibition in the Melbourne suburb of Dandenong is hoping to put to rest some misconceptions about other cultures. Are we really so different?

More: http://bit.ly/16fGDpc

Sunny Gajjar is the MotoGrapher. He's riding his motorbike across Australia in just 65 days. 

Gajjar, who hails from New Delhi, has spent the journey uploading photos and live blogging his experiences.  Read more about his trip here: http://bit.ly/13ELAVP

Follow him on Facebook or Twitter (@themotographer) for more incredible images.
A beautiful shot of the Simpson desert from ABC Rural reporter Caddie Brain.
Our reporter Astrid Berendsen goes dumpster diving. Have you ever heard of it? Full story: http://bit.ly/13ASFIG
link_name: Dumpster diving for edible treasure in Australia's trash

status_message: Are you a gamer? Hex from Good Game is at E3 - the biggest video game conference and show around.  Wish you could tag along?

Do you hold any really odd beliefs—in ghosts, UFOs or tooth fairies? You're likely to find troves of evidence online to support it. Tory Shepherd explains why science is now in mortal combat with the internet, and why for many children science is losing. 
http://bit.ly/107EKeV

What about internet bombshell that the US National Security Agency program called Prism is collecting and storing information on you and me.   The NSA has either convinced or forced a range of companies, including Google, Microsoft, Yahoo, Apple and Facebook to pass over information on clients. All in the name of US national security...Canada, UK, NZ and Australia could all be getting this info via the program.  Are you worries that what you say online will be used against you?

Chinese artist and activist Ai Weiwei's work is getting a lot of attention at the Venice Biennale.

Part of it includes boxes like this, where people can peer in to watch him as he was watched during his detention.

What do you think of his work? More on his solo show here: http://youtu.be/a3Ta7Wd0pEM
A musical light display on the iconic Opera House as part of Vivid Sydney. What colour would you paint it?

Indigenous artist Lena Nyadbi will be showing her work to millions of people  - on the rooftop of a Paris museum.  

Her black-and-white painting called Dayiwul Lirlmim, or Barramundi Scales, is inspired by her mother's homeland in Dayiwul Country. A large scale reproduction will fill the museum's 700-square-metre rooftop terrace. More: http://bit.ly/16O20BN
Owen Campbell is a bluesman - who also rocks, serenades and plays a mean banjo. His new release 'The Pilgrim' is our Album of the Week. Check it out here: http://bit.ly/15ChHXV

Last week, Vietnam police arrested about 30 people demonstrating against China in Hanoi as tensions around territorial disputes remain between the two countries.   Witnesses said security forces dispersed more than 100 protesters gathered in the city centre.   Those arrested were taken by bus to the camp Loc Ha - a rehabilitation center for criminals  - located on the outskirts of the capital. Some were beaten up by police and security agents. The remaining protesters lay down on a nearby highway to block traffic until all their comrades were released.   Two AFP journalists were also among those arrested but were released a few hours later.

Happy Thursday. Here's a beautiful image of the Aurora Australis in north-west Tasmania to help get your day off to a good start. 

Thanks to audience member Tim Cooper for the photo.

Have you heard of the Keystone XL pipeline? It would carry carbon-intensive tar sand crude oil from Alberta, Canada, to the Gulf of Mexico.  

Veteran climate change activist Bill McKibben hopes US president Obama may be close to blocking it, and that this move could slash fossil fuel use and reopen global debate on carbon pollution. Read more: http://bit.ly/13DUq6w

(Flickr photo by Elvert Barnes)

Happy World Environment Day. This year: think, eat, save. Did you know Australian households throw away about 2.675 million tonnes of food waste per year?

Here are 30 simple ways to save food and money - like avoiding buying too much in the first place. What are your tips? http://bit.ly/17mol8G

Flickr photo by Mr. iMaax

It's the 24th anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests. And to mark it, China has banned internet searches of a wide range of keywords including 'today', 'tomorrow', 'that day' and 'big yellow duck'.  More: http://bit.ly/16GiDiE

Photo from - Twitter/weibo.com/weibolg

Anti-government protests in Turkey continue. 

Find out what's happening on the ground. Anna Hipsley speaks with Abdullah Bozkurt, Ankara Bureau Chief for Today's Zaman Turkey's highest-selling national daily newspaper. Hear the interview: http://bit.ly/11jq1Zp

(Photo from audience member Chris Hurren)

Now that's a big cat. 

The feral cat population across Arnhem Land in the Northern Territory has exploded. Traditional owners are saying they've noticed a steep decline in local birds and other wildlife. More: http://bit.ly/11Auoht

What's the trouble with beauty?

Having a daughter made Lea Redfern think long and hard about the place of beauty in women's lives today. How important is to feel pretty?  More: http://bit.ly/12ZLbwX

(Flickr photo by Shai Savariau)

Princess Mary of Denmark visits the Malaysia Karen Organization in Kuala Lumpur, where she met and talked to young Karen refugee students.

The Karen are an ethnic group living primarily in Myanmar many of  whom have been displaced by decades of war. 

(Photo courtesy MKO)

Are you tired? Feeling weak? Eat whale meat! At least, that's the message behind Japan's peak whaling body's new campaign. More: http://bit.ly/1aPPxd8

There are about 5,000 tonnes of whale meat sitting unwanted in freezers around Japan. Once popular in school lunches, younger generations of Japanese rarely, if ever, eat whale.

(Flickr photo by Thessaly La Force)

Solomon Islands is banning single cigarette sales and smoking in public places, as part of tough new regulations to coincide with World No Tobacco Day.

Will this stop people smoking? Have you got similar regulations in your country? Do they work?

Read more here: http://bit.ly/11eOguQ (image below by Tom Magliery, via Flickr)

Are you in Jakarta? Chances are, you're on Twitter then, too. It's the world's Twitter capital. 

RN Drive site down with author, tech blogger and editor Budi Putra to get the inside scoop the city's love affair with very very very short messages. Read more: http://bit.ly/16qCAde

Twenty years ago Radio Australia technician Brian Cox developed what is affectionally known to staff as the "Cox Box"  - allowing them to monitor and record audio from various sources. They are still used to this day and remain reliable.

Brian was at the recent send off of long serving RA staff, and dropped in to check out how his blue namesakes are working.

A child is fascinated by the Night Blossoms on Pyrmont Bridge as a part of Vivid Sydney - a festival of light, music and ideas.

Photo by Neerav Bhatt.

Melbourne snapshot: We caught some of the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra in preparation for Education Week.

Do you think classical music is still relevant to kids today? Why or why not?

Jakarta has a collective obsession with traffic. 

Some pedestrian activists are trying to reclaim the footpaths and clear the air.

More: http://bit.ly/1axt5Fk

This week is National Reconciliation Week in Australia, and momentum is gathering for for constitutional change to recognise Australia's first peoples in the country's Constitution. More: http://bit.ly/1714dca

Within one or two generations the majority of the world's population will be struggling for fresh water, according to a group of 500 water scientists that met recently in Germany.

Is it time for the conversation around water to get serious?
Read more: http://bit.ly/12gZbHv

Today on Shelflife, James and Michael look at Australian actors who have turned their "talents" to singing. 

Those trailblazers with enough chutzpah to attempt the transition from the TV screen to the stereo-system, had only their intuition and better judgement to guide them.

Recognise any of the actors below?

Waleed Aly and RN Drive are bringing the Drawing Room to Jakarta. Tune in at 8pm Jakarta time (11pm Sydney) to hear a discussion about the flavours of home and away with two correspondents -  George Brown for the ABC and Helen Brown for the Australia Network.  

More fantastic photos from Jakarta on the RN Drive Facebook page!

Michael Munson and James Lee will be joining Phil Kafcaloudes this morning for their regular segment - Shelflife.

Do you have a favourite album cover? Or better yet, have you ever dreamed up what the cover of your debut album might look like?

Billionaire philanthropist Bill Gates is in Canberra today, and says he's less than impressed with the Australian government's decision to defer increases in foreign aid. He wants to see more done to fight diseases like polio and malaria, and encourage entrepreneurs to make toilets instead of tech gadgets.  

Hear more: http://bit.ly/11lMNyv

(Photo: N'djamena, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, Flickr.com)

Dinky, the famous singing dingo from Stuarts Well Roadhouse in the Northern Territory, has retired to Alice Springs.

Dinky has been singing to passing tourists standing on an upright piano for more than 12 years, raising money for charity.

More: http://bit.ly/12zDNrU

The mysterious Marree Man was first discovered in the South Australian desert in 1998. It's more than 4 km long, and has faded a lot over the years. Now, though, there's pressure to spruce him up. 

Read more: http://bit.ly/15a3OAa

At the World Barista Championship in Melbourne last week, each barista had to make three different types of espresso-based drinks for four judges in 15 minutes, while being watched by cameras and judges. Doddy Samsura, the Indonesian representative, trained for 8-12 hours a day for two months before the competition.

The Australian Government is cracking down on gambling advertisements during live sporting events. Some say they should ban gambling ads completely during children's TV hours. What do  you think?

Full story: http://bit.ly/18kWxlg

(Flickr photo by Michael Dorausch)
Those aren't leaves - they're Corellas! Thanks to Rod Flavell for the photo.

Australia Network is launching a new show, and it's all about what you think. 

Right now they're looking at racism. Is it a problem where you live? Share your experiences here in the comments, or upload your video comment to their Facebook page or to Youtube (http://bit.ly/11elSV9).
link_name: Racism - is it a problem where you live?

status_message:
Australian singer-songwriter Heath Cullen gives some fatherly advice in this live performance at the ABC Sound Library in Melbourne. 

What's the best advice you've ever received?

What we eat says a lot about us, where we're from and where we live. Do you know what this is a picture of? And where it's from?

Give your best guesses in the comments. We'll let you know the real answer before too long. 

Dwi S. Utåmå shared this photo with Radio Australia - My World. Show us what's on the plate where you live. Just snap, upload and share.

Where did the Australian accent come from? Some say we mumble so the flies can't get into our mouths. A project called Australian Voices is tackling the origins of our accent. Listen to our interview with them here: http://bit.ly/12Rbh6T

What's your favourite Australianism?
Mr. Keo Sonan Kavei and his team share photos of Angkor Wat's pin harp, brought to life once again. Read more: http://bit.ly/13MXMWX
link_name: Cambodian researchers, musicians revive ancient harp

status_message: The beautiful and beautifully expressive Malaysian actress Wardina Safiyyah is at our Melbourne studios as part of a Malaysian delegation of future leaders today. She spoke to us about a lot of things, including changing ideas of beauty and wearing the hijab on screen. Interview to come!

Rescuers are continuing to look for survivors in Oklahoma. 

Tornadoes can be extremely destructive. More on how they form here: http://bit.ly/119V8VL

Animal rights groups say Thai criminal syndicates are rounding up thousands of dogs to feed demand for dog meat in Asia. Sometimes the dogs are bought from poor villagers, many are taken from the streets. After they are taken, they are force fed to increase their weight so they can be sold at a higher price. some suffocate and die in the process, read full report: http://bit.ly/12QQIpW

This month, ABC Open is celebrating the many faces of Australia. 

This is John, taken by Paula McManus

Paula wrote: 'John was taking a break from his duties as the generator maintenance man. The town's electricity is supplied by generators which run 24 hours a day. John's job is to make sure that the generators continue to work. He has lived in the town for about 10 years after moving from the Coorong. He said that he thinks that he may retire soon to the Flinders Ranges.'

http://bit.ly/10eUsmy

For more than eight centuries the sound of the pin harp has been locked in stone - seen on the walls of Angkor Wat, but lost from music today. 

Now a Cambodian composer has revealed what it may have sounded like.

Hear more: http://bit.ly/19SSN73

The sunrise this morning over Noosa, Queensland.

Photo by ABC Sunshine Coast's David Shipton.

Dinghys sit on the shore before the start of the Fremantle to Bali yacht race in Western Australia. 

Photo by ABC audience member aaronphoto.

Members of the Sri Lankan military practice on the streets of Colombo ahead of the annual Victory Day parade commemorating the anniversary of the Sri Lankan Forces' defeat of the Tamil Tigers on May 18, 2009.

Photo by ABC audience member Eva Frances.

'Big Brother in Space'- a Dutch reality TV show plans to send volunteers on a mission to Mars.  The only catch? There's no return trip. Yet.   

More: http://bit.ly/13wljv3

Is Bollywood to blame?

 Women in Indian film are still presented as scantily clad, passive sex objects, leading many to wonder if blame for a recent spate of horrific rapes lies with the country's directors and actors. More: http://bit.ly/17wopCz

You might not be able to walk on water, but you can at least stand up and glide. 

A stand up paddle boarder makes his way across the water at the seaside Adelaide suburb of Seacliff.

Australia has announced plans to save money by delaying planned spending to foreign aid.

But Dr Musimbi Kanyoro, one of the world's leading advocates for the advancement of women, says this could have serious consequences for women in the Asia Pacific. Full interview: http://bit.ly/11CPVgE

You can't help but dance when you hear the music of Melbourne-based bluegrass band Mustered Courage. Their new album 'Powerlines' is our Album of the Week and they stopped by to treat us to a live performance in the ABC Music Library.

Full interview here: http://bit.ly/10myWvB

A UN report says insects like maggots, beetles, caterpillars and ants might be the food of the future. They're environmentally friendly and could help fight obesity. 

Do you think people will catch the bug-eating bug? More: http://bit.ly/YS0V88

The Australian Body Art Carnival was held over the weekend in Eumundi, on Queensland's Sunshine Coast. 

(Photo by Bruce Atkinson)

In 1932 about 20,000 emus descended on farms -  a situation that local farmers thought could only be handled by the Australian Army. 

It seems absurd today, but in 1932 three army personnel along with Lewis machine guns and 10,000 rounds of ammunition were dispatched to the frontline. 

After a few days it appeared that their enemy was to be more difficult to defeat than they had first expected. 

Read more - http://bit.ly/10swxLP

In Australia these days, it's pretty rare to find families with more than two kids. But when Natalie Elkins wakes up this Mother's Day, she'll have twice as much fun. She has four children to make her breakfast in bed. 

Nadia Hume catches up with some mothers who are bucking the trend of 2.1 kids and having families larger than the norm: http://bit.ly/18xq2ih
Happy Mother's Day! How do you tell your mum you love her?

Tomorrow is International Nurses Day. Stop and think a moment about all the great things nurses do for you and your community. Nurses like Olivet Tugu in rural Vanuatu. 

Olivet works every single day, treating people who are sick in a very remote community. Here she is learning how to use a compass so that she can navigate the boat trip to the hospital in foggy weather.
It's the Milky Way. ABC Open contributor Laurie Anne King took this amazing shot of the night sky.

Did you see this morning's solar eclipse? 

Producer Bethany Keats used a pinhole camera to view it safely. 

Did you do a better job than her? Send us your photos!

What happens in Australia when the sun goes down? 
ABC Open stays up late with Snapped: After Dark http://bit.ly/10iRqP7

Photo by vorka70

A horse attempts to buck its rider at the Daly Waters Rodeo in the north of Australia's Northern Territory.

Photo by audience member Sam Gubicak.

Are vegetarians hypocrites because millions of animals are massacred to protect fruit, vegetable and grain crops? Is it possible to be a compassionate meat-eater? 

Hear the debate: http://bit.ly/11gYk9w

(Flickr photo by ZeroOne)

A girl walks past a flock of little corellas as they take off from a field in South Australia. 

Photo by audience member Rod Squire.

Yesterday we asked about postcards, today - handwriting. 

Can you write as beautifully as your grandmother did? Or does your hand start to cramp up? Has handwriting been lost to Times New Roman and Helvetica? 

ABC Open contributor Sue Peacock writes about missing a part of her mother's personality : http://bit.ly/12cNEUL

On your marks, get set... GOAT! 

Competitors take off at the start of one of the goat races during the Tree of Knowledge Festival in the central-west Queensland town of Barcaldine.  Thanks to Trevor Howie for the photo.

When was the last time you sent a postcard?

Do you think the digital age has killed the act of sending postcards and letters? 

More: http://bit.ly/YyTJO7

(Image courtesy Kununurra Historical Society and Museum)

Wes Marne is 91 and for the past 30 years, he has been an Aboriginal elder in western Sydney. He's had a profound impact on his community, and says his goal is "just to let them know there's somebody here who cares."

Read his story: http://bit.ly/18KjZ7f

Andrew Fairclough is Welsh, but he was born in PNG while his parents were working as a doctor and a teacher there. Recently, he ran the 2013 London Marathon wearing a traditional Papua New Guinean grass skirt to raise money for charity. 

 
Yes, he was worried the skirt might fall off but managed to complete the marathon without any embarrassing moments running past Buckingham Palace! 

Hear his interview with Heather Jarvis: http://bit.ly/1082nOL

(Photo by Jess Webb)

One day you might be able to print yourself a new body part from the comfort of home! Australian scientists say they have found a way to grow human body parts using 3D printing technology. More: http://bit.ly/YilVT7

A British management organisation has surveyed 2,000 of its members to find out the pet office peeves.  They include all staff-emails, colleagues eating at the their desks and management-speak including 'going forward' and 'thinking outside the box'.

What are your pet peeves about (lacking) office etiquette?

More: http://bit.ly/16x4S4A

A sneak peak inside our newsroom here at ABC International  on World Press Freedom Day. Some of the people who bring you news and stories from around the world every day.

(From right to left, roughly: Adelaine Ng,Bruce Hill, Heather Jarvis, Camilla Hannan, Tom Maddocks, Richard Ewart, Campbell Cooney, Bill Bainbridge and Bethany Keats)

A competitor makes their way down the bog-snorkelling trench at the annual championships in north-west Queensland.  Competitors swim two lengths of the 50 metre pit while wearing only bathers, flippers and a snorkel.

More: http://bit.ly/ZCOjf2

Thanks to Tayla Beaton for the photo.

Have you been watching the election in Malaysia? This morning, Phil Kafcaloudes and Adelaine Ng will be talking about how some political parties and groups are using videos and YouTube to spread their message to voters.

What do you think about politics using social media? Is it an extension of democracy? Or just sneaky manipulation?

"My name is Amrit Solanki. I was born in Gujarat. I have spent most of my life in Mumbai.

"I was engaged at the age of two months and married when I was 12 years old.

"Life in India for women is what you see it as. It's not easy being a woman in this society but God has given us a lot of strength, so we can deal with what ever comes our way."

Her full story: http://bit.ly/ZNqnez

New Zealand has released a list of rejected baby names, and it contains some real head-scratchers (4Real? Mafia No Fear?).  What's the nuttiest name you've come across? 

Full story here: http://bit.ly/12YpdMa

Australia Network is in Kuala Lumpur this week for a series of specials in the lead-up to this weekend's poll.

In the latest of out Malaysia, opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim has warned that "massive fraud" could prevent his coalition from winning. More: http://bit.ly/12XJ0Ly

Photo by @jbaylisssmith
What a beautiful autumn colors in Canberra. Great photo by Jenny Bonner.

Zoe Daniel ABC Southeast Asia Correspondent is on the road in Perak state, Malaysia, covering the 2013 election. 

More on our election coverage here: http://bit.ly/14RFKEG
bobby Alu brings his tunes and band to Melbourne.
link_name: Bobby Alu live on the traffic island

status_message:
A young woman in traditional dress in a Mosuo village, in a remote and mountainous region of China's Yunnan province. 

It's one of the last surviving matriarchal societies in the world.  In the Mosuo's dialect there is no word for husband or father.  

Hear more: http://bit.ly/11GIEIR
(Photo by Dave Tacon)

Australia's Governor-General Quentin Bryce visits the UPNG Buk bilong Pikinini library, Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea. She's in PNG on a five-day visit. 

Photo by Serleen Nicholas: Stella Magazine. Check out their Facebook page for more photos.

In Myanmar, a women steps forward to test her luck in a sim card lottery.
 
Previously, a single sim card cost around $2000 in Myanmar. Currently one costs around $200, but a few days ago some lucky people got one for $2.  

The government distributed a total of 300,000 cheap sim cards across the country in April.  The median daily wage in Myanmar is around $2.
Today is World Malaria Day. Get the full story: http://bit.ly/Y3fOnG

Lone Pine at Gallipoli - one of the most famous sites of the campaign where thousands of Australian soldiers lost their lives in WWI. 

Pine cones from the ridge were brought back to Australia and thousands of pine trees now grow in Australia from the Gallipoli cones.

Thanks to Bethany Keats for the photo.

Lest we forget. 
Thanks to Bethany Keats for sharing this photo from Belgium's famed Flanders fields

Five teen girls in Indonesia have been accused of blasphemy after making a video in which they mixed Islamic prayer with dancing to a Maroon 5 song. 

The video went viral, but now they might face jail time.

Have you seen it? And if you're in Indonesia, do you think it's time to revisit blasphemy laws? More: http://bit.ly/15HOP3v

Early morning joggers run past red lanterns hanging in Brisbane,  ahead of the Buddha Birth Day Festival from May 3-5.

Thanks to Peter Taylor for sharing the photo.

Frozen frogs: the key to saving a species? 

Australia's native frogs could be saved from extinction after a world-first breakthrough. A team of scientists from Newcastle University have frozen frog embryonic cells - a way to press the 'pause' button while they try to fight disease. 

More: http://bit.ly/17KwY8x

Tonight Australia's population will reach an estimated 23 million people. 

How do the experts know? Well, with a birth every one minute and 44 seconds, a new migrant arriving every two minutes and 19 seconds, and a death every three minutes and 32 seconds, they put a bit of math to use. 

Our question: What would you name the lucky baby?
Iconic Australian rock singer Chrissy Amphlett has died. Chrissy fronted The Divinyls, who were popular in the early 80s and 90s. More: http://bit.ly/ZfMk5L

Chinese rescue workers are blasting to clear mounds of rock blocking roads as emergency teams try to reach isolated towns hit by China's worst earthquake in three years. 

At least 1,700 aftershocks have followed since the quake struck Saturday morning. More: http://bit.ly/10spwSe

Today is World Circus Day. Mason West from Australia's famed circus troupe, Circus Oz, shows us why we keep going back to the big top. 

More pics and story here: http://bit.ly/11pAsKn

(Thanks to Circus Oz for the great photo!)

Is your country or region famous for a certain dessert?
 
The origins of pavlova is a hotly debated issue. Both Australia and New Zealand lay claim to it. This was prepared by Clement Paligaru recently who layered the crispy meringue with cream, kiwi fruit, berries and passionfruit.

Share your picture and recipe with Radio Australia - My World. It could be featured on the website and more!

Twenty years ago this week, Indigenous Australian footballer Nicky Winmar made a very public, yet personal stand that challenged Australia's attitude towards racism.

Responding to racial abuse during an AFL match, he defiantly raised his jumper, pointed to his skin and said "I'm black and I'm proud to be black".

Heather Jarvis speaks with the co-curator of a new exhibition on the event: http://bit.ly/15kXokn

When you hear the word graffiti, what's the first thing you think of?

A group of creative Jakarta volunteers are using graffiti to help teach street children who are missing out on regular school. 
Find out more: http://bit.ly/Z2toY9

One of Australia's most prestigious universities is under fire after cancelling a planned speaking event by the Dalai Lama.

The university says it never received any official request to host the Dalai Lama, and that the problem with the event was logistics. 

But the ABC has obtained emails revealing the university, which has close links to China, went to great lengths to wash its hands of the iconic monk. Read more: http://bit.ly/11sNmK0

Yesterday's horrific bombings at the Boston Marathon shook the sporting world. Unfortunately, this isn't the first time a sporting event has been rocked by violence. 

From the Munich Olympics in 1972 to 2009's Sri Lanka and Pakistan cricket match, ABC News remembers: http://bit.ly/12kKss6

Australia's Blackchords are a four-piece band who use vintage instruments, keyboards and electronic programming to create an original sound. They're our new Album of the Week. 

Check them out: http://bit.ly/15ebLqJ

(Thanks to the band for letting us use their photo!)

The last goat on Cape Byron in New South Wales has evaded capture after a daring bid to rescue it from the bottom of a cliff.

She's been on the run for eight years.  Byron Bay resident Elaine Reed says the goat has other plans in mind.

"I think she's got a new lease on life and she saw the guys coming and she thought I am getting out of here. I'm not having anything to do with men," she said.

How would you catch her?

Meet Gwen Bullock, a master of the peach blossom cake. She entered her first cake in a show in 1952, and has been winning ribbons and awards ever since.

Do you have a prize-winning recipe? Share it with us here or at Radio Australia - My World.

Scientists may have cracked a key mystery surrounding the cancer pushing Tasmanian devils to extinction. 

They've worked out how the disease evades the immune system – by suppressing important molecules that help identify foreign cells.  It's a glimmer of hope that a vaccine might be developed.  
Read more: http://bit.ly/ZtKUWP

(Photo courtesy of University of Tasmania)

There are over 65 million motorcycles on the roads in Indonesia, and more are added every day. 

It has dramatically changed the ability of young Indonesians to work and learn because they no longer have to use the country's unreliable public transport system. 

Do you use a motorcycle to get around? 

Read more: http://bit.ly/107df5l
Map showing the site of the Boston Marathon explosions.

A surfer wipes out at Mona Vale Beach on Sydney's northern beaches. 

Photo by audience member Jon Dibbs.

Over 40 million people have already watched Psy's new music vido 'Gentleman' on YouTube - and it was only posted two days ago.  Have you seen it yet? 

Here's a link to the clip: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ASO_zypdnsQ
Read more here: http://bit.ly/XB91z7

What's your style? Rock, rap, beats, blues, soul, or pop punk? 
Australia Network has you covered with the One Night Stand concert. It's held in a different country town around Australia every year. This is the tenth triple j One Night Stand and it's Dubbo's turn – 400 kilometres from Sydney!

Watch live tonight on Australia Network TV in one hour: 
http://australianetwork.com/guide/00183199.htm 

Or live stream from triple j anywhere in the world: http://tripj.net/triplejONS

Is saying it with flowers still relevant? Or you prefer saying it with ecard, text, or photo messaging? However, the most beautiful symmetry is still found in flowers. Look at this beautiful Camelia flower, photographed by Liza Hunt at the George Tindale Memorial Gardens, Victoria, Australia. Have a good weekend!

Hey game lovers, do you like hunting dragons or zombies? Follow reviews and latest news of games on Australia Network's Good Game. Bajo and Hex review The Walking Dead: Survival Instinct, Year Walk and Monster Hunter 3 Ultimate. Watch it online here: http://bit.ly/YPkSdW
Smoke rises from forestry burn-offs in the Hartz Mountains National Park, southern Tasmania, Australia. Thanks Beth Heap for submitting the photo.

A rainbow pedestrian crossing laid across one of Sydney's busiest thoroughfares for the Gay and Lesbian Mardi Grass has been torn up by the New South Wales government. Do you agree with the Government's decision to tear up this crossing? (Photo: ABC News)
According to Clarence Day, an American author, ants are good citizens, they place group interests first. Do you think we need to live the life like ants? (Photo: ABC Environment)

Faulty Towers, a British sitcom, visits Radio Australia while touring their award-winning international show, called 'The Dining Experience' in Melbourne. When they were inspecting the studio for an interview with Phil Kafcaloudes this morning, they found dust bunnies! Are they going to clean the studio? Watch it here: http://bit.ly/YiEurz

The Sumatran Tiger is classified as critically endangered as much of the forests they inhabit on the Indonesian Island of Sumatra have been largely logged to make room for palm oil plantations, and to a lesser extent, rubber plantations. Radio Australia's Nadia Hume went along to Melbourne zoo to find out more. Fulll report: http://bit.ly/12Ijw4j
link_name: Save Sumateran tiger from palm oil plantations

status_message: Amnesty International has published its global death penalty statistics for 2012 and it found that the global trend towards ending the death penalty worldwide is continuing. Find out the report here: http://bit.ly/16OZ2Hk

Do you check to see if the products you buy contain non-sustainable palm oil? The Sumatran Tiger is a critically endangered species. Their natural habitat has largely been replaced by palm oil plantations.
link_name: Save Sumateran tiger from palm oil plantations

status_message: Do you want to practice speaking in English? Are you preparing speaking test for IELTS? Join 'Passport to English' from Australia Network. It provides you with the opportunity to experience what it is like to sit a formal English language interview for assessment purposes. Get the free course here: http://bit.ly/10IRjZw

What do you think about the growing numbers of open online courses? Do you see it as the future of education or just another giant marketing scam? Find out more and join the discussion: http://bit.ly/10NlGy4
link_name: MOOCs: The future of education or mere marketing?

status_message: Good morning! Brilliant sun captured by Mike Friday at Ringers Soak, West Australia. Have a good day!
Former British prime minister Margret Thatcher has died at the age of 87 following a stroke: http://bit.ly/ZhLQXe
link_name: Former British PM Margaret Thatcher dead

status_message:
What are your hopes for a better Malaysia?

Malaysia is preparing for what could be the closest election since independence. Earlier this month, Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak dissolved Parliament, paving the way for the election. Official campaigning when the poll is called will be fast and furious, and the campaign may last just 2 weeks. Read full story: http://bit.ly/10JBAdP (Photo: ABC Open - Lauren433)

The classic album this week is chosen by our morning presenter Phil Kafcaloudes. It is 'Earth and Sun and Moon' by Midnight Oil.  For him, this album has spiritual meaning. Many of the songs question what it means to be Australian and live in this vast, complex country.  The album was released in 1993 and did well on charts around the world, reaching No. 2 in Australia.

Find out why this album is so special to Phil and so many others: http://bit.ly/14Qz3CR

Watch Phil talking about the album: http://bit.ly/10JTc8D

Paulo Coelho, an award-winning author of 'The Alchemist' says  there is only one thing that makes a dream impossible to achieve: the fear of failure. Have a good week and never give up! (Photo: Jon Dibbs)

Photos from the Contemporary Pacific Arts Festival which has been developed by Footscray Community Arts Centre - in Melbourne's Western suburbs, and a recently formed group called the Big Island Collective. Visitors enjoyed a range of exhibitions, workshops, forums, and film screenings. Not to mention a big community day celebration.
Pacific Island Hula dancer Fipe Keanu show us how it's done at the inaugural Contemporary Pacific Arts Festival's community day held in Melbourne today.

Hal Loo is now a mechanic in regional Australia.  But he spent the first eighteen years of his life in the Mae La Refugee Camp of Karen State, Burma. 

Meet Hal Loo, and others in his Karen community in this series of profiles by Nhill resident Katherine Colbert, with photography by Melissa Powell from Natimuk. 

Link from ABC Open: http://bit.ly/10BgaPa
Australia's Prime Minister is in China and will meet the new Chinese president, Xi Jinping, and premier Li Keqiang during her time on Hainan Island and in Shanghai and Beijing.
link_name: Gillard embarks on Chinese trade mission

status_message: Radio Australia attended a conference today at Deakin University which focused on leadership in Papua New Guinea.  Heather Jarvis and Caroline Tiriman hosted a live broadcast for the Pacific, and some of the photos from the event are included here.  Join our Tok Pisin team live tonight across PNG on FM and shortwave to hear more of the stories and interviews.

Nth Korea has announced "the moment of explosion is fast approaching" and has dramatically upped its warlike rhetoric. The U.S says Pyongyang is a real and clear danger to the U.S and her allies.

Full story here: http://bit.ly/YTWsiV

Myanmar artists are taking the opportunity to push boundaries and express themselves with less government interference. Political art can now be seen hanging in public galleries. 

Full story here: http://bit.ly/Z0ygZ8

Adelaide band Lowrider have mixed their signature soul and hip hop flavour with an edgy jazz, rock and pop feel. Their new album 'Black Stones' is our Album of the Week. 

Take a listen: http://bit.ly/YuyN9b
Here's a picture of the newly discovered frog in its natural habitat....

Lightning strikes at dawn in Robe, South Australia, as thunderstorms passed overhead.

Photo by Levin Barrett

This weekend, many families around the world will be getting together to dye eggs and make food for Easter. Of course, the most important question is, what music will they be listening to while they do it? 

What music do you like to listen to when you cook?

(Photo: Flickr - Nancy Frost)

Meet 'Uni', soon to be New Zealand's first diabetic response dog.

Once trained, the two-year-old German Shepherd will be able to smell abnormal blood sugar levels.

Full story here: http://bit.ly/XFDSrb

(Photo by Kotuku Foundation Assistance Animals Aotearoa)

A star trails light up the sky above Norman Bay in Wilsons Promontory. The peninsula in Victoria's south forms the southernmost part of the Australian mainland.

Photo by Nicholas Milum

What would you do to draw attention to climate change? Latin N'Drihin is walking around the world. He's Papua New Guinea's Climate Change Ambassador. 

Hear more about his journey: http://bit.ly/YHkEBJ

(Photo by Julianna Waeda)

Meet Klaus Menzel. He's 65 and has spent the last 10 years travelling outback Australian roads with his two camels pulling a ute.  More: http://bit.ly/11IKCeQ

Do you ever dream of doing something similar? Like cycling across Asia? Or walking across Tasmania?

Australian blues and roots artist Benny Walker was recently awarded the Victorian Indigenous Performing Arts Award for Best New Talent. His new album 'Sinners and Saints' is our Album of the Week! 

Check it out: http://bit.ly/X6vCEY

Lightning illuminates the Surfers Paradise skyline as storms lashed southeast Queensland yesterday. Emergency crews worked through the evening after the storm brought down trees and cut power to 50,000 homes. 

Thanks to Mike Slough for the photo.

On this day in 1966, the Beatles took what was then the most controversial photo of their career - the album cover for "Yesterday and Today". The original photo (on the left) was replaced by the one on the right after a general outcry.

What do you think? Is it still controversial today?

Harmony Day is an annual celebration of Australia's diverse and multicultural society.  And an opportunity for people to also celebrate the things we have in common. Full story:  http://bit.ly/YtAoIH  (Photos by Nadia Hume)
link_name: Diverse harmonies entertain on Harmony Day

status_message: Today is Harmony Day. Join us as we get on the Worship Bus to visit Mata Chintapurni Hindu Temple and the Australian Bosnian Islamic Centre. The Worship Bus is a real bus that takes people to different places of worship to encourage interfaith dialogue and mutual understanding. Stay tuned for more!
Young people from around the world gather together to debate and discuss global issues at the World Model UN 2013.
We're broadcasting live with Phil Kafcaloudes from World Model UN 2013. Stay tuned for updates throughout the day as young people from around the world make resolutions for real change.

A supporter cheers on the game as the Imalu Tigers defeat the Tapalinga Superstars in the Tiwi Islands footy Grand Final n Australia's Northern Territory.

The Tiwi Islands has the highest AFL participation rate in Australia, with around 900 participants in the population of 2600. Read more: http://bit.ly/XN9sZW

(Photo by Clare Rawlinson)

Prime Minister Julia Gillard has announced a new $20 million commitment as part of the Australia's aid program for Myanmar. The announcement came after Ms Gillard held talks with the President of Myanmar, Thein Sein, who is on a three day visit to Australia. Full story: http://bit.ly/117ab8W
link_name: Myanmar President Thein Sein visits Australia

status_message:
Can you name these birds? They're all from the Paluma rainforest, just north of Townsville, Queensland - a birder's paradise.

If you can't, don't worry. The answers are here: http://bit.ly/Xbp57p

Today is national Speaking Out Against Bullying Day. 

What advice would you give to a young person who is being bullied? 

Meet a group of young people who had the courage to share their stories of bullying. - http://bit.ly/Z4jAtZ

Swaziland is a country devastated by extreme poverty and the HIV/AIDS epidemic. The members of the Possible Dreams International Choir have been victims of rape, HIV/AIDS or other diseases, and they travel the country singing songs of hope. Read more: http://bit.ly/Zl35Zs

Happy Birthday, Canberra! Australia's national capital celebrates 100 years today. Read more: http://bit.ly/YQ2Lmi

Photo by Derek Flannery
Images from the World of Music, Arts & Dance Festival in Adelaide, South Australia (Photos by Kim Taylor)
Images from the World of Music, Arts & Dance Festival in Adelaide, South Australia (Photos by Kim Taylor)

Real women wear lab coats. When you look around at the female role models for young girls today, how many of them have careers in science? 

In 1990, we looked at the hurdles faced by girls and women in science. How much has changed since then? Listen: http://bit.ly/104Td6N

(Photo of Estonian geneticist and award-winning science journalist Riin Tamm)

Happy International Women's Day! Today we're highlighting women around the world - their achievement and triumphs, and the struggles still facing them today and in the future.

Who is the woman who has inspired you most?

Tracee Hutchison with Sharon Bhagwan-Rolls. She's a Fijian political activist and spoke to Tracee about her role with femLINKPACIFIC and the drive to get more women involved with politics. 

If you could imagine a government with equal involvement from men and women, what would it look like? Would it be any different? How?
A member of China's  Guizhou Beijing Opera Troupe puts on makeup in preparation for the Chinese Opera Festival, held in Melbourne last weekend.

Are the members of anti-whaling group Sea Shepherd pirates? A US judge thinks so, saying that when you ram ships, hurl glass containers of acid, launch smoke bombs and flares with hooks, there's no doubt you're a pirate. 

Whether or not you agree, are the methods Sea Shepherd uses ever justifiable?

More: http://bit.ly/ZzGPeZ

A message on the side of a bus in a mine in northern Western Australia. The mine crew who use the bus didn't have to go to work because of Cyclone Rusty.

Tropical Cyclone Rusty intensified to a category four storm this morning. Locals took shelter and mining sites ground to a halt. 
More: http://bit.ly/V7ruDy

Australian mining billionaire Clive Palmer is building a replica of the  Titanic. It hopes to set sail on its maiden voyage in 2016. 

Would you buy a ticket on it? Or are you too superstitious?

Full story: http://bit.ly/YBFIMZ

Graffiti artists from across Europe are joining Thai artists in Bangkok for the city's first ever street art festival. 
More: http://bit.ly/VFoGMX

"The real aim was to do something colourful - something positive, if it's the good word. We hope that the people will look at it with a smile. That to us, is the most important." 
            - French artist Nicolas Barrone.
Not a bad view to wake up to! What does your morning look like?   Thanks to ABC Tropical North for the gorgeous photo.

The Asian English Olympics took place recently at Binus University in Jakarta. Individuals compete across 6 fields, including Scrabble. 

What event would you include in the English Olympics?

Today is International Mother Language Day.

What's your mother tongue or ancestral language? Do you still speak it? Say hello to us in the comments and don't forget to mention which language it is!
Thousands of people gather in Melbourne's Sidney Myer Music Bowl for a free outdoor performance of the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra

American-Australian couple Steve and Susi Evans hold the photos that Rev. Sun Myung Moon used to match them for marriage in 1992.

They will join millions worldwide for a marriage re-dedication ceremony February 23, one of the first since the leader of the movement some call the 'Moonies' died last September. 

Hear their conversation with Phil Kafcaloudes: http://bit.ly/WO6LmI

A New Zealand study says children who watch very large amounts of television are more likely to have criminal convictions and be aggressive as adults.

If you have children, do you put a limit on how much TV they watch?  
Read more: http://bit.ly/VGCucJ

Confusing labels can hide the fact that frozen foods from New Zealand may actually be grown in China, vegetable growers there are saying.

Do you trust the labels on your food?  More: http://bit.ly/11RCYPs

One Billion Rising - Jakarta. About two hundred people dance together in the courtyard of the National Monument (Monas), Jakarta. This action is part of a global movement of One Billion Rising, which was held simultaneously around the world as part of a campaign to stop violence against women.  (Photo: Nur Iffah Arifah)

February 14 is more than just Valentine's Day. It's also the day when millions of people around the world are coming together to call for an end to violence against women. It's global movement in more than 200 countries. The dancing flash mob hit Melbourne's streets today.
Have you ever wondered where Radio Australia comes from? To celebrate World Radio Day, we travelled to the central Victorian town of Shepparton to visit Radio Australia's transmission site.

Happy World Radio Day!

Where in the world do you listen to Radio Australia?

Thousands of people packed Hobart's docks for the Tasmanian city's wooden boat festival.

Thanks to Mark Clemens for the photo.
The Sydney suburb of Bankstown plays host to a multicultural celebration of Lunar New Year. (Photos by Do Duc Anh)
Thousands of Melburnians come together to celebrate the beginning of the Year of the Snake
Lions hit the stage and cameras start flashing in Melbourne's Chinatown as New Year celebrations get started.

Welcome the Year of the Snake! 

The snake is the sixth sign in the Chinese zodiac and symbolises wisdom, caution and romance. Find out what the new year has in store for you: http://bit.ly/WxXiRH

The caretaker of Darwin's Chinese Temple, Dennis Low, lights incense. 

Discover the mystical story behind Darwin's Chinese Temple here: http://bit.ly/XrXwWz

(Photo by Clare Rawlinson)

Each year fruit and vegies are grown in special shapes as gifts for Tet in Vietnam. This square melon symbolises the Earth. 
More pictures here: http://bit.ly/14GUy6D
The markets in Melbourne's Little Saigon are getting busy as people prepare to welcome the Year of the Snake. (Photos by Hanh Tran)

Meet Robohand. It's a prosthetic hand that can be made with a 3D printer. The designers have put it in the public domain, meaning it's accessible to people who can't afford expensive commercial alternatives. It could change a lot of lives.  

Hear more: http://bit.ly/11o5hEV

It's official ... mowing the lawn is good for the brain!  That's the findings of researchers who have been looking at how the smell of cut grass reduces stress.  

Hear what Dr Judith Reinhard told Phil Kafkaloudes:  http://bit.ly/11mnYcg, and thanks to Justin Huntsdale from ABC Local for this photo.
Cambodia will today hold an elaborate cremation ceremony for its revered former king Norodom Sihanouk, part of a week-long funeral. Full story: http://bit.ly/Uke5sK

Free ride? A bird balances on the king post of a hang glider as it flies over Stanwell Park, south of Sydney.

Thanks to audience member Vera Harper for this photo.

What on earth is this pelican doing 1000 kilometres from the sea? It was spotted near the South Australian and Northern Territory border. 

Alice Springs-based bird expert Chris Watson says while the sightings are unusual, pelicans do cover huge distances inland to breed. More: http://bit.ly/WVtzjf

Thanks to Julie Smith who snapped this picture of the pelican wandering around town.

It's not just a truck, it's a letterbox!

Photographer Manz said, 'After stopping to take a photo of this cool little letterbox we had a chat with the owners and it happens to be a replica of one of their own trucks made by a local bloke in the town.'

This photo is a part of ABC Open's Snapped project: http://bit.ly/W3p6vb

Any idea what this might be?

It's a phenomenon called bioluminescence. Micro organisms make the lake appear to 'glow in the dark'. It's caused when there is a large input of nutrients into the lakes from natural events like bushfires and floods.

Find out more about it here: http://bit.ly/YDh6FQ

Thanks to Phil Hart for this amazing photo.

A couple of days ago, we asked you if Australia should have a new flag, and some of you responded. 

This is Andrew Widdis' suggestion. He says it's "Simple, uniquely Australian. Inclusive of all who call Australia home."

More of your suggestions here: http://bit.ly/10QnIRD

Inundated ... pilot John McDermott, who is helping airlift flood-affected people in Bundaberg, Queensland sent in this photo.

Our rolling news channel ABC24 is now available to viewers outside Australia. Watch our live coverage on: http://www.abc.net.au/news/abcnews24/
http://bit.ly/dwWpKG

Join Radio Australia and triple j as we count down the hottest 100 songs of 2012!  Listen now: http://bit.ly/GQ1iXR

What was your favourite song this year?
Happy Australia Day! Follow all of our coverage of related events and news here: http://bit.ly/xLB0Cu

Is this the Asian Century... of tennis? Our Tracee Hutchison takes a look at the rise of Li Na, and the millions of boys and girls who are poised to follow in her footsteps. 

Full story: http://bit.ly/14fQPfX

Two youthful kangaroos play fight on Mount Taylor in Canberra. 

What do you think they're thinking? Send us your caption! 

Thanks to David Flannery for this photo.
Widespread flooding across the Indonesian capital has forced more than 10,000 people to flee their homes and left two people dead. Full story: http://bit.ly/W7OhuP (Photos by Laban Laisila)

Sina is a 13-year-old from Beijing who is one of the six ballkids from China taking part in the Australian Open. She and her chaperone, Kai Yin, joined Phil Kafcaloudes on air today.

Sina's favourite tennis player is Novak Djokovic, who won the China Open this year. She said he was really nice and that when she had her photo taken with him, he even said 'thank you' in Chinese.
A small plane flies towards the cloud of smoke rising from a bushfire at Coonabarabran in northern New South Wales. Thanks to audience member Anna Tenne for the photo.

Have you voted in triple j's Hottest 100 yet? It's the world's biggest musical democracy, choosing the best songs of the year. We'll be bringing the countdown to your airwaves on Australia Day.

What was your favourite song this year?
Vote: http://bit.ly/Vm1JMv
Images from the 2013 Australian Open.

Could people migrating from India more than 4,000 years ago have introduced the dingo to Australia? 

New research suggests they might be linked - well before the arrival of Europeans in Australia in the 1700s. 

More: http://bit.ly/X9SJcc

(Photo by mstephens7)

Wild lions are now extinct in 25 African countries. In an effort to help save them, Zambia has become the latest country to ban lion hunting. 

Is it too late to save them?   More: http://bit.ly/VFeioP

(Flickr photo by puliarf)
Images from the 2013 Australian Open.

A six-month ban on carrying firearms has begun in the Philippines, after a series of shooting deaths so far this year. 

This comes at the same time as news that Australians have imported more than 1 million guns over the past 10 years - but the number of people killed by guns has been cut in half. 

What's your take on gun control?

More on the Philippines: http://bit.ly/VU5kn7
More on Australia: http://bit.ly/W346Tv

People in Beijing are being warned that air pollution has reached levels that are hazardous to human health. 

Dense smog covers the city and has hidden the sun. 

Radio Australia's Tracee Hutchison found the air in Beijing hard to breathe when she was there last year - especially because she is asthmatic. 

Full story: http://bit.ly/TU5DxF

Thanks to René Spaargaren for this impressive picture of a metre-long pike that had died with a 75cm zander in its mouth in the Netherlands last week. 

The pike attacked the zander but couldn't release it because the pike's teeth face backwards.

A new study has found that a staggering 50 per cent of the world's food goes to waste.

Does the figure surprise you? How much food do you waste?

Read more: http://bit.ly/VozHT9

Big sheep, big guitar and even a big mango! All sights to be seen driving around Australia. What's the best/strangest/most beautiful statue or monument you've seen in your travels?

Check out the other big things seen by ABC Open and triple j Road Trip Relay travellers across Australia: http://abc.net.au/triplej/roadtriprelay/

Polish prosecutors are investigating Swedish artist Carl Michael von Hausswolff's claim that he used the ashes of people killed in the Holocaust in one of his paintings.

He says the black-and-white painting represents the suffering of the victims. Prosecutors are investigating charges of desecration of the dead or stealing human remains.

(Photo of the artist from Wikimedia)

Stand behind the orange line! Thanks to Robert Wilhelm for sharing this photo of Melbourne's Southern Cross railway station with Radio Australia - My World. 

We're challenging people to take photos of streets where they live and share them with us. Have you shown us your street yet?

Spontaneous dancing took over the small island of Milingimbi in Australia's far north. And it didn't stop for seven days - from Christmas to New Year's Day.

Hundreds of people took turns dancing, creating a "healing sense of joy" for the grief-stricken Indigenous community.  More: http://bit.ly/UDOCdv

Adelaide Zoo's Sumatran tiger Tuan enjoys some extra cold meat. Animals have been given blocks of ice with their favourite foods to help them stay cool during the heatwave. 

What's your favourite way to stay cool?

Read more: http://bit.ly/Xd8fpT

Residents of Murdunna, south-east of Hobart, take shelter from bushfires which have devastated entire communities in Tasmania. Thousands of people are stranded and about 100 are still unaccounted for as the fires continue to burn.

Full story: http://bit.ly/UAnh8s

(Photo: Audience submitted)

Have you ever seen black swans? ReelMcCoy shared this image with ABC Environment. 

More great photos here: http://bit.ly/Z0MAjU

Jaik Berg from the Cook Islands is the winner of Pacific Break 2012, our music competition for the Pacific. He arrived in Australia today with his mum Lyza.  Jaik's prize is a week in Melbourne recording, performing and learning from music industry professionals. 

Jaik is pictured at the airport earlier today with his mum and Pacific Break coordinator Sally McMahon.  Stay with us all week for updates on Jaik's adventures in Australia.

status_message:
Today is 37 years since the end of the Vietnam War, and some wounds still need to heal. In Vietnam, April 30 is celebrated as Liberation Day or Reunification Day. But among Vietnamese refugees overseas, April 30 can be referred to as Black April and commemorates the fall of Saigon.

So how do young Vietnamese people both inside and outside of Vietnam feel about the day?
Read full story (in Vietnamese) here: http://bit.ly/In1y1c

status_message:
For Pacific Island nations like Kiribati, the problem is too much water - sea water eating up their coastline thanks to rising sea levels. 

What is the biggest water issue in your life? Is it access to clean water? Is it trying to ration the water that you have?

Pearson Vetuna, broadcaster with Tok Pisin, shares his thoughts on World Water Day.

"Last night we asked listeners if celebrating water in a special world water day was important to them. We received SMS responses from PNG, Solomon Islands and Vanuatu that indicated people are passionately aware of the importance of water to life. The responses also indicated that without water, there's no life.
...
When I was a boy growing up, long before plastic bottles and buckets, my folks used to carry and store water from wells and underground water dripping out of limestone, in long bamboo trunks. Water stored in this way was always refreshingly cool.

For my family and I, we have simple rules in the house about shorter showers, no running tap when brushing teeth, running grey water tubes from the washing machine to the lawn and veggie garden.

It's important to think that, one doesn't put up rules like these because there are water restrictions in Melbourne but rather because we know ourselves that water is important to life and as listeners told us last night, no water no life."

"We know they're trying to exercise more control over lawyers, but does anyone seriously believe that requiring lawyers to mouth these words is somehow going to make them more loyal to the party?" - Donald Clarke, Chinese law specialist

In the Pacific, water is isn't just a resource. It's also a large part of the culture.  Larry Raigetal tells Heather Jarvis about a canoe-building project that is helping young people from the outer island of Lamotrek learn their traditional home-island skills and gain cultural knowledge and pride along the way.
link_name: Canoes connect outer island youth back to their culture

status_message: Today is World Water Day. In the area of Sawah Besar, Jakarta, people can no longer drink water from the wells due to salt water intrusion. So they have to queue every day to buy clean water from people like Mulyadi - a water seller for the past 32 years.

Today is World Water Day. In the area of Sawah Besar, Jakarta, people can no longer drink water from the wells due to salt water intrusion. The locals do not have access to piped water to their houses, so they have to queue every day to buy clean water from people like Mulyadi - a water seller for the past 32 years.

Mulyadi, 60, is a water-seller in Jakarta, Indonesia. He has been selling water for 32 years. His starts selling water at 5 am and works until 8 pm. In the average day, he sells 15 buckets. Photo by Denny Herlambang.

Tok Pisin journalist and presenter Kenya Kala grew up all over PNG, in Kainantu, Wau, Lae and Port Moresby.

"Growing up we had just a river so we had to dig for water wells and people knew they had to boil water, but I remember using the water wells and trying to get clean water in the bucket. 

"The issue today is water and food security. Water is food. And I suppose we're looking at the health side of water this time because a lot of mothers don't know how to manage water and give clean safe water to children."
Did you know it takes 15,000 litres of water to produce one kilogram of beef?

From flooding to drought, rising sea levels to depleted clean water supplies, water affects each single one of the 7 billion people on this planet. Today is World Water Day. What is the biggest water issue affecting you where you live?
(Photo by Sheree Enguell)

The Queensland Floods Commission has released its long-awaited report into last year's massive floods.
