status_message: Sometimes a picture really is worth a thousand words. See some of the best photos of the past year as chosen by the 2012 World Press Photo awards.

Happy Valentine's Day. To celebrate, ABC Radio National asked some well-known Australians about their favourite love poems. Listen to them all and share them with the ones you love. Do you have a favourite of your own?

A final photo to mark World Radio Day on February 13th. Thanks to everyone who contributed their stories across the day. This photo was sent to our new Indonesian Facebook page and is from Muhammad Yusuf, a passionate listener in West Sulawesi. He takes his shortwave transmitter everywhere. In the picture, he's hanging his transmitter on a washing line to get a clearer signal. Apparently, this method works!

Photos from Radio Australia for World Radio Day. Since its launch more than a century ago, radio has shown itself to be not only one of humanity's most useful inventions, but also the most universal media, being free and accessible to the majority of the world's population.  On February 13 the ABC is helping to celebrate World Radio Day, an initiative from UNESCO.
We've just launched our new Facebook page for Indonesia.  Join the conversation in Bahasa Indonesia at: http://www.facebook.com/RadioAustraliaIndonesia
Villagers gather around to listen to a Radio Australia broadcast in Eastern Indonesia in 1966. We have been broadcasting into Indonesia now for over 70 years.
Amazing photo taken in the Queensland town of St George, where severe flooding has forced people to evacuate their homes this week.

How important is radio in your life?  Monday February 13 is World Radio Day.  It is a UNESCO intiative and Radio Australia is getting behind it. Listen to some of our team talk about why they love radio and feel free to share your thoughts and stories below.

Terrible tragedy in PNG today. A ferry, the MV Rabaul Queen, disappeared while travelling from Kimbe, on the island of New Britain, to Lae, on PNG's mainland. Australia is helping with the rescue mission.
link_name: More than 200 rescued from sunk PNG ferry

status_message: Why don't more young women want a career in engineering or science? Marita Cheng is the Young Australian of the Year for 2012.  Born and raised in far North Queensland by her Chinese parents, Marita has dedicated herself to making a positive change to the low participation of women in the technology and engineering fields.
link_name: Interview with Young Australian of the Year

status_message: Photos from Australia Day celebrations, January 26, 2012.
Lunar New Year with Radio Australia and ABC Local Radio
Celebrations are underway in Australia for Lunar New Year 2012.
Lunar New Year festivities in Sydney. Photo: Jason Fang
Have you tried any of our Lunar New Year recipes yet? We'd love to know what you think about them!
Celebrations are underway in Australia for Lunar New Year 2012.
Gung hai fa choi, xin nian kuai le and chúc mừng nǎm mới from Radio Australia!
link_name: Happy Lunar New Year from Radio Australia

status_message: A lion dancer makes his way down the main thoroughfare in the Melbourne suburb of Springvale.
Lunar New Year with Radio Australia and ABC Local Radio

Today Radio Australia, together with ABC Local Radio is hosting a special three hour program – a celebration of the start of the Lunar New Year period. Tune in live on our website (http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/) and follow the highlights right here on our Facebook page.
Check out our recipes for Lunar New Year. Download them and share them with your friends!
Celebrations are underway in Australia for Lunar New Year 2012.

Lunar New Year celebrations have kicked off in Australia's Chinese and Vietnamese communities. We'll be marking the beginning of the Year of the Dragon with a live broadcast from celebrations around Australia this Sunday 22 January.
Lunar New Year Festival in the Melbourne suburb of Richmond. Photo: Xiaoning Mo

Are you encouraged by recent events in Burma?  A total of 651 prisoners have been slated for release under the latest amnesty.  And after nearly six decades of conflict Burma's government and the ethnic rebel group, the Karen National Union, have signed a ceasefire.  Australia is also easing sanctions against the country.

In recent years, many Australians have suffered loss as a result of natural disasters. Their personal and heartfelt stories are now featured in Aftermath, ABC Open's interactive online documentary created with affected communities. This past month marked the first anniversary of the devastating Queensland floods. Have you been affected or known people affected by natural disasters?
Photo: Acok Pettaruka

During a visit to Australia Fadly Arifuddin, lead vocalist of a top Indonesian rock band has been impressed by environmental projects being run by small community groups in Australia. After his performance at CERES, a community environment park in Melbourne, he told Radio Australia that environmental awareness can be raised through simple education and practical activities, starting in the family. Padi or "Paddy" in English is a famous Indonesian band. Their albums have sold in the millions. In 2007, two of their albums were named among the 150 Greatest Indonesian Albums of all times by Rolling Stone magazine. Fadly is also known as an environmental activist.

What's your New Year's resolution for 2012? We're running a series on popular resolutions and getting advise from professionals on how to stay true to them. Here's Luke Atkin from Quit Victoria giving useful tips on how to quit smoking.
Are we likely to see Malaysia and Nauru hosting offshore processing of asylum seekers for Australia in 2012?

link_name: North Korea's neighbours call emergency meetings after Kim's death

status_message: AFL stars Nic Naitanui and Israel Folau pass on some new skills to young footy players in the Pacific.

There is now a convention that prohibits the stockpiling and production of chemical weapons, but many countries are still struggling with controlling  chemical products that could be dangerous. Are you worried about these chemical products?

link_name: Tension rising in politically unstable PNG

status_message: Do you know that there have been more deaths caused by bee stings than shark bites? What animals are you afraid of, or think as dangerous?

The punk music fans were arrested as they were attending a concert to raise money for orphans. Their heads were shaved, and they were forced to bathe. Human rights activists are saying that these arrests breached human rights, since the punk fans didn't break any law. Do you think police and government have any rights to 'morally rehabilitate' citizens?

The leadership situation in PNG is still unclear, and Papua New Guineans are vigorously speaking out about the country's political impasse on social networking sites and other public fora, including with Radio Australia on this interview. Do you live in PNG, or have lived through a similar situation? Share your stories here!

Local media said a 75-year-old woman and two teenage boys died at the scene of the attack and said 123 people had been injured and taken to local hospitals. One of the injured was a baby who was reported to be in a critical condition.
link_name: Five killed in Belgium grenade attack

status_message: Papua New Guinea's Governor-General has refused to reinstate Sir Michael Somare as Prime Minister despite the Supreme Court's ruling, leaving the country in political deadlock.
link_name: PNG G-G refuses to reinstate Somare

status_message: If Suu Kyi is allowed to rejoin mainstream politics, how successful do you think she will be?
link_name: Suu Kyi closer to political comeback

status_message: Where do you stand on the result of the international climate change talks in Durban? Do you feel positive or negative about it?

Australia's longest running television soap opera included its newest neighbours, the Kapoor family from India. But there are positive as well as negative responses to this new addition, who were added to reflect the multicultural nature of the Australian society. Do you like watching Neighbours? What do you think of the new Indian family?
Our friends in ABC local radio in Sydney have just broken the world record for the longest one-on-one radio interview! It lasted for 24 hours. What kind of world records would you like to break?

An expert panel has found that the Australian constitution still retains clauses which could be harmful to the country's indigenous peoples. Do minority groups in your country get enough opportunities to be involved in politics or are there still barriers?
What do you think about this news from Tokelau? And have you got your own plan to be more sustainable in your energy consumption?
link_name: Tokelau to be first renewable energy nation

status_message: There have been reports that workers in a Malaysian plantation in Kalimantan were paid around 90 US dollars for each orangutan they killed as part of a program of pest control. Do you believe that there will ever be a balance between protecting economic developments and protecting nature?

Robert Luketic, an Australian director who made highly successful Hollywood films like Legally Blonde, shares some insights about how to be a successful film director and about a new mentorship opportunity for young Australians. He also talks about what he thinks is the best and the worst of Hollywood -what do you think is the best thing and the worst thing about Hollywood films?
The Indian government's proposal to censor Facebook and Twitter has been decried as a barrier on freedom of speech. Do you want to see any type of censorship at all for social media sites?

link_name: Amnesty urges Indonesia to respect Papuan human rights

status_message: What came to your mind when you heard this news? Has the world become safer or more dangerous after the 'war on terrorism'?
There are so many types of traditional music that we have lost or are losing. Can traditional music still survive in this globalised world?

Do you sometimes feel mosquitoes are more attracted to you than to other people? (If you do, you are probably right, according to this interviewee - including the problems faced by people who moved to another country)
The teenager is now back in Australia, and has managed to avoid the media crews who were waiting at the airport. Will he be able to return to normal life now?
link_name: Ordeal over as 'Bali boy' arrives home

status_message: Do you agree with the Australian Labor Party's endorsement to export uranium to India?
link_name: India uranium exports divides Australian Government

status_message: Sometimes it is difficult to know where and how the clothings you buy were made, including if they were made ethically (not using child workers, for example). Do you often wonder about this when you buy clothes?
link_name: Cambodia denies using jailhouse labour for profit

status_message: The new Corruption Perception Index has been published, and it shows that corruption is still a big problem in the Asia-Pacific region. How important is the reduction of corruption for you and your country?
link_name: International survey reveals corruption in Pacific nations

status_message: US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton is on a landmark visit to Burma. What's your reaction to the country's recent reforms?
link_name: Clinton's voyage to Burma a landmark affair

status_message: Radio Australia is broadcasting from Melbourne's renowned St Kilda Beach to celebrate the start of summer in Australia. Listen live on our website, check for highlights posted throughout the day and keep an eye on our Facebook for photos.

Today is not only the first day of summer in Australia (check out our photos -we'll keep on updating it with the latest photos today!), but also the World AIDS Day. Do you think there are still misinformed ideas about AIDS in your area?
link_name: World turns red for AIDS Day

status_message: What do you think is the best way to educate children about the danger of smoking, especially in a country like Indonesia where a high percentage of men smoke?
link_name: Bali bans cigarette advertising in schools

status_message: How did you go with Mo-vember? Many men would be relieved (or secretly sad) that they have to say goodbye to their moustaches -that they've grown to raise awareness about cancer and mental health for men. The staff of Australian High Commission have also shown their support for the campaign.

One of the most celebrated Australian author (best known for writing Schindler's Ark) Tom Keneally came to our studio to talk about Australian history and identity. If you have to use one word to describe Australians, what would it be?
Do you prefer watching films from other countries or films from your own country?

A survey of children from 44 countries around the world shows that children in developing countries are more interested in becoming doctors and teachers than those living in developed countries who would rather become sports stars. What about your nephews/nieces/children -what are their hopes and aspirations?
Many rivers around the world are facing challenges. Unsustainable level of usage, pollution, overflow, and many others. What about the rivers around where you live? Are you worried about them?
link_name: Plan to rescue major Australian river system released

status_message: Happy Friday! This could be something to end your week on an inspiring note: the story of Kosal Khiev, a Cambodian-American who was deported to Cambodia (even though he grew up in the US). In this interview, he told us about his childhood alienation and his long stretch in tough US prisons where he discovered the spoken word poetry that's helped him turn his life around.

link_name: Two months jail for Bali teen

status_message: Today is White Ribbon Day, an Australian campaign to stop men's violence against women. Almost 20 thousand Australian men have taken the oath, including famous Australians like Kevin Rudd. Will you take the oath as well? What's the best way to reduce men's violence against women?

Around the region, we are still seeing many people moving into the city from villages. Many of these people have become a part of the urban poor, partly because of the harsh control put on them by the bureaucracy and the legal system in the cities, as well as due to corruption. The problem is complex, but what do you see as the way to help reduce poverty in the cities?

American Samoa football team (who, in 2001, was beaten by Australia with an international record scoreline of 31-0), have managed to record some thrilling victories recently. They won 2-1 over Tonga and 3-2 over Cook Islands. How much do you know about football in the Pacific? If you live in the Pacific, do you think it is becoming more popular? (And yes, of course, we mean associate football -or soccer, with round ball).
We have seen many street protests leading to real changes around the world recently. What do you think about this latest move from the Malaysian government to ban street protests?

From the tiny indigenous community of Wangkatjungka where hot winds sweep off the Great Sandy Desert, Australian aboriginal singer Olive Knight is now performing in snowy New York, among the glitters of Broadway. If you're a musician, where would you want to perform in?
Have you, or do you know anyone who have, stopped smoking? We'd love to hear your stories, and if you think plain packaging will make people less inclined to start smoking.
This is not the first time in Indonesia, and we have seen deaths in other sports events in other countries as well. What do you think is the core of the problem?
link_name: Two dead in SEA Games stampede

status_message: Do you think there is too much security measurements being implemented in airports, or do you think there is not enough security?
The clash is still continuing in Egypt after a violent weekend that killed at least 10 people. The protestors are demanding an end of the interim military government.
link_name: Deadly clashes continue in Cairo's Tahrir Square

status_message: A book on an East Timorese traditional story is helping to boost literacy for children across East Timor. What about your area -do you have a favourite traditional story that you can share?
Do you like seafood? If you do, how much do you think about the environmental issues surrounding the seafood industry?
Have you been following the announcements made by US President Barack Obama during his visit to Australia? You can catch up on the latest on the Radio Australia News site.
link_name: Obama signals new US focus on Asia-Pacific

status_message: China is not happy with the 'military build-up' of the US military in Australia. This military build-up includes up to 2,500 US marines to be stationed in Darwin for six months a year by 2017. Do you think this strengthening of US-Australia military ties is good for the Asia-Pacific region?
The arts can apparently help stimulate the minds of people living with dementia. What do you do to keep your mind active and healthy?

How would you feel if a woman managed your male national sports team? In Samoa, a woman is applying for a job as the national rugby team manager. Robina Siteine-Tua, who is a wife and manager of the boxer, David Tua, thinks that Samoan rugby could benefit from having a woman at the reigns.
Do you think the Australian Prime Minister's push to reverse her Labor Party's long-standing ban on selling uranium to India is a good idea?
link_name: Australia warned against selling uranium to India

status_message: Are you worried about the pace of development in your country, and how it is changing your society?
link_name: Anger over forced demolitions in China

status_message: Did you know that Jackie Chan used to live in Canberra, and that there is a story that he got 'Jackie' as a nickname when he was working as a builder in Australia? What's your favourite Jackie Chan film?
SEA Games is opening tonight in Jakarta and Palembang, Indonesia. Which countries do you think are the favourites to top the gold medal tally this time?

The Fest' Napuan cultural festival is on at the moment in Port Vila, Vanuatu.  The winner of our Pacific Break 2011 music competition will be performing on Friday and Saturday night as part of their prize.  They're from Fiji and they are called BSQ.  The group gave up some of their spare time to meet students from a school on Ifira Island and came away with some new fans.  Have a listen to Clem's report on the link below.
link_name: Pacific Break - BSQ visits Ifira Secondary School

status_message: Dozens of people are still trapped in collapsed buildings in this province, which is still reeling from another earthquake on October 23rd which killed more than 600.
link_name: Three dead, scores trapped after second Turkey earthquake

status_message: There are so many books, films, and games that explore the experiences of being soldiers in war. But have you ever thought about how soldiers are trained to kill and the moral questions that they have to face? This interview explores those questions.
This is the third time Afghan soldiers have wounded or killed Australian soldiers this year. Do you agree that this reveals a 'systemic problem' within the Afghan military?
link_name: Afghan soldier shoots three Australian Diggers

status_message: After a long battle, Australia now will have carbon tax, planned to take effect mid next year. What do you think about this?
link_name: Vote approves carbon tax for Australia

status_message: Parts of the Great Wall of China are facing collapse as a result of illegal mining. Whose responsibility should it be to protect UNESCO-listed World Heritage Sites?
Are you worried about the number of world's population and our ability to support this number of people?

Many current technological research are looking at the possibility of machines that can 'read' people's mind and body language. This can be used to support people with disabilities or to prevent road accidents. If you can have a mind-reading machine, what would you use it for?
Besides this case, there are other examples of bribery in sports around the world. What do you think needs to be done to reduce bribery in sports?
link_name: Jail for Pakistan cricketers in bribes case

status_message: Have you been affected by the flood in Cambodia and Thailand?
link_name: Aid gets through to Cambodia flood victims

status_message: This incident has put the issue of asylum seekers back in the spotlight of Australian media and politics. But do you think the discussion and debates that you've read in the media have given you and your friends enough understanding and information about the issue?
link_name: Indonesia may call off search for asylum boat missing

status_message: While many Australians were celebrating the Melbourne Cup, many in India enjoyed the country's first Formula One race. Are you a fan of Formula One races?
link_name: Formula One off and racing in India

status_message: People who whistle are very rarely grumpy according to former World Champion Whistler Asim Gorashi. When he left his Sudanese homeland eight years ago he brought with him to Australia a very special talent.   He told Phil Kafcaloudes that his unique style of whistling, which he perfected while working farmland, has won him some high profile fans.

Will you stop for 'the race that stops a nation'? Radio Australia will broadcast the Melbourne Cup live today at 12 noon in Beijing, 11am in Jakarta, 2pm in Port Moresby, and 5pm in Suva. Listen to it streaming online on www.radioaustralia.net.au
link_name: Melburnians turn out for annual Cup parade

status_message: Qantas has now been ordered to continue its operation -but is it too late? Will you still fly with Qantas in the near future?
link_name: Qantas ordered back into the skies

status_message: Has the grounding of the Qantas fleet eroded trust in the airline? Will this have a lasting impact on their local and international reputation?
link_name: Irate passengers vow to abandon Qantas
Three Australian soldiers killed in Afghanistan

status_message: Big story breaking tonight: Australian airline Qantas has grounded its entire fleet, disrupting both domestic and international flights. In total 108 aircraft will be grounded indefinitely in 22 airports around the world. Have you been affected by this? We'd be keen to hear your story or reaction to these events.
What do you think the Commonwealth heads of government should focus their energies on in the coming years? Are you hoping for reforms to be agreed upon at this year's meeting?
link_name: Time for change: Australian leader urges Commonwealth heads

status_message: The ABC has obtained video which reportedly shows the aftermath of a crackdown by Indonesian troops at an independence rally in the province of West Papua.
link_name: Video shows aftermath of Papua crackdown

status_message: Vietnam has lost its battle to save one of its iconic species, the Javan Rhinoceros. Are animals in your area under threat? What can be done to promote conservation?
Is your area affected by frequent flooding? How does flooding impact your life?
link_name: Thai floods close second Bangkok airport

status_message: With the sun shining, Australia's head of state, Queen Elizabeth II and her husband Prince Philip, took a four-hour tour of Melbourne.  The Queen officially opened the new $1 billion Royal Children's Hospital and met with a small group of critically ill children, their families and hospital staff.  Well wishers came to meet her as she passed by on a specially designed tram. Our Radio Australia team were there to take some photos.

Nobel winner Professor Françoise Barré-Sinoussi says HIV/AIDS can be completely eradicated by 2050, but the main problem is discrimination. Do you still see discrimination towards HIV/AIDS sufferers in your culture?

On Wednesday several of our Asian language teams will be covering the Queen's visit to Melbourne. You can follow proceedings throughout the day on our website: http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/. Is your country part of the Commonwealth of Nations? Do you follow royal goings-on?

Australian Prime Minister Julia Gillard is preparing to host this week's Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Perth. The Government's handling of asylum seeker policy and live exports has been criticised for damaging Australia's reputation in the region. But she's told Radio Australia the country's ties with its regional neighbours are strong.
link_name: Regional relations strong, says Australian PM

status_message: The United Nations estimates up to a third of North Korean children under five are malnourished. What do you hope to see the United Nations do for North Korea?
If scientists created a pill that would let you live to be 150 years old, would you take it?
The earthquake has caused the collapse of around 50 buildings in the city of Van, and there are fears that many are still trapped in the rubble.
link_name: Hundreds feared dead in Turkey quake

status_message: New Zealand victorious in the 2011 Rugby World Cup. Are you impressed by the result? Would you have picked them to win at the start of the tournament?
link_name: All Blacks hang on for RWC glory

status_message: In the Australian city of Melbourne, an "Occupy" anti-greed protest has been broken up by police. Inspired by the "Occupy Wall Street" movement in the US, similar protests have been taking place worldwide. Are there "Occupy" events taking place in your neck of the woods?
Libya's new leaders have confirmed that Moamar Gaddafi has been killed by fighters who overran his hometown of Sirte.
link_name: Gaddafi dead as home town captured

status_message: In Australia, the Queen remains a prominent figurehead. Hundreds of well-wishers flocked to Canberra's Lake Burley Griffin today to catch a glimpse of the Queen on the first full day of her Australian visit. Are monarchs still important where you are?
link_name: Queen wows the crowds in Canberra

status_message: Reports from Indonesia's Papua province say military forces fired on participants of the Papuan People's Congress in Jayapura on Wednesday evening.

If you've been a carer, what difficulties have you faced, and what's got you through? Caring full-time for a sick, elderly or disabled partner or relative can be a difficult, lonely and overwhelming experience. Add in the stigma of HIV-AIDS, and the job can be even harder.

Bougainville-born artist Taloi Havini and Australian photographer Stuart Miller have collaborated to present a photographic exhibition that explores the impacts of conflict and mining on the island through portraits of young people.
A representative of the Red Cross has told Radio Australia's Connect Asia the flood situation in Thailand remains grim. Are you in an affected area?
link_name: SE Asia needs to prepare for floods, says Red Cross

status_message: How culturally diverse are schools in your area? Do you think it's important for children to experience different cultures at school?

Papua New Guinea's new Prime Minister Peter O'Neill recently visited Australia, hoping to revitalise the PNG Australia partnership. What are your thoughts on the first two months of the O'Neill prime ministership?
link_name: Peter O'Neill, PNG Prime Minister - Interview with Australia Network

status_message: What's your reaction to the "Occupy Wall Street" movement and the weekend's global protests?
Did you watch the match tonight? Do the All Blacks have what it takes to go all the way?
link_name: All Blacks batter Wallabies to reach final

status_message: Southeast Asia is experiencing some of the worst floods in more than a decade. Have the floods affected your area? An Australian visiting Cambodia took these photos and shared them with ABC News.
link_name: Eyewitness account of the Cambodian floods

status_message: After much deliberation, Fiji's BSQ has been crowned the 2011 winner of our music competition Pacific Break.  The five-piece group from Suva took the prize for their infectious hip-hop dance track 'Rue Ele Ele Remix feat. NeMoney.' You can hear from the group and download their winning song below.
link_name: Radio Australia - BSQ wins Pacific Break 2011!

status_message: The Australian Government's bill, designed to secure the future of offshore processing, has hit another snag. In lieu of a debate in parliament, we'd like to know what you think about the proposed amendments.

Burma has freed some of its most prominent dissidents as part of a mass amnesty which will see more than 6,000 people released from the country's jails. More prisoners are expected to be released in the coming days.
How much power do young people have over the landscape of politics in Asia and Pacific?

We are getting set to announce the winner for Pacific Break 2011 - our annual competition to unearth musical talent in the Pacific.  Check out below what some of our judges thought about the songs this year. And tune in tomorrow afternoon across the Pacific during Isabelle's show to hear who wins!
link_name: A sneak peak at the judge's picks for Pacific Break 2011

status_message: Today marks nine years after the 2002 Bali bombing which killed more than 200 people in Indonesia. Do you think we have more understanding of the causes and problems of terrorism since then, especially in Indonesia?
Do you agree that there has been a complacency in fighting AIDS?

There have been many new economic successes and challenges in the Asian region, but the old family pressures to get married haven't changed by much. Do you feel this pressure to marry needs to be reassessed in your culture?
How might the outcome of this case affect the relationship between Australia and Indonesia?
link_name: Australian PM phones teen arrested in Bali
Brave women share Nobel Peace Prize

status_message: Do you think new generations have enough understanding of the trauma of the past generations -who are often too traumatised to talk about it?
Can technology really help bring people out of poverty?
link_name: India says budget computer tablet will 'end the digital divide'

status_message: The products of his ideas have influenced the lifestyle of many people around Asia and the Pacific. Read about him, his legacy, and his vision in this link below.
This new exhibition shows the rich and diverse traditions of art in the Asian region. How important is art in your life?
link_name: Asian Flowers: A New Exhibition of Asian Art

status_message: What do you think is the root cause of the use of child labour in Asia?
Who is the Nobel Prize winner you admire the most?
link_name: Australian scientist joint Nobel Prize winner

status_message: What do you think about this idea of 'bamboo ceiling'? Is it still difficult for Asians to reach their aspirations in Australia?
link_name: Asian communities in Australia: Breaking through the bamboo ceiling

status_message: Do you think issues surrounding asylum seekers have been too politicised?

status_message: Today's the day! The clock is ticking. It's your last chance to submit your song for Pacific Break 2011.  And if you are a fan of Pacific music you can hear all of the entries so far on our blog.
After sweeping through Hong Kong and the Philippines, Typhoon Nesat is moving to Vietnam. How ready are you in facing destructive weather?
link_name: Typhoon Nesat closes in on Vietnam

status_message: South Korean and Japanese music and films are very popular in other Asian countries. Are you a fan as well?
Apparently there is a switch in airline cockpits that will make them flip upside down! If you were to invent an airplane, what buttons would you have in the cockpit?
link_name: ABC Radio Australia News:Stories:Japanese airliner almost flips after co-pilot flicks wrong switch

status_message: What do you think is the best way to prevent alcohol abuse, especially for young people in Asia?
What do you think of this new law? Should governments have more control over what NGOs are doing?
link_name: New Cambodian law 'cracking down' on NGOs

status_message: What are the challenges for women to serve in combat for your country?
link_name: Australian women cleared to serve in combat

status_message: Do you want to see more trees planted in your city? And do you have a favourite tree?
link_name: A Tree A Day A Life

status_message: When considering to study overseas, what is the most important factor to you in choosing a country?
Aside from financial contributions, what other contributions do you think international students give to a country?

The president of Indonesia has hoped that Indonesians won't have to be 'afraid or overly afraid' about terrorism in the future. How would you describe the condition now in Indonesia, after another bomb attack?
link_name: ABC Radio Australia News:Stories:Suicide bomber strikes Indonesian church

status_message: Almost half of the natural disasters of the past ten years were in the Asia Pacific region, according to a new Red Cross World Disasters Report.  How prepared are you for a natural disaster like a tsunami, earthquake or cyclone?

The death penalty is on the political agenda in the United States again following the execution of 42-year-old Troy Davis by lethal injection in the state of Georgia. But what do we know about the job of executioner?
What does La Niña mean to your region? This article explains what La Niña is and its predicted impact on the weather in Australia and the rest of the world.
link_name: She's back: What La Nina means for summer

status_message: Are these changes likely to make Australia more attractive to international students?
Burma's ten-month old civilian government has been urged to match promised political reform with a healthy and free media. Is press freedom an issue where you are?
Are the rich taxed fairly where you are? How do you define rich?
link_name: Tax hikes for rich in Obama's $3 trillion savings plan

status_message: An Australian actor and scriptwriter is behind three of the most popular drama series on television in Afghanistan.

These proposed new laws would let Australia's Immigration Minister send asylum seekers to third-party countries if it can be proved to parliament that to do so is in the public interest. The Prime Minister says changes made to the bill today will guarantee Australia honours its obligations under United Nations refugee conventions.  Are you satisfied with this assurance? Do you have any concerns about these proposed laws in Australia?
link_name: Australian PM pushes asylum law change

status_message: Indonesians are trying to promote bike-riding in Jakarta, but are meeting many challenges. Are you a bike rider? What are the challenges of riding bikes in the big cities of Asia?
link_name: Cycling Jakarta - from Australia Network News

status_message: What kind of political leadership would you like to see for a world that has seen economic crises recently?
link_name: IMF boss slams 'feeble leadership' for economic crisis

status_message: A new report by the UN has revealed that half of all of the world's amphetamine users live in East and South East Asia. Does this worry you?
Plastic products are everywhere. Are we too dependent on plastic? Is there any way that we can lessen this dependence?

The online media sector is going to be one of the focuses of a new inquiry in Australia. Has online media made you a better-informed citizen? Do you think governments should introduce measures to control online media?
There are signs that divorce rates are increasing in Asia. What do you see as important factors in this rise?
Do you think our societies are moving fast enough to tackle the challenges of climate change?
Do you enjoy reading e-books? Or do you prefer paper books?

Abdul Hekmat arrived in Australia as a refugee from Afghanistan in the year 2000. Now, he has been given a university scholarship, and is writing and working to help young people in Australia. What do you think we can learn from the experiences of refugees?

There are reports from China, India, and Indonesia, that there are a lack of affordable housing for young people in the big cities. How hard is it for young people in your country to find affordable houses or apartments?
The first time since 1973 that an Australian has claimed the women's crown at the US Open. And the first women's major winner since Evonne Goolagong Cawley at Wimbledon in 1980. Great effort Sam!
link_name: Australian Sam Stosur wins US Open tennis

status_message: Radio Australia broadcasters join Adelaine Ng to reflect on how they learnt about the events of September 11 and how their home countries responded in the wake of the attacks.  How did your  country change after 9/11?
Do you remember where you were during the events of September 11?
A survey shows that Australia, China, and India are showing high rates of sick leave because of stress at work. Do you have tips on how to reduce stress at work?
Our condolences go to Radio Australia listeners in India affected by this attack, which has been described as 'cowardly' by the Indian Prime Minister.
link_name: Bomb at Indian High Court kills 11

status_message: The Pacific is going sports mad with the Pacific Games in full swing in New Caledonia and the Rugby World Cup about to kick off. Have you been following the action?

Annual flooding is a big problem in our region. In Pakistan, 132 killed in this month's flooding. The livelihood of millions in cities like Jakarta and Manila are impacted by annual flooding  -do you think governments can do more to prevent or minimise the impact of flooding?
link_name: Pakistan devastated by month of floods

status_message: The Australian Government's border protection policies remain unclear because of the High Court's decision to overturn the Malaysian asylum seeker deal.  Should Australia just process asylum seeker claims in Australia?
link_name: NZ to discuss asylum issue with Australia

status_message: How much do you think the events of 9/11 have changed the world?
The Australian Council for International Development says there is still a lack of women in parliaments in the Pacific region. What difference would having more women in parliament make?
Listen to two Australian Muslim intellectuals sharing their experiences of hajj and discussing one of the most important historical figures in the Islamic world, Ibn Battuta.
Are you learning International Relations, or want to be a diplomat? What inspires you?
Australia maintains a high level alert for Indonesia due to a "very high threat of terrorist attack".  Is this fair, should Australia rethink its travel warning?
link_name: Indonesia unhappy with Australia's travel warnings

status_message: What do you think of the relationship between Asian and Pacific countries? Do we have enough knowledge about each other?
link_name: Pacific Island power recognised at UN

status_message: Have you ever been curious about the origin of the name of your country or city? What is it? If you don't know, drop a comment here, someone might be able to tell you.
Australia's High Court has overturned the Federal Government's asylum seeker swap deal with Malaysia.  More to come on our news website and on-air.
link_name: Australian High Court rules against Malaysia swap deal

status_message: Happy Eid al-Fitr today! Well, either today or yesterday, that is. How do you celebrate Eid al-Fitr in your area? Share your stories here, we'd love to hear from you.
link_name: Ramadan ends in confusion in Indonesia

status_message: Why do you choose to fly with one airline over another? What does a new airline have to do to win you over?
Do you believe in ghosts and spirits? Why?
Do you like telling and listening to ghost stories? Some of the most popular films produced in Asia are horror films.
What's your take on the debate surrounding the Khmer language? Is it dying? Are languages in your region "in crisis"?

Japan is set to have its sixth prime minister in five years. Do you think this is a positive step towards political stability or a distraction from rebuilding efforts in the earthquake and tsunami-damaged Tohoku region?

link_name: Highlights from the Opening Ceremony of the 14th Pacific Games

status_message: We'll take you live to the opening ceremony of the Pacific Games on Saturday evening, on our Pacific radio streams, during breaks in the NRL. Join us from 7pm Sydney time (8pm Noumea, 9pm Suva). Information on how to listen and connect with our coverage on facebook and twitter in the link below.
Do you think governments should be responsible to provide for the nutrition and physical well-being of students?
link_name: Free lunch for South Korea's schoolkids

status_message: Towards the end of the interview, Pauline Nguyen talks about her restaurant's "sustainability philosophy." How important is environmental sustainability in your choices of food consumption and restaurants?
Can a traditional social system live harmoniously with the needs of modern developments and human rights?
The Homeless World Cup has started! Can sports be useful to tackle social problems?

Terrible and sad news out of Brisbane overnight. Details still coming through but neighbours say the two families living in the home were from Tonga. Our thoughts with the families and loved ones of those who died.
link_name: Pacific Islanders feared dead in Brisbane house fire

status_message: After rioters in Britain used the internet to coordinate their protests, the English Prime Minister wants to have more control over social media. How do you think governments should deal with social media?
link_name: China, England, and Social Media censorship

status_message: Like Australia, same-sex unions are not recognized legally in Taiwan.  Do you think it's time for countries to consider legalising same-sex marriage? Respond to our poll, and add your thoughts in the comments.
We are seeing more and more supermarkets in cities in Asia Pacific. Do you prefer shopping in a supermarket or a traditional market?
ABC cameraman John Bean had a soft spot for Papua New Guinea. And many in Port Moresby will remember his gentle kindness.

Three Australian newsmen from the ABC are feared dead in a helicopter accident, and the ABC managing director, Mark Scott, said that "this has been the longest of nights and we fear it will be the saddest of days."
link_name: Australian news crew feared dead in chopper crash

status_message: It might have been cold and rainy, but these Indonesian students warmed the hearts in Melbourne with their flag-raising spirit. Check out the photos on Rantang, our Indonesian blog page.

A group of Indonesians and Australians have been working together for a decade to help solve a toilet shortage in some areas in Indonesia. Listen to the interview here and tell us what you think about this project!
In many Asian cities, things like traffic and pollution can discourage us from finding entertainment outdoors or doing physical exercise. Do you find it hard to get away from watching television?
Happy 66th Independence Day for Indonesia! What does being independent mean to you?

Qantas is planning to launch a new Asia-based premium airline which will not carry the Qantas brand and it is also launching Jetstar Japan.  Many major international routes will be scrapped and thousands of jobs lost.

CEO Alan Joyce says the changes were vital if Qantas was to carry out the "fundamental change" needed to ensure its survival.   Do you agree, is this the right move for the iconic airline?
link_name: Jobs to go as Qantas flies into Asia

status_message: What can be done about wealth divides in developing countries?
Is Malaria still a problem in your part of the world?
Nobel prize winner in economics, Michael Spence, said that the economic growth in developing worlds is vulnerable. Do you agree with him?
What can a society do to minimise emotional stress during financial crises?

Radio Australia supports the ABC East Africa Appeal.

The worst drought in 60 years is affecting people across the East and Horn of Africa. The combination of the drought and ongoing conflict has resulted in the UN declaring famine in parts of Somalia. This is an extraordinary crisis.

Help provide food, shelter and medical care to thousands of families http://ow.ly/60sDx
Are you worried about deforestation in your part of the world?

status_message: What do you think of the Australian soccer team? Do you have a favourite Australian player?

status_message: Do you have or want a tattoo? What does it represent to you?

Graeme Innes suggests that Australia suffers not from zero tolerance of racism, but zero acknowledgement of racism. Do you agree with his assessment of Australia, and what can you tell us about the state of race relations where you are?
Are you surprised by the volatility of the riots in England?
An Australian musician has been exploring the language and the soundscape of Shanghai to create music. Is music a good way to create cultural understanding?

Are institutional universities able to face the challenges of the 21st century? Do you think that the idea of an 'urmadic university' – a social network of people interested in exchanging ideas and working together on issues of sustainability – could work better?
What's the best way to protect children who are fleeing from wars, many of whom are unaccompanied?
Are you worried that the recent global market losses will have an impact on your personal financial situation?
A horror night on Wall Street, European markets down and losses in our region too.  Could we be heading into another global recession?

status_message: How should Australian and Malaysian governments deal with child asylum seekers?
link_name: UN warns of children's trauma in Malaysian deal

status_message: Do you think Australia is a good place for international students to live and study? Why are student visa applications to Australia in decline?
Trains are making a comeback around the world. Are you a fan of travelling by trains? Why?
Australia has Ned Kelly, Indonesia has Si Pitung, while China has Song Jiang (who inspired one of the great classics of Chinese literature). Why are we attracted to outlaws?

In Indonesia, there is a plan to use a colour system to ease traffic congestion, where only cars of certain colours are allowed to travel on certain days. Is this going to work? What's the best way to ease traffic?
What's your reaction to the events in Papua New Guinea's parliament today?
Do you think showing videos of asylum seekers would deter the practices of people smuggling?
link_name: Malaysia swap to be shown on YouTube

status_message: Do you think Yingluck Shinawatra will bring stability to Thailand?
A pilot program to raise awareness about cyber safety has begun in the tiny Pacific nation of Niue. How safe do you feel online?

Have you changed the way you shop? Do you spend less in shops and more online? Australian consumers are spending less, and there are doubts that the pre-Global Financial Crisis spending boom will return. Is consumerism dead?
Now that China's basketball superstar, Yao Ming has retired, will we see another NBA all-star from Asia (or the Pacific)?
link_name: ABC Radio Australia News:Stories:End of the 'Ming Dynasty'

status_message: Check out some of the best new unsigned music from the Pacific.

status_message: "Wantok system should not be used as an excuse for corruption or abuses of power." What do you think of this statement by Bishop? ('Wantok' roughly means 'kinship'.)
What is your opinion on Australia's relationship with Asian countries? Do you think increasing Asian history classes at Australian schools will improve relations?
Are you worried about food prices and availability in the future?
Can you really measure how happy the people in a country are?  What would you do to make people happier?
Do you think there are already too many cars on the road?
Australia's Prime Minister says this will "smash the business model of people smugglers" in the region.  Do you agree?

Australians are celebrating Cadel Evans' victory in Tour de France, while Indonesians are optimistic after a draw in an away football match with Turkmenistan. How important are sports achievements for the well-being of your country?
Has music brought you closer to others? Musicians Without Borders, a global movement based in The Netherlands, promotes unity through music.

The United Nations has declared a famine in Somalia. UN humanitarian coordinator for Somalia, Mark Bowden says "If we don't act now, famine will spread to all eight regions of southern Somalia within two months."

Do you drink coffee? Word is that Papua New Guineans rarely drink coffee despite the fact that their country produces some of the best coffee in the world. When they do drink coffee, they prefer instant rather than their locally produced beans. What's wrong? Why aren't Papua New Guineans great coffee drinkers?
﻿A staggering number of prisoners die in their first year of release from Australian jails, with suicide and drug overdoses the main causes. Do we need to reform the prison system?
What do you think is the best way to tackle corruption? In Papua New Guinea, a top-ranking cop has asked people to stop offering bribes to police officers.
link_name: PNG top cop targets bribery culture

status_message: Leadership, according to this writer and business coach, is 'not a lonely job, but a solitary job'. What do you think being a leader means?

After seeing her popularity decline in recent opinion polls, the Australian Prime Minister says that "Politics is a marathon, it's not a sprint, and democracy's not one long opinion poll." Do you agree?
link_name: Australian PM suffers dip in popularity

status_message: In Australia, there is currently a debate about whether more regulation of the media is required. Should governments have more control over media in your country?
Miru Kim explores art by photographing herself near famous landmarks, nude. What do you think is the role of art in understanding your surroundings?

After waiting for more than 10 years, Indonesian villagers can now take on Exxon Mobil for alleged rape, torture and murder by soldiers hired as security guards by the oil giant. Do you think this will damage US-Indonesia relations?
Young Malaysians are playing an important part in 'Bersih 2.0', a civil society movement trying to call for reforms in Malaysia. Do you think they will be successful?
A watercolour painting of Dalai Lama, sent by Slim Angus from Biri Island in The Philippines.
Has the phone hacking scandal in the United Kingdom made you question your level of trust in the media?
link_name: UK scandal raises fears of Australian hacking

status_message: The rate of diabetes has doubled since 1980 in the world. In Asia, many who have diabetes are young. What is the best way to prevent this illness?
The earth's population has grown by about 2 billion since 1987, and now there are questions about the planet's ability to cope. Are you worried about the population boom?
Australia has unveiled an ambitious carbon tax plan. Do you think carbon tax is the best way to tackle climate change?
After several years of intense debate, the Australian Government will finally unveil its plan to price carbon on Sunday.
Do you think there's enough discussion about cruelty towards animals in your country?
Do you see much Indigenous Australian art in your neck of the woods? A gallery in Malaysia specialising in art from emerging regions and movements is featuring work by artists from Elcho Island.
What do you think is the best way to learn how to forgive?
It may sound morbid, but have you thought about what you'll wear to your funeral? Phil Kafcaloudes had a chat with an Australian designer who does work and research on dressing the dead.
The Australian Government says it is phasing out its bilateral aid to China and India but has reaffirmed its aid commitment to the Asia-Pacific.  Do you agree with this change in focus?

This morning Phil Kafcaloudes spoke to the lawyer of one of the Indonesian boys freed from an Australian prison. Find out more on our website: http://blogs.radioaustralia.net.au/english/2011/asia/indonesian-boys-jailed-on-people-smuggling-charges-walk-free

Do you support or oppose paying more money to ensure your newest electronic gadgets are recycled properly? In the Pacific, experts are discussing options that might not be too popular with consumers. Read more here: http://blogs.radioaustralia.net.au/english/2011/pacific/radical-plans-for-pacific-waste-disposal
Do you visit famous grave sites when travelling or do you think they should be left alone? Read more here: http://blogs.radioaustralia.net.au/english/2011/asia/indonesia-promotes-grave-tourism
What type of alternative energy source do you trust the most?
In Australia it's NAIDOC week - a celebration of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultures. Isabelle Genoux caught up on some of the events planned in Queensland.
Should current governments have to apologise for the policies or actions of previous governments?
What bugs you when travelling on a plane?
link_name: Malaysia Airlines bans babies in first class

status_message: Have you been to New Caledonia? Radio Australia's Geraldine Coutts has been bringing us some great stories from New Caledonia, which you can listen to on our website.

What issues or achievements spring to your mind when reflecting on more than 60 years of communist rule in China? On Friday, we'll be talking about the Communist Party of China's 90th anniversary and we're keen to include your thoughts.
What are your thoughts about the announcement from Sir Michael Somare's family that the veteran leader should retire?
link_name: Somare too ill to continue, says family

status_message: Have you eaten any snack foods today? They may have contained palm oil. Palm oil production can be sustainable, but in many places its cultivation is damaging local environments. In PNG, residents are protesting a local plantation.

Ever been kitesurfing? Right now in the Cook Islands, they're holding their inaugural kitesurfing competition. Clement Paligaru will be discussing the event tomorrow, and we'd love to hear what you know about kitesurfing.
In 1987, Marian Wilkinson interviewed recent arrivals to Australia from Cambodia. 24 years later, she has revisited these families. Read more about this interview on our website: http://bit.ly/lluMRu
Where do you go to see and experience art where you are? In Venice, the streets and canals have been given over to art for their annual Biennale.
Caroline filed this story on the Chinese community in Tahiti. Australia embraces many different cultures, and so do many Asian and Pacific countries. What cultures are important to your community?

How's your English? A new report says that employers in Australia prefer native English speakers. Should English proficiency be the most important factor in skilled migration? Join the conversation on our website.
link_name: New English test will change the migration mix: report

status_message: Bands in the Pacific are tuning up for Pacific Break 2011. There are five new entrants that you can listen to on our website. Which is your favourite?
link_name: Pacific Break - New entrants from Fiji, Guam and New Caledonia

status_message: Are you getting excited about the Pacific Games? It sounds like the life of an athlete is pretty hard going. Weightlifters preparing for the Games are training three times a day, six days a week.

The ICC East Asia-Pacific Division 1 cricket tournament is happening in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea from July 4-7. PNG, Fiji, Vanuatu, Samoa and Japan will compete. Is cricket popular in your neighbourhood?
Vietnamese-Australian comedian Hung Le reflects on his journey as a refugee. Do you have a migration story to share with us?
A new TV series on SBS features ordinary Australians retracing the steps of an asylum seeker. How do you think you would go on this journey?

Australia's Minister for Agriculture will leave Indonesia with no deal on animal welfare standards for Australian cattle. What's your take on the Indonesia Peasant Union's call to prioritise their local industry? Join the discussion on our website.
link_name: Indonesian graziers want live cattle export ban to stay

status_message: What's the strangest way you've travelled?
Now that they have signed the UN Convention on Refugees, how do you feel about the possibility of off-shore processing in Nauru?
What do you think about the Dalai Lama's thoughts on refugees, China's crackdown on dissidents and the possibility of a totally independent Tibet?
link_name: Dalai Lama talks of independence and moral fibre

status_message: Next week we'll be looking at the palm oil industry in Papua New Guinea. It has many uses, but its cultivation can have a negative environmental impact. Can you name five products that use palm oil? Are you concerned about its impact?
Oliver Percovich is the Executive Director of Skateistan. Do you think skateboarding could take off in your area?
What's your reaction to the conviction of Abu Bakar Bashir?
Skateistan is a community aid project founded by three Australians teaching kids to skateboard in Kabul. What kind of project would help the youth in your neighbourhood?

The faces of some of the people you're hearing on Radio Australia.
Radio Australia celebrates 70 years of broadcasting
Radio Australia at the South Pacific Games in Samoa.

The crowd cheers the local favourites on at the South Pacific Games, in Apia, Samoa in 2007.

Radio Australia has covered every Commonwealth, Olympic and Pacific Games since 1984.  

Comprising 32 sports and 22 countries, the South Pacific Games were broadcast through Radio Australia's network of FM stations across the Pacific

Radio Australia Indonesian broadcaster Dian Islamiati reverses roles with a local 'becak' driver in Jogjakarta in 2006.

Radio Australia's Indonesian service is broadcast in Jogjakarta, Indonesia, through a popular local radio network.

In May 2006 Radio Australia worked with partners to provide aid and assistance to affected locals after an earthquake devastated Jogjakarta.

Radio Australia continued to support its local Indonesian partners in 2007 by hosting a fundraising event in Melbourne, which was headlined by renowned Indonesian jazz musician Jaya Suprana.

School children learning English from Radio Australia's then shortwave broadcasts in Cao Dai Pagoda in Can Thanh, Vietnam in November 1993.

The photo was sent by Phan Ba Dat a teacher of literature in a local secondary school.  Every week her class tuned in to Radio Australia's English learning lessons as their only external source of English teaching materials.
